TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Siddons was elected Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats in a national ballot of members which concluded on Friday, 15 August 1986. In that same ballot members saw fit to elect me as the Party Leader of the Australian Democrats. I pay the highest possible tribute to Senator Chipp, who, as Leader of the Party, entered the Senate in 1978 and who has now retired after 25 years in Australian political life. Senator Chipp worked untiringly in Parliament and in the community for the welfare of all Australians. His contribution to Australian politics, to the work of the Senate, and before that in another place, has been a unique and significant achievement, and I believe it will be remembered as such.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I congratulate Senator Haines on her election as Leader of the Australian Democrats and Senator Siddons on his election as Deputy Leader. We had the opportunity to say something about Senator Chipp on a previous occasion and I merely reiterate what I said then and confirm a considerable degree of agreement with what Senator Haines said on that matter.

—by leave-I, too, congratulate Senators Haines and Siddons for the positions they now occupy. I note in passing that Mr Wran knew when to leave, and I can only assume that in this case a departing Chipp means a sinking ship. In any event, I wish them well for the remainder of their terms in this place.

—by leave-I congratulate Senator Haines and Senator Siddons on attaining positions of leadership in the Australian Democrats and I look forward to working in co-operation with the Australian Democrats, especially on nuclear matters.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention to the presence in the President's Gallery of a delegation from the Canadian Parliament, including among its members the Speaker of the Senate, Speaker Charbonneau, and the Speaker of the House of Commons, Speaker Bosley. I welcome all the members of the delegation to Australia, and to Canberra in particular, and trust that they will enjoy the rest of their visit. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite the two Presiding Officers to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Speakers Charbonneau and Bosley were thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind him of three matters: Firstly, the Budget Statement No. 1 last year, which predicted `a marked deterioration in the terms of trade'; secondly, the June Treasury Round-up, which talked about terms of trade having fluctuated around a downward trend for the last 15 years; and lastly, the Treasurer's statement only three months ago that the Australian economy was `entirely robust' and `entirely healthy'. I ask the Minister: Why has the Government persistently misled the Australian people about the state of and prospects for the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has not been misleading the Australian people about the state of the economy. It is very easy for Senator Chaney to take three statements out of context and put them together in the way in which he has done. Let me be quite clear about this: It is quite true that the balance of the current account has been deteriorating in this country for some time. All the structural problems which have led to that deterioration have been the product of 30 years of conservative government in this country.

—Opposition senators can shout about those things now, but it is a fact which is widely recognised by intelligent commentators. Let me just remind honourable senators of a few things. There are people on the Opposition benches now-for God's sake, the alternative government of Australia, so called-who in 1980 and 1981 were talking up a phoney resources boom in Australia, were talking up a boom which was to lead to 500,000 jobs in this country and were ignoring the manufacturing sector about which they now complain. That is just part of the symbolism of what happened over the seven years of the last conservative Government and over the 23 years of the conservative Government before that. Everybody, from the National Farmers Federation and elsewhere, who comes to the Opposition and complains now says: `Where did we go wrong in all that period? They say: `We were misled by the National Country Party'-by Senator Boswell over here, the noisiest interjector in the place. Those are some of the structural and intellectual facts which relate to the current situation with which this country is confronted.

ANSWER.PARA: When the Australian Labor Party came into government in 1983 we had had seven years of conservative government, in the last four of which wage outcomes had been precisely double what they have been since this Government came to power, the size of the deficit had been significant in every year and inflation rates had been higher than they have been since this Government came to power. All those structural things were built in when this Government came to power in 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was the president of the union movement then? Who was in charge of the ACTU at the time?

—Senator Puplick, the mouse that roared! Who was chief trade unionist at the time? So Senator Puplick blames it all on him, does he, not on the Government of the time? He must have been a very good trade union official to deal with such a competent government as honourable senators opposite say it was. Let us try to get away from some of these childish alibis.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government is addressing those problems of the current account deficit. I have said, and have been saying it for two or three years now, that that problem will not be turned around overnight. It took 25 years to create under conservative governments and we will not turn it around overnight. I said that publicly last year. Many people on the Opposition side of the House came to me and said: `That is an interesting idea. That is probably right'. We are in this for the medium to long haul. What the people of this country need is a government with the courage to tackle some of the problems that honourable senators opposite ran away from over a number of years. We will do that, and the Opposition will find out about it tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I must say that the Minister moved on to safer ground when he quoted himself rather than Mr Keating. I ask: Does he agree that Mr Keating was entitled to say, and was speaking truthfully when he said, in May of this year in Parliament, `So what we have is an entirely healthy economy', and when on the same day he said: `Let me make the point that the Australian economy has been entirely robust'? How does he square that with his recent diatribe?
—Quite simply. It has to be done simply for the benefit of the Opposition; that is why I said that. What Mr Keating was talking about in May 1983 was the health of the Australian--
—In 1986, three months ago.

—It could not have been 1983, no; I agree with that. We had just taken over from honourable senators opposite then. In May 1986 what Mr Keating was talking about was the basic strength of the Australian domestic economy, and what he said was right. If the Opposition wants a simple lesson in economics we will give it one in the next week or two. If honourable senators look at the decline in commodity prices in the last year--
—It has been going on for 15 years.

—No, Senator. The structural problems have been going on for 15 years, exacerbated by that disastrous period of Fraser Government. Let me say this: What he said about the Australian domestic economy was right. He was probably making a comparison with the situation three years before when the domestic economy was in an abysmal mess in spite of good prices for commodities throughout the world.
—Mr President--
—Oh, the genius!

—The honourable senator should not worry, he will get his. Has the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry seen the report in yesterday's Australian citing the Western Australian Liberal Party member of the Legislative Assembly for Murchison-Eyre-one of Senator Chaney's colleagues-Mr Ross Lightfoot as urging the United States Administration to push through subsidised wheat sales to the Soviet Union and China as a means of undermining the Australian economy and Government? If so, can the Minister comment on the implications of this action for Australia's negotiating strategy on this matter in Washington?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the report to which Senator Cook referred in the Australian. I also saw it in a number of other newspapers today. Since I originally read the article only in the Australian I had some doubts as to its accuracy but as the same story has been repeated in a number of other more reputable and reliable newspapers its accuracy is now established beyond all doubt. I have also been told by a journalist that he possesses a copy of the letter which Mr Lightfoot wrote.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason why I found the report unbelievable, apart from first seeing it published in that newspaper, is that I could not believe that even a member of the Western Australian Liberal Party would seek publicly to sabotage the Australian economy for no more noble a motive than to assist that rat-bag bunch in the Opposition to get back into government. Mr Lightfoot spelt it right out in the article. He is a Western Australian Liberal Party member of parliament. He urged George Shultz and the United States Administration to continue to subsidise sales of wheat and sugar to the Soviet Union and China respectively. He urged the Reagan Administration to continue to foot the bill for the atrocities being committed in Afghanistan and thus to sabotage the Australian economy just so a bunch of scungy no-hopers, represented by Mr Lightfoot, would have a better chance of getting back into government.

There used to be under the Ian Smith regime in Rhodesia, of which many members of the Liberal Party were admirers, a criminal offence called economic treason. If there were such a criminal offence in Australia Mr Lightfoot would, without doubt, be behind bars. Mr Lightfoot wants to make Australians suffer for no more noble a motive than to assist a discredited Opposition to get back into government on the economic misfortunes to which the United States Administration's present policy is contributing. Liberal members will stop at nothing to satisfy their power lust. Most appalling of all, I have yet to hear Mr Lightfoot being repudiated or disowned by any other member of the Liberal Party. Surely, at the very least, somebody who indulges in economic sabotage to the extent that Mr Lightfoot has-call it economic treason if you like-should be rebuked and repudiated by the members of his own party. I would go further and say that the minimum penalty which the Liberal Party ought to impose on Mr Lightfoot, if it wants to retain any credibility at all in Australian politics, is to expel him forthwith.

Finally, I wonder what the National Party thinks about this matter. It purports to represent the interests of Australian farmers. It is in coalition with the Liberal Party, which contains Mr Lightfoot, who has attempted to further undermine the prices being received for Australian agricultural commodities. Some people-and I do not count myself in this group-might offer excuses for the Liberal Party not repudiating or expelling one of its own, but where is that great champion of the Australian farmer, Ian Sinclair? What does he have to say about Mr Lightfoot deliberately, and in a premeditated way, attempting to further undermine the prices being received by Australian farmers and the income being received by this country? I have noted the silence on the other side. Not one member of the Liberal Opposition has given any indication that he has repudiated Mr Lightfoot. Not one member of the National Party has given any indication that he or she has repudiated Mr Lightfoot. The Western Australian Liberal Party leader, Mr Bill Hassell, to the best of my knowledge, has still said and done nothing. Of course, that greatest coward of them all, Mr John Howard, has remained mute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will withdraw that last remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's weekend reference to Australia now facing a war-like situation and the long term deterioration in this country's terms of trade as revealed in last year's Budget papers, particularly since, as Senator Chaney reminded us, it was only recently that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were extolling the virtues of our strong and growing economy. Does the Minister acknowledge that a three-fold increase in our overseas debt can hardly be seen as effectively addressing the problem of our current deficit, as he has just indicated the Government was doing? Does he acknowledge that his Government's failure to take a stronger line with the unions on wages and work practices, its support for the productivity wages rise, its high interest rate policy and its anti-investment tax measures are major reasons for the mess in which Australia now finds itself?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not get all the details of that question, but I do not think that matters. This refrain which stems from the Opposition about these various issues is so boringly familiar. In the last period of this Parliament we spent all the time talking about wage outcomes and results in this country. Let me remind the Senate of a few facts about wages in terms of the comparative questions to which Senator Collard is addressing his mind. I remind you, Mr President, that in the past three years, since this Government came to power, the wage outcomes have been in the order of 7 or 6 per cent a year, compared with previous years' wage outcomes in this country of 14, 15 or 16 per cent. That has been steadily so for three years.
—Could we afford it?

—Yes-can we afford it? A lot of the members of the Opposition give much vaunted attention to the situation in the United Kingdom. What a brilliant situation that is. John Howard is a sort of Margaret Thatcher in drag in Australia, trying to emulate that draconian Government in the United Kingdom. There is a lot of talk about all that. Look at the wage outcomes by comparison in the United Kingdom in the past three years-plus 11 1/2 per cent in real wage growth. It is minus 3 per cent in Australia. True, its inflation rate is coming down. It has not had a devaluation to the extent that we have had-nothing like it. It has had enormous unemployment accompanying those sorts of wage outcomes. Senator Collard had a number of bits in his question which are all fairly familiar-wages, work practices, and so on. I guess this must be the first government in the history of this country that has seriously addressed the question of work practices in Australian industry.
—What about the redundancy practices?

—Order! I call Senator Boswell to order. I ask honourable senators to bear in mind that so far there have been only three questions and three answers. A number of answers have been lengthened by interjections. I ask the Senate to realise that, it being the first day of session, a number of honourable senators wish to ask questions. I call Senator Button.

—Thank you, Mr President. Senator Boswell queried the expression `work practices'. Observing his conduct here in the Senate I do not think he would know what a work practice is. He spends half his time dozing. However, let me say that this is the first government in the history of this country that has addressed the question of work practices in Australian industry. It is not possible to turn those things around over night, but this Government will turn them around. In Australia the question is not about wage rates. That is not the real issue, except for the devaluation and inflationary effects of that. Apart from those effects, the issue of long term improvements in this economy does not concern wage rates relative to those of other countries. The issue is about the method of doing work in Australia, about management and about productivity. That is what it is about. Those are the questions which this Government, for the first time in Australian history, has been addressing.

ANSWER.PARA: I inform Senator Collard that turning those things around will be difficult. Under Senator Collard's present leader there would be no hope of turning around any of those things. The people of this country would walk away from his party in droves if it tried the sorts of things it proposes and accompanied them with the other silly, ratbag collection of policies which have been advanced in the community. The Government's policies require time, and they are working. If the honourable senator wants it put in simple, practical terms, I ask him to look at the man days lost in the steel industry under his Government. Some 43,000 man days a year were lost. What was it last year? Last year 4,000 man days were lost. Industrial disputation in this country now is 40 per cent of what it was under his Government. They are the basic sorts of things that honourable senators opposite have to face up to. They have to think very hard about what they can do, because their sitting here and sniping about wages will not bring about a solution to these problems. Senator Collard can go through again all the things that he mentioned, but I would give him much the same sort of answer. However, I defer to the President's desire to be brief.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance whether he has seen the transcript of a speech made by the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, to the annual convention of the New South Wales division of the Liberal Party on Friday, 8 August. If so, can the Minister provide the Senate and the Australian people with a cost assessment of undertakings that the Leader of the Opposition made in that speech, together with other undertakings recently made by the Leader and other members of the coalition front bench?
—Order! Before I call the Minister for Finance I draw the Minister's attention to my earlier statement asking Ministers to keep their answers as short as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the transcript of that speech. I think that speech entitles Mr Howard to nomination as newspeaker of the year. Among other things-I think this is the most spectacular line in the speech-he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian people do not want new spending commitments from us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister has accused the Leader of the Opposition of lying. I think that is out of order.
—Order! I did not hear that. There is no point of order.
—That was the most spectacular line. I said that the Leader of the Opposition was entitled to be nominated for newspeaker of the year. Perhaps I should have said newspeaker of the decade. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian people do not want new spending commitments from us.

The Australian people already have new spending commitments from the Opposition-$1,500m from the Liberal Party plus another $500m from the National Party, added on by its 14-point program for agricultural reconstruction. I presume that was the grave-digger's answer, or the undertaker's answer, to Mr Lightfoot's attempts to bury Australian agriculture-a 14-point rescue package costing the taxpayers $500m to try to repair some of the damage which people like Mr Lightfoot would do to Australian agriculture and which the Liberal Party, by implication, supports. We have not yet had one member of the Liberal Party in this House-nor anywhere else to my knowledge-who has repudiated what Mr Lightfoot has done. On the outlay side, those commitments that were given then, plus all the other commitments, would add $2 billion to the deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Two billion dollars-an extra $2 billion worth of expenditure promises. I should reinforce that by saying that at the Country Liberal Party Conference at Alice Springs a couple of weeks ago the Leader of the National Party, Mr Sinclair, repeated the Opposition's commitment to construct the Darwin to Alice Springs railway. It would appear that when the National Party gets in front of its own redneck cheer squad it just cannot help itself; it does things that are politically stupid as well as economically stupid.

ANSWER.PARA: If one looks at the receipts side of the Budget-there is a range of estimates here, depending upon how one wishes to interpret a particular promise the Opposition has given-receipts would fall by between $3 billion and $5 billion. In other words, if Mr Howard were put in the position of implementing his policies, they would add between $5 billion and $7 billion to the Budget deficit. That would leave us with a Budget deficit well above $10 billion, which is even bigger than the deficit he left in the bag for this Government to pick up when he was kicked out of office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security by reminding him of the Prime Minister's statements that all sectors of the community must share equally in the sacrifices demanded in these times of stringency. Does the Minister believe that a reduced deficit achieved by cuts to welfare spending in circumstances where the Government has not yet achieved its 1983 election promise to raise pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings is a more socially equitable arrangement than, for example, reducing the deficit by closing off taxation rip-offs, such as the continued use by wealthy businessmen of taxpayer-subsidised loans to finance their essentially non-productive takeovers and share raids?

—In Question Time today obviously I am not going to anticipate anything that is contained in the Budget. With the Prime Minister and other members on this side, I believe that any burden that has to be borne by the community should be borne equitably. I believe we have treated and will continue to treat pensions so that we get closer to that aim of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. I do not believe that anything we do now will stop us from getting closer to that aim. I must say very gently and very kindly to the new Leader of the Australian Democrats that for her to accuse this Government of a way in which it is more concerned about tax dodgers than it is about those people who are recipients of welfare expenditure comes very strangely from the leader of a party the majority of whose members voted against legislation in this Parliament that would have recovered some $700m in tax forgone, which we could have used to assist the people about whom she claims to be concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. No doubt the Minister will have seen numerous reports that the Liberal Party under the leadership of Mr Howard has promised to abolish fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, tax on lump sum superannuation payouts, and the assets test. Can the Minister give the Senate an indication of the cost of those measures? Do these promises represent what could be called financial irresponsibility in the present economic circumstances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of the question is unequivocally yes, it does represent financial irresponsibility. Anybody familiar with the record in government of the present Leader of the Opposition as the key economic Minister in the Fraser Government-the Treasurer-would not expect anything but financial irresponsibility from him. His desperate last Budget, which had absolutely no economic strategy, contained a political strategy aimed at the re-election of the Fraser Government and nothing else-a strategy which, let it be noted for the record, failed. That Budget had no economic strategy. As I said earlier, it left this Government holding the bag with a $10 billion Budget deficit, the foundations for which were laid by Mr Howard in his last year of irresponsibility as Treasurer in the late and unlamented last coalition Government.

ANSWER.PARA: To give precise answers as to the revenue costs of the promises which the Opposition Leader has made would require the incorporation of some of the parameters, assumptions and economic forecasts which are contained in the Budget which will be delivered tonight. I have already gone on the public record, some time ago, saying that the promises regarding specific measures which Mr Howard made in Adelaide at the Liberal Party conference would cost the revenue more than $1 billion. That, of course, is only a small component of the package of fiscal irresponsibility which Mr Howard is putting to the country. The other promises on taxation which he has made would cost the revenue an additional $2 billion to $4 billion, depending on how one liked to interpret it-without even taking into account the $2 billion the Opposition collectively has promised to add to expenditure.

There can be only one or two possible outcomes from that sort of expenditure and those sorts of tax policies were they to be implemented. Either the deficit would blow out in excess of $10 billion, that is, an even higher deficit than we inherited from Mr Howard the last time he was dumped from office, or, alternatively, the taxation promises would make it absolutely impossible for the present Opposition, if in government, to deliver lower marginal tax rates. Again, this is absolutely consistent with Mr Howard's record in government. He was Treasurer for five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister is now clearly debating the answer. I ask him to bring his answer to a conclusion.

—I conclude by saying that Mr Howard had five years as Treasurer to reduce marginal tax rates and he did not do it. He will not do it if he gets the opportunity again. Indeed, he could not do it, given all the other irresponsible promises he has made to which Senator Foreman has referred.

—I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General: Will he inform the Senate whether Mr Justice Murphy intends to continue sitting as a member of the High Court of Australia and, if so, for how long?
—It is my understanding that he does not intend to continue sitting, that the condition of his health makes that impossible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Recent changes to the pharmaceutical benefits schedule having engendered some adverse comment, can the Minister please describe the process and the rationale involved in revision of the schedule?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Decisions about additions to and deletions from the pharmaceutical benefits schedule are made on the recommendation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. That Committee considers the schedule and makes decisions and recommendations to the Minister, who has no ability to remove from or add items to the list without the Committee's recommendation. As Senator Giles has said, recently some 46 items or formulations were removed. They were items such as low dose analgesics, some aspirins and paracetamols, some expectorants, some cough suppressants and vitamins and some antihistamines. Almost all of these items are available across the counter without prescription. In fact, many of them are available in supermarkets in the community.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been some adverse comment. I remind honourable senators that over the years when anything was removed from the list-I remember various laxatives and other items being removed from the list-there was some adverse comment, usually from some patients who had been on those items for a long time. However, on this occasion much of the adverse comment was engendered by officials of the Australian Medical Association, particularly in Queensland but I understand also in Tasmania, who took it upon themselves to criticise the decisions of the Government and this Committee. I remind honourable senators that the Committee is made up of nine people who are pharmacists, pharmacologists or doctors. Six of those nine people are nominees of the Australian Medical Association and they make their decisions on the basis of medical activities. In this case they made their decisions because the drugs were of little therapeutic value. As a side line to this there are obviously financial implications of the decision they have made. The financial implications are these: These substances are available, as I have said, across the counter or in supermarkets from about $2; some of them cost up to $3. To provide them under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, say in New South Wales, costs a Medicare consultation, which is $13.30, the cost of the drug, which is usually about $1.60-in the case, say, of paracetamol $1.66-and there is a dispensing fee of $2.40. So the taxpayer is expected to pay some $17 or $18 for a substance which is available across the counter or in the supermarket and which is of little or no therapeutic value at all. Other aspirins, aspirins that are used for the treatment of rheumatism, et cetera, stay on the list.

Medical practitioners who are speaking for the AMA and who have made this adverse comment, I am sorry to say, are acting in an irresponsible way medically and are clearly acting purely to try to embarrass the Government. They are acting in a party political way. They do not deserve their positions. The members of the medical profession in this country who have elected those people do not deserve to have them representing them. They are dishonest, they are acting in a party political way and they are causing distress to patients and pensioners in this country unnecessarily. They are a disgrace to the profession; they are even a disgrace as politicians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to recent comments by the Attorney about the Government's intention with regard to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. Does the Government intend to proceed with the legislation in the Budget session or indeed in the life of this Parliament? If not, does this mean that the Australian people have heard the last of this unnecessary and divisive Bill of Rights or does the Government propose to achieve its aims in some other way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I advise the Senate that the Government does not propose to proceed with the Bill and will withdraw it from the Senate at the first appropriate opportunity. This is not due to any lack of commitment on the part of the Government to the principles underlying the Bill. The Bill is nothing more, as we have said for many years, than an attempt to better protect the civil and political rights of all Australians against interference by governments. The Bill has been the subject of a quite disgraceful campaign of deliberate misrepresentation and deception on the part of the Opposition. That campaign has led to unfounded, but widespread, concern in the community about the terms of the Bill. It is no matter of pride to this nation that on this occasion at least it would appear that the troglodytes, the neanderthals, the drones and the thugs have had their way.

ANSWER.PARA: The reality is, however, that this Government must take account of the very great practical problems which have been caused by the Senate's deliberate obstruction of the Bill. The Bill has been before the Parliament since 9 October last year. During the autumn sittings, 36 hours of debate on this Bill and associated legislation-which is, I believe, a record since federation- has occurred, in the Senate leading to quite unacceptably minuscule progress on the Bill. This was due, it must be said, to deliberate filibustering tactics on the part of the Opposition, not least the most grotesque filibusterer of them all, the asker of this question. For instance, the list of the proposed amendments to the Bill, which was circulated prior to the debate, contained no proposal to amend articles 3, 4 or 5 of the Bill, yet the so-called debate on those articles occupied more than 50 pages of Hansard. No amendment was moved or anticipated in respect of those articles. Article 5 was not even voted on.

I must say that the Australian Democrats have not assisted this process by their unwillingness to keep the debate within reasonable bounds. Although some of them had indicated their support for this Bill, that support has not, I regret to say, been reflected in the kind of procedural support which was obviously necessary if this Bill was to get its passage through this House. It is more in sorrow than in anger that I report that the Democrats, as has so often been the case, simply have not put their money where their mouths are in regard to their commitment to this Bill.

For all those reasons, not least of which are some additional financial stringency considerations which we will hear more about tonight, the Government has decided, as I have said, to withdraw the legislation and not proceed with it in this Parliament. The substance of the Bill of Rights concept and the particular terms of the Bill will, as the Attorney-General has foreshadowed, however, be referred to the Constitutional Commission in order that this highly valuable concept can be further explored in that environment.

I also mention that the proposed Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, which was to replace the Human Rights Commission-scheduled to meet its demise as a result of a sunset clause in the present legislation-will proceed, albeit with a slightly different title to reflect the absence of a Bill of Rights jurisdiction. It will be moved that the Bill now before the Parliament have its title altered to that simply of Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, to reflect the fact that it will be concerned essentially with proceedings under the Sex Discrimination Act and the Racial Discrimination Act, but it will also retain its jurisdiction to investigate complaints and make reports in relation to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the other matters set out in the Bill, which have attracted, of course, as they should, a degree of community support.

I hope that that sufficiently answers the question and means that at least we will not be subjected to the further chirrupings of Senator Walters on this issue-which will be a blessed and merciful release for us all-and also that some of those petitioners will cease getting writers' cramp in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Education aware of concerns felt by the Western Australian College of Advanced Education about proposed changes in tertiary education in Western Australia-namely, a new tertiary education institution at Yanchep, and the renaming of the Western Australian Institute of Technology as a university of technology? If so, what is the Government's view of these proposals and the concerns expressed by the College of Advanced Education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very well aware of the concerns of staff and students at the Western Australian College of Advanced Education about the issues mentioned in Senator McIntosh's question and, indeed, of staff and students of a number of other higher education institutions in that State. Two weeks ago I spent some time in Perth, where I had the opportunity to explain to representatives of all the higher education institutions and student organisations and staff associations, the Commonwealth's views on the range of changes which are being proposed-or, at least, floated-by the Western Australian Government at this stage.

ANSWER.PARA: Fundamentally, without taking up too much of the time of the Senate, our position is this: We have a national responsibility for proper planning of the development of higher education throughout Australia-in Western Australia and all other States and Territories. We need to ensure that developments will as far as possible give equal opportunity of access to higher education to Australians in all parts of the country. Therefore, when changes of direction or new or amalgamated institutions are proposed at State level, discussions with the Commonwealth are necessary so that those proposals can be assessed in terms of what they will offer-such as improved educational standards and access-and in terms of the fair and balanced development of the rest of Australia.

The Western Australian Government's proposal is to change the Institute's name to technical university. That proposal has not been agreed to by us. There is no need to make that name change. WAIT, which is an institute of technology, has a good reputation which goes beyond Australia. It has some off-shore operations-for example, its external studies program in Singapore. In the view of the Commonwealth and many of the States, WAIT's development is in no way hampered by the fact that it is an institute of technology. It seems that some people associated with that institute believe that, by securing the Western Australian Government's agreement to a name change, the institution will automatically be entitled to a higher level of Commonwealth funding. That is simply not the case. Funds for pure research are scarce, as all honourable senators know. Our commitments to existing universities are already stretched to the limit. It is simply not possible and, I suggest, not fair for one institution to decide that it will queue jump with respect to research funds by persuading its State government to change that institution's name. So we are not interested in that proposal, and I have made that clear to the Western Australian authorities.

The Western Australian Institute of Technology is working on a proposal to incorporate the land at Yanchep as an additional campus. It may be possible that such an incorporation could go ahead in a way that meets our guidelines, which are to protect the standards of public institutions, the access of Australians to those institutions on a merit basis and the use of public funds made available for public purposes. Should a proposal that meets all those criteria come forward, the Commonwealth would be sympathetic to it. But if a proposal did not meet those criteria, we would not agree to it. At this stage I am waiting on a proposal from WAIT with regard to the Yanchep campus. I will inform Senator McIntosh and all interested parties of the Commonwealth's response when that proposal is to hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Treasurer agree with Premier Burke of Western Australia that the fringe benefits tax has gone awry and that there is an urgent need for reassessment of both the impact of the tax and its method of collection? Does he think that Premier Unsworth is correct in describing the tax as an administrative nightmare? In view of those comments, opposition by other Labor leaders and objections raised in Caucus yesterday by Mr Ron Edwards, MP, does the Government intend making any changes aimed at reducing the impact of the tax or simplifying its administration?

—The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and anyone else with any common sense would say that, if an equally effective but easier and less expensive method of administering any scheme were presented, of course a government would be stupid not to accept that advice. Whether it would be cheaper, easier and so on would of course be a matter of judgment. The only people I can think of who would be likely to reject that proposition are members of the Opposition. As to the comments of Premier Burke and Premier Unsworth, Premier Unsworth has particular problems which are domestic rather than national and there are precedents for politicians throwing a smoke-screen around themselves. As for Premier Burke, I will be telling him something of what I think of his comments when he returns to Western Australia. Essentially, the answer to Senator Messner's questions is no.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: CHEMICAL WEAPONS PRODUCTION

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether it is correct that the United States Administration wants to push ahead with the resumption of chemical weapons production. I also note with alarm reports today which speak approvingly about biological weapons. What action has the Australian Government taken on behalf of Australians to discourage the United States from its course? If no action has yet been taken, will the Government make clear to its contacts in high places in the United States our abhorrence of the development of chemical and biological weapons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the defence budget for fiscal year 1987 submitted by President Reagan to Congress does include a request for funds to modernise the United States of America's chemical weapons arsenal, and that does cause us some concern. The United States unilaterally ceased production of chemical weapons in 1969. The United Kingdom destroyed its stockpiles of chemical weapons at around the same time. The Government is not aware of any matching response by the Soviet Union.

ANSWER.PARA: The United States Administration has justified its request for its chemical weapons modernisation program in terms of the need to reduce the Soviet Union's incentive to use chemical weapons against the United States or its allies by rebuilding and maintaining an adequate United States chemical warfare capability. It also believes that modernisation would provide an inducement for the Soviet Union to conclude a comprehensive chemical weapons convention. The Australian Government's position on chemical weapons is well known. We support the early conclusion of a comprehensive convention that would ban the production, stockpiling and use of all chemical weapons. Such a convention would involve the destruction of all existing stockpiles of chemical weapons and the dismantling of chemical weapons production facilities. It would, therefore, remove the need for any country or security alliance to acquire or modernise its chemical weapons capacity in order to deter a potential attack with chemical weapons.

I interpolate that it is a rather strange prospect that one needs to build up one's stock of chemical weapons in order to create the incentive for a chemical weapons convention to then occur, but such is the alarming reasoning with which we are in fact confronted in the real world of international deterrence. Australia's delegation to the Conference on Disarmament is playing a significant role in the negotiations for this convention which have, it must be said, made encouraging progress so far this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Since coming to power the Hawke Government has abolished exchange controls, loosened regulations on foreign investment in property and other areas of investment, and generally deregulated the economy to the advantage of foreign interests, while harming ordinary Australians. Given the lack of concern this Government has shown for the economic sovereignty of this country, can the Minister give an assurance that the Foreign Investment Review Board will not be further weakened or scrapped completely?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am puzzled by this question because there seems to be a good deal of confusion in the ranks of the Australian Democrats as to what they are in favour of and what they are not in favour of. On the one hand I have noted that they have been repeatedly critical of overseas debt incurred by a number of people to acquire equity in Australian assets. Indeed, as I recall it, they have been extremely critical of that. Therefore, I expected that they would have been in favour of foreigners taking equity rather than debt interests in Australian activities. The only conclusion I can reasonably draw from Senator Siddons's question is that he is opposed to foreign equity in businesses operating in Australia. It seems to me that the Democrats are speaking with at least two voices on this question.

ANSWER.PARA: I suggest to the Democrats that they should have some internal discussions to see whether they are for or against foreigners having financial interests-that is, making loans to Australian enterprises or Australians-or whether they are in favour of equity. Perhaps they are against both. I suppose they could be against both if they were starting from scratch 150 or nearly 200 years ago; they could be against the practice of Australians either surrendering equity in Australian enterprises or having debts abroad. The price of that would be, of course, a very much slower rate of economic growth and economic development. I am willing to concede that there are arguments to be put both for and against debt or equity.

I want to close by making this observation: Whilst a higher proportion of equity may-I do not think it necessarily follows-give Australians more effective control over Australian enterprises, the replacement of equity by debt exposes Australia to much higher risks. Indeed that is the experience the country is going through right now. Ever since the talk of a resources boom-a boom which did not happen-of the early 1980s, Australia has maintained a very high current account deficit. The record current account deficit was in Mr Howard's second last year as Treasurer, when it equalled 6 per cent of gross domestic product. A lot of that was in the form of loans raised abroad to directly fund either resource development projects or the infrastructure for them. Now that those industries are less profitable than was anticipated at that time, we as a nation are stuck with the interest payments on that debt, whereas if there had been a higher proportion of foreign equity the foreigners would have had to accept a higher share of the cost by way of lower profits and lower dividends.

This has happened to Australia before. We were in a similar situation in the 1920s due to reckless borrowings, mostly by coalition governments. We had a very high level of foreign debt as we went into the 1930s, with the difference then being that most of that debt was government debt. In short, if a nation is to be a capital importer, as Australia traditionally has been, the more it substitutes borrowings overseas and debt for equity the more exposed it will be in the prices for its commodities to adverse movements of the type which have occurred in the last 12 or 18 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I have been given a rather convoluted lecture on capital versus debt financing. I direct the Minister to the very simple question I asked, which he has not yet answered. Can the Minister give us an assurance that the Foreign Investment Review Board will not be further weakened or scrapped completely?

—I understand that the Treasurer has made a statement on that. I will confess that sometimes when I have been present when decisions have been made I find it a bit difficult to remember whether they have been announced publicly. I believe the Treasurer has made a statement of changes to the FIRB. If he has not done so I will seek a definitive statement from him in the near future. I have no reason to believe that the policy of the Treasurer which I believe has already been announced will be changed.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has there been any particular pattern in the unemployment rates of the various Australian States in recent years? Have any particular States tended to have consistently high unemployment rates? If so, what reasons can the Minister offer for the existence of that pattern?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a very long time indeed there has been a pattern in unemployment rates by States. Queensland and Tasmania have consistently had the highest unemployment rates. Indeed, not since April 1984 has any State other than Queensland or Tasmania had the highest unemployment rate. In other words, for two and a half years either Queensland or Tasmania has had the highest unemployment rate of any State. At the moment Queensland is leading the field. It has the worst unemployment rate in the country and has had for the last four consecutive months. Last month, Queensland's unemployment rate soared to 9.6 per cent. I do not know whether that is ominous, but except for having a percentage sign instead of being in billions of dollars, that is the same figure as that of the deficit which Mr Howard left this Government. For six of the last 12 months Queensland has had the highest unemployment rate of any State.

ANSWER.PARA: To put the figures in another context, more people in Queensland are receiving the unemployment benefit than in Victoria in spite of the fact that Victoria has a 65 per cent higher population-or, more accurately, higher labour force-than does Queensland. Finally, it ought to be noted that this phenomenon in Queensland of consistently having the highest unemployment rate of any State is not related to what some Queenslanders would call the southern dole bludger syndrome because Queensland has suffered a net loss of about 5,200 people in the key 20 to 34-year-old job seeker group in the last 12 months' issued figures. As to what one attributes the fact that Queensland and Tasmania consistently have the highest unemployment rates, the answer is self-evident. It is due to mismanagement by the respective State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation whether it is correct that it is not proposed to construct an international airport terminal in Brisbane until 1992. Is the Minister aware that tenders were called recently for a hotel on the airport site and one of the proposals included the construction of an international terminal as well as a hotel? Can the Minister confirm that the proposal for the combined international air terminal and hotel is being reviewed on its merits along with the other proposals received? Does the Minister not agree that the growth of tourism in Queensland and the fact that Expo 1988 is being held in Brisbane highlight the need for an international air terminal as soon as possible and that it should not be deferred until 1992?

—I have briefings on 19 different issues dealing with aviation and no information at all on the question raised by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. As she has raised a matter of some importance I will seek an early response so that I will be able to reply to her.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance seen the letter from the Liberal Party seeking campaign funds under the slogan `Win Back Government'? Can he comment on the claims in this letter that not only would a Liberal government remove the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax but also that it would introduce a five-point plan including industrial relations reform, greater recognition of the crucial role of export industries and reduced government interference?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks, troops. Because of what I will say next, I am glad that this has support. In the light of the Liberal Opposition's spending list of $2 billion in extra expenditure, can the Minister elaborate on how reduced taxes go with increased spending? Does he also think that the slogan of winning back government is a blatant statement of the Liberal Opposition's intention rather than what is best for Australia?
—Have you ever heard of the Laffer curve?
—Patrick Partners style economics.

—I did not think anyone still took the Laffer curve seriously. As my colleague Senator Grimes suggests, perhaps one needs a background in Patrick Partners to do so because figures did not mean much for Patrick Partners, and while reality had little to do--
—Order! I ask the Minister to answer Senator Crowley's question.

—Certainly, Mr President. It is a quite substantial divorcement from reality. I have seen the letter to which Senator Crowley refers. I suppose that it is the letter. The letter has been addressed to somebody but the name has been wiped out and I cannot read it even through the back. I do not know whether it was sent to Senator Crowley. There is a precedent for that sort of thing, because Mr Sinclair sent a letter to Senator Grimes appealing for funds, so I suppose that one should not be surprised if Mr Howard sent one to Senator Crowley appealing for funds. It would appear that both the Opposition parties--
—I addressed the reply to George Sinclair.
—Did he send a reply back to the honourable senator?
—Yes.

—George Sinclair replied to Senator Grimes's reply. Apparently both Opposition parties have listed medical practitioners-I think that is the most logical conclusion that one could draw from these facts-to whom they send letters appealing for funds. I have already dealt with the question of taxation in two previous answers I gave to questions in the Senate today. Senator Crowley did, however, raise the question of the Liberal Party's commitment to deregulate the economy if in government. Mr Howard was in government and a Minister for seven years. He held the key economic portfolio for five of those years and he deregulated nothing. So I would prefer to judge the worth of that letter by the record of the person who signed it rather than the rhetoric within it. Anybody who has a passing knowledge of Australian politics or political history would have noticed that the Liberal Party is always, in government, in coalition, federally, with the National Party, and that the National Party is still the greatest bunch of pork-barrellers and regulators that the world has ever seen. It has reached its highest point of development in the State of Queensland, where the National Party is in fact the Government. So, whatever brave rhetoric may pour out of Mr Howard's mouth now, should he be back in coalition government I predict that absolutely nothing will happen because the National Party would not let him act. It has been a longstanding propensity of the Liberal Party to be heroic in opposition and cowardly in coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a brief statement to correct a matter of fact contained in a speech I made to the Senate in the last session.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June last, during the matters of public interest debate, I expressed my concern about the recommendation of the Kerr White report that the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine at Sydney University be replaced. In the course of my remarks I referred to some statements by the United States health professionals that suggested that Dr Kerr White, the head of the investigating committee which produced the report, was biased against schools of public health. I quoted from a letter from Dr Jacob Brody, Dean of the Office of Public Health, University of Illinois, in which Dr Brody said:

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect they stem at least in some part, from the fact that he-
that is, Dr Kerr White-
was fired from Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health Faculty and harbours some bitterness about this.

I quoted from that letter accurately believing that it was factually correct. Dr Blewett, the Minister for Health, has now drawn to my attention first a telegram and then a letter which relate to this matter. The telegram from Dr Brody to Dr Blewett states:

I was in error in my letter to C. B. Kerr for which I certainly owe Kerr White an apology. Dr White was not fired from Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health. I regret having communicated false information.
A letter sent subsequently by Dr Brody to Dr Kerr White states:
I apologise to you for transmitting incorrect information when I stated you had been fired from Johns Hopkins. I was misinformed and clearly in error.

I am grateful to the Minister for Health for having drawn those to my attention. By quoting accurately from Dr Brody's first letter, it appears that I have repeated an untrue assertion about Dr Kerr White. I therefore make it clear to honourable senators that Dr Kerr White was not fired from Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health but in fact resigned. I should also make it clear that this statement in no way lessens my concern about the recommendations of the Kerr White report that the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine be replaced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of background, honourable senators will be aware of the disastrous mine explosion at Moura and the resultant deaths of 12 people in that mine. Following that disaster, in addition to the normal workers compensation and superannuation payouts through the miners' pension fund a public fund was set up. This fund is controlled, in fact, by the unions. A lot of people contributed to that fund. More importantly, the employer at Moura, Thiess Dampier Mitsui Coal Pty Ltd, kicked off the fund with a contribution of $250,000. The company, having either promised that money or given it, was then advised by its tax consultants that its contribution to that fund would attract a fringe benefits tax. I was advised accordingly. I checked that claim with tax experts within the mining industry and within the chartered accounting profession. Generally the view was that, yes, it would attract the fringe benefits tax, for the following reasons: First of all, the definition of `employee' includes employees past, present and future; secondly, `employee' also includes an associate; and, thirdly, a fringe benefit is defined as any benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: That fund was set up simply to provide for the families of those people who were so tragically killed. I asked the company involved whether it had sought a ruling from the Australian Taxation Office. The company said that it had not but would be applying for such a ruling. It said, however, that if it did ask for a ruling it would be lucky to get a reply within 12 months because that is the time it normally takes to get a ruling from the Taxation Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask Senator Parer to make his personal explanation. He has been given leave to make a personal explanation and I suggest that he is quite exceeding the bounds of such an explanation.
—Thank you, Mr President.
—Just say you were wrong.

—I will not say that I was wrong. I am right. As a result of that announcement some quite hysterical claims were made by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright). At that stage those claims lacked credibility, because the honourable member for Capricornia lacks credibility.
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to withdraw that remark.
—Mr President, I withdraw that remark.
—I ask Senator Parer to confine his remarks to a personal explanation, or I shall ask him to resume his seat.

—Thank you, Mr President. I claimed, quite correctly, that under the legislation as it was written-I very clearly pointed this out-the company involved was liable for a fringe benefits tax. That was supported by expert advice. Subsequently-this is the point of my personal explanation and my claim that I have been misrepresented-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) appeared on State Affair on Channel 7 on 14 August. During that program, either because of ignorance or deliberately-I do not know which-he tried to say that I had said that the beneficiaries would be subject to the fringe benefits tax. At no time did I say that. I said that the company that had made the contribution would be subject to fringe benefits tax. Subsequently the Taxation Office or the Treasury made a few statements which I think are worth repeating. One of those statements was that the payment was an ex gratia payment.
—Order! The honourable senator clearly is out of order. I ask him to resume his seat or else come to the point of his personal explanation.
—Thank you, Mr President. I will come to the point. The point is that I was misrepresented by the Prime Minister, either through ignorance or deliberately.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I present a special report of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry which covers the effect of Mr Justice Murphy's illness upon the Commission's proceedings. For the information of the Senate, I also table a statement by the Presiding Officers, dated 4 August 1986, following a meeting with the Presiding Member of the Commission; and copies of letters, dated 6 August 1986, forwarding a copy of the Commission's special report to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button); the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney); the Leader of the Australian Democrats and the two Independent senators, Senator Harradine and Senator Vallentine.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Opposition does not believe that this is the appropriate moment to debate this special report of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry to you and Madam Speaker which you have tabled. However, I must put on record the fact that the Opposition is very concerned about a number of aspects of the report and the views which are reported to the Senate and which are held by the Commission. In particular, I refer to this statement in paragraph 5:

SPEECH.PARA: The situation which existed at the date when the Act became law, 13 May 1986, was such that Parliament regarded the task allotted to the Commission as one of national importance. That situation remains unchanged.
It proceeds to state:

Counsel assisting the Commission estimate that the hearing of evidence on all present allegations, including cross-examination, up to the stage at which the Judge might be called upon to give evidence would last at least four months, and possibly much longer.

It concludes by indicating that it would need an extension of its time from 30 September this year to 31 March 1987 but reports, however, that the prognosis in a medical certificate presents obvious problems to the Commission in continuing its hearings. The Opposition has given, and will continue to give, very close consideration to this report. We understand that the Government intends to introduce legislation today in relation to this question following receipt of this report. We do not believe it is suitable in those circumstances to debate this question until that legislation is brought into the Parliament. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR SYDNEY AMBROSE NEGUS

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 1 August 1986, of former Senator Sydney Ambrose Negus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 1 August 1986, of Sydney Ambrose Negus, Senator for the State of Western Australia from 1971 to 1974, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and the members of his family in their bereavement.

Sydney Ambrose Negus was born on 12 March 1912 in Perth. He was a building contractor by occupation and won his seat as an independent senator for Western Australia at the November 1970 election. Those of us who are long in the political tooth, if that is the appropriate expression, will recall that he fought his campaign solely on the abolition of Federal death duties. He entered the Senate in July 1971 and lost his seat at the May 1974 double dissolution election. Sydney Negus served with the Australian Imperial Force between 1928 and 1931. He held officer status in the United States Navy from 1942 to 1946 and was awarded the Certificate of Merit. I did not know former Senator Negus; he left the Senate shortly before I arrived. On behalf of the Government I extend to his widow and members of his family sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the expression of sympathy to the widow of Mr Sydney Negus and members of his family. Mr Negus had a relatively brief parliamentary career, serving only between 1971 and 1974, but it would be fair to say that many people would regard him as having made a quite notable contribution to politics and government in Australia. Whilst many may disagree with his view that all death duties should be abolished, he prosecuted that aim to very good effect. In the 1971 election he won a seat in the Senate that otherwise would have been won by my Party. I was a very close friend of the man who, as a result of that campaign, never entered the Senate. Mr Negus's campaign was very quickly rewarded, with governments, both State and Federal, moving in the ensuing years to remove death duties. It has to be said that that included governments which seemed to have a philosophic attachment to death duties but which found both the wave of public opinion and the fact that it was very difficult to have death duties in one State but not in another impossible to withstand.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Negus had a very distinctive contribution to make to the Australian political scene. He serves as a reminder that the major political parties which generally form governments in this country cannot take the electorate for granted. I think many Australian electors would regard his contribution as one that was significantly greater than that of many of us in this place. I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate in expressing sympathy to his widow and family and in recalling his brief but rather notable career in this place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The members of the National Party of Australia in the Senate also wish to be associated with this motion of condolence moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). I suppose Mr Negus was one of those rare people who came in here on a single issue. It was an issue that was very dear to the heart of the then Country Party of Australia, now the National Party. As Senator Chaney has said, it does us well to take notice of the fact that, although we belong to major political parties, quite often the people out there have minds of their own. When somebody such as former Senator Negus is able to focus the attention of those minds the major parties also should pay attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Former Senator Negus came into the Senate at the same time as a number of us-Senator Sir John Carrick, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and I are some of the survivors of that period-and he lasted as a senator for only a three-year period. As has been pointed out by other speakers, he came here with a commitment to abolish estate and death duties, and he played a significant part in achieving that objective. In common with only a few members of this Parliament, he also served during World War II as an officer in the United States Navy. Although I did not share his blanket opposition to death duties, as chairman of a committee that was appointed by the Whitlam Government, I came to appreciate the commitment Senator Negus had to the abolition of death and estate duties. I readily agree that he was instrumental in alerting public opinion to some of the anomalous aspects of the Federal legislation dealing with those issues. As chairman of the committee I came to appreciate the sincerity of Senator Negus and his capacity, almost singlehandedly, to impact public opinion on that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: It is significant that from time to time people in Western Australia have been able to elect Independent senators who have had a strongly held view and who have found their place subsequently in the Australian Senate. Whilst, as I say, I did not agree with Senator Negus's absolute position, he nevertheless played a very significant part in the preparation of the committee's report insofar as he was able to draw attention to the fact that the very wealthy people in this country were able to avoid their responsibilities by availing themselves of legal and accountancy principles in respect of estate and death duties. It was ordinary people, caught up in the inflationary spiral in the 1950s and 1960s, who were being caught by the legislation. If it was a redistributive process, it was not realising its objectives because the very wealthy people were able to contrive to arrange their financial affairs in such a way as to avoid their responsibilities. So Senator Negus will go down in history as a person with a singleminded approach who was able to realise an objective, which is something rarely done by members of parliament. To that extent the people who have profited by the abolition of Federal death duties owe Senator Negus a great deal.

Senator Negus had many other interests, of course. He had a view about road safety which he often expressed in this place and he made some thoughtful and novel contributions. For example, he pointed out here the need for road safety signs to use imperial and metric measurements during the changeover period. We all recall the petitions that were presented about the change to a metric system. He suggested a system of graded driving licences under which drivers would have to pass more rigorous tests before being permitted to drive at high speeds-a very interesting idea. He was an early advocate of the wearing of crash helmets by all motor cycle riders and passengers. So Senator Negus was a man who, in the brief period in which he was a member of the Senate, was able to make a number of significant impacts upon legislation and public opinion. To that extent we mourn his passing. He was one of a band of men who are fast disappearing from the Parliament insofar as he served actively during World War II. On behalf of myself and members of the Government I extend our regret at the passing of Senator Negus and offer condolences to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of my colleagues I would like to associate the Australian Democrats with the condolence motion that has been moved by Senator Button. Like many other senators in this place today, I did not know Senator Negus, but one must admire any individual whose commitment to an issue or to a variety of issues was such that he campaigned strongly and publicly enough to secure for himself a seat in the Federal Parliament in order to pursue his goals and, in particular, his aim to abolish death duties in what is, I suppose, the most public forum, if not necessarily always the most effective forum, for change in this country. Most honourable senators would agree that it is a shame that more people do not have such a strong commitment to an ideal that they pursue it with the enthusiasm Senator Negus did. The country, I believe, would certainly be the better for it. Too little of his brand of common sense and concern for, perhaps, ordinary issues that affect ordinary Australians is expressed in this place or in many other parliaments in this country. The Australian Democrats extend their sympathy to Senator Negus's widow.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR ARTHUR GEORGE POYSER

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 5 August 1986, of former Senator Arthur George Poyser.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 5 August 1986, of Arthur George Poyser, Senator for the State of Victoria from 1966 to 1975, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and the members of his family in their bereavement.

George Poyser was born in Ballarat in 1915. In later life he was Secretary of the Geelong Trades Hall Council from 1955 to 1961, Assistant Secretary of the Victorian Branch of the Australian Labor Party from 1961 to 1967 and a member of the Miscellaneous Workers Union. He was chosen by the Parliament of Victoria to represent that State in the Senate under section 15 of the Constitution on 26 October 1966 and was subsequently re-elected to the Senate in 1967 and 1974. He lost his seat in the December 1975 elections.

During George Poyser's nine years as a senator, he served on a number of parliamentary committees, including the Senate Standing Orders Committee, the Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Primary and Secondary Industry and Trade, the Senate Select Committee on the Metric System of Weights and Measures and the Joint Committee on Public Works. He was Deputy Government Whip from December 1972 to April 1974 and became Government Whip in July 1974. I first took my seat in the Senate in August 1974, when George Poyser was new in his job as Government Whip. I recall my meeting with him in that capacity as being very embarrassing and difficult because I had it fixed in my head that the Senate resumed after dinner at 8.15, when in fact it resumed at 8 o'clock. On my fifth night here, I think, I missed three divisions between 8 p.m. and 8.15 p.m. George Poyser on that occasion reminded me of the most severe schoolmaster I had ever had. I remember asking Senator Wheeldon what he thought I ought to do. He said: `You only have one course and that is to resign'. On that occasion I had been here for only five days and I felt mine was going to be a very short career.

George Poyser was Whip from 1974 until 1975 and was also Temporary Chairman of Committees in that period. During the War he served with the 2/5 Australian Infantry Battalion in the Middle East from 1940 until 1941. George Poyser was a man who worked for better conditions for the less privileged in our society. He was a very active and compassionate community worker in his own city of Geelong. Even in here his maiden speech was devoted to the problems which migrants to Australia were experiencing at the time he was elected. He was also a loyal and tireless worker for the Australian Labor Party and gave valued service to the labour movement in various ways. I might also add-it is not a virtue which is usually reported-that George Poyser was a very keen and skilled fisherman. Fishing is a pastime and activity which connotes a reflective capacity, a very endearing quality in a person. He certainly had those. George Poyser was a respected member of the Senate and on behalf of the Government I extend to his widow, Dorothy, and to his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). On behalf of the Opposition I extend our sympathy to the widow and family of Senator Poyser. He was one of the many Australian Labor Party politicians who came from the trade union movement. He was a man who gave the impression that he had started not so much as a trade union official but indeed as a worker in the industries with which he was concerned. He remained deeply concerned about the individual situation and the conditions of the people he represented. In that sense I think he was a totally genuine representative of the Labor movement. He was certainly a person who had my personal respect.

SPEECH.PARA: I got to know him very well because I became Opposition Whip while he was Government Whip. Senator Button need not think that he delivered lectures only to members of the then Government; he was quite capable of delivering rather stern lectures to the then Opposition Whip-that was me-and anyone else who happened to be passing. I found him a very con- genial Whip to work opposite. Indeed he had some of Senator Georges's qualities in that he was able to separate his political views from the administration and operation of the Senate, which is essential if the Senate is to be a workable place. I express my personal appreciation for the way the late George Poyser worked with me when we were Whips and I include the very difficult and stressful period in late 1975 when political passions ran very high in Canberra. I still found George a person with whom I could work in a sensible way.

I join the Leader of the Government in the Senate in having some satisfaction in George Poyser's very cheerful retirement years. He visited Canberra occasionally. It was always very good to see him and he was always very enthusiastic about his post-parliamentary life. He certainly talked of his fishing and I must say that I thought he seemed a man who had life by the throat. I believe it would be a matter of pleasure to all honourable senators that George Poyser enjoyed so much his post-parliamentary years. On behalf of the Opposition I again express sympathy to his family and our very great regret at his death.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The members of the National Party of Australia we also wish to be associated with this motion of condolence moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and supported by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney. Former Senator Poyser was one of a very select band of people who have become known as Whips in this establishment. I think I am correct in saying that Senator Georges succeeded him after 1975. One of the stories I heard when I first became a senator was that one of the reasons Senator Georges was so successful was that he was so delinquent when Senator Poyser was the Whip and he learned the hard way how Whips operate. Nonetheless, as has been indicated by the two previous speakers, Senator Poyser served not only his country but also his own political party and the trade union movement quite well in this chamber. We wish to be associated with the motion of condolence and express our sympathy to his widow and family.

—On behalf of my Australian Democrat colleagues I too indicate our support for the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, on the death of Senator George Poyser and extend our sympathy to his widow and family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my remarks on this occasion of a condolence motion for George Poyser.
