Like the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, I was one of a fairly large group who arrived in this place in 1974 when George Poyser became the Government Whip. The first official occasion when I had dealings with George was when he announced to me that I was to second the Address-in-Reply. As I had not only not been to Canberra before but also had not been to Parliament House and did not know whom the Address-in-Reply was to, or anything else, I suggested that that was not a very good idea. George suggested to me that if I chose to turn down that opportunity I might not get another opportunity in this place. I then quickly learned what Senator Button and Senator Chaney have referred to: George Poyser was a very colourful and very lively character in this place who lived life to the full and who took his job very seriously-as I think do most people who have come from extremely poor backgrounds as he did, who have worked hard, who have come up through the trade union movement and who have worked hard in political life and community life to achieve a position in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: George often spoke-it was mentioned at his funeral-about his childhood when his family had to move from house to house largely because they could not afford to pay the rent. Life was a continual struggle then. He often talked in a rather cheerful way about his Army career when he went to war. He was wounded in one of the first battles that the Australian forces took part in and, as he said, he was back in Australia before anyone else knew we were at war.

George was a cheerful, sometimes scathing Whip in this place; he was a very efficient Whip. He approached life in a serious way but in a way which we all appreciated meant that he saw the brighter side of things. He also approached death in a way that I think many of us could emulate. For a long time he knew he was dying and he took his farewell of his various friends, those who could get to him and those who could phone him. He made certain arrangements for his own funeral and those of us who went found it to be what most of us would like funerals to be-a farewell to a beloved colleague, a farewell which was attended by many people. Arrangements had been made by him to ensure that, as he put it in a message that he gave our former colleague Cyril Primmer to read at the funeral, we recognised that it was an occasion of grief and sorrow but not an occasion of imagined terrors or unachievable expectations. We said farewell to George. Cyril Primmer made a very fine speech of farewell and then we sat and contemplated the great honour we had had of knowing such a person. Would that all our funerals could be such occasions.

To his wife, Dorothy, who looked after him throughout their married life but in particular in his final months, to his children, who had so much respect for him as a father and as a community member, and to all his friends in Geelong, I also send my condolences and express my sorrow. We will miss George visiting here, as Senator Chaney said, telling us about his fishing exploits and about how much he had enjoyed life out of this place. I suppose he is the best example that it is possible to leave this place, have a decent and happy life and retain respect for one's colleagues. I think we will remember George. His wife Dorothy need have no regrets that he was anything other than highly respected in this place and in the community at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with the motion of condolence in respect of our late comrade George Poyser, who spent most of his lifetime in activities associated with the causes designed to improve the living standards and lifestyles of ordinary people. For 12 years he was a full time official in both the industrial and party political movements before he was selected to fill a casual vacancy. He was subsequently elected to the Senate following his appointment to fill that casual vacancy in 1966. He was a unique man in that he held very firm views. He called a spade a spade. Nevertheless, he was able to show that he could live with other points of view.

SPEECH.PARA: George was able to gain the support of his Party to become the Deputy Government Whip for a period and subsequently Government Whip when we were re-elected to government in 1974. I think he may have set something of a record for a senator because two days after taking his seat he had to stand for re-election. Of course, in a later period he displayed an extraordinary selflessness in volunteering to be dropped from the number one position on the Victorian ALP Senate ticket to the number four position, in order to help the preselection processes of the Party. That decision, which indicates the sort of man that George Poyser was, could have cost him two years in the Parliament but for the infamous events of 1975 which led to a double dissolution. In that gesture, of course, he brought about the election of my colleague the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button.

Looking back at his parliamentary contribution, the number of issues with which he was associated must be recognised. Some of his views have become conventional wisdom or have gained broad community support. I refer, for example, to his opposition to the war in Vietnam and the draft which was introduced as a means of prosecuting that war. Indeed, he took part in a courageous act of civil disobedience, for which he risked prosecution under the Crimes Act, when he joined four other members of parliament-Dr Cairns, Dr Cass, Senator Hendrickson and David Bornstein from the Victorian Legislative Assembly-in signing a public statement urging resistance to the National Service Act.

He was an early opponent of the indiscriminate slaughter of kangaroos. He had a concern for human beings and animals. He drew attention early to the racist aspect of our immigration policy prior to 1972, when assisted passages to our country were granted only to persons of European descent. He strongly criticised sporting contacts with the apartheid regime in South Africa, when prevailing views were quite different and not as mature as they are today. He had a strong commitment to social welfare. In particular, he was concerned about maladministration in nursing homes, migrant hostels and psychiatric hospitals at a time when abuses were widespread. He played a significant part in alerting the Senate to those deficiencies.

He drew attention to the absurd Senate voting system which was in force until recently, in which failure to number all squares-this will be recalled by honourable senators-rendered a vote invalid. He played a part in bringing about the ultimate change to that system which I think was a very significant factor in avoiding the amount of informal voting that took place under the old, complicated system. He had a strong commitment to consumer affairs and consumer protection, in particular from disreputable finance and insurance companies. In a lighter vein, I recall when he, along with a couple of others, advocated a more flexible dress code for members of parliament. He and two other members wore shorts and long socks during a Senate sitting in 1974. He freely admitted that he was not the most elegant person to take part in that experiment, but he did bring about a more flexible position as a result of that incident.

I will remember him with a great deal of affection for the sorts of causes that he stood for. I will remember him for the fact that he was one of a declining band of veterans in this place. Both former senators who are the subject of condolence motions today were members of that band. I have heard that Senator Kilgariff is to retire. I think Senator Sir John Carrick will also retire. I do not want to comment other than to say that I have heard that he might retire. I will be retiring from the Senate in 1988. That means, of course, that very few persons will be left in this place who served during World War II.

I extend my deepest sympathy to Dorothy and to George's family. I have heard not only from Senator Grimes but also from former Senator Justin O'Byrne-who visited him only a few days before his passing-that he knew of his imminent death and that he had very courageously organised for the event that took place a few days later. Some of our former colleagues who knew of George's very serious illness were able to visit him and report to us on the way in which George dealt with all issues. He was extraordinarily devoted to the parliamentary processes and to the causes which he held dear. I join the other members of the Senate in the generous remarks that have been expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay my respects to George Poyser and support the motion of condolence moved by the Government and supported by the Opposition. I was elected in 1974. I have found it entertaining to hear some of the stories about George from those days. He certainly had a fairly robust style in his role as Government Whip. I support the words of Senator Grimes that he was an efficient Whip. I particularly remember him in regard to the historic joint sitting of the Parliament. He was the Government Whip in the Senate at the time and had a lot to do with the organisation of the joint sitting. I got a guernsey to speak during the joint sitting. I remember that George Poyser was most courteous, considerate and efficient in the organisation of that joint sitting. I remember at one time he interjected while I was speaking. I did not then know which State he came from. I accused him of coming from one of the smaller States, so he could not possibly understand what I was talking about, as I came from Queensland. I corrected that later. We became friends after that and I enjoyed his company and that of his wife for many years. After he left the Parliament, whenever he came to Canberra he would call in to see me. I have enjoyed many of the stories that honourable senators have mentioned this afternoon. I extend my sympathy to Mrs Poyser-that is what I always called her-and George's family and wish them all the happiness that I know George would want them to have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues in expressing deep regret at the passing of former Senator George Poyser. I was one of many senators who were elected in 1974. I refer to Senator Peter Baume, Senator Fred Chaney, Senator John Button and Senator Don Grimes. I refer also to Jean Melzer from Victoria, Kathy Martin and Glen Sheil from Queensland and Gordon McIntosh and Peter Walsh, along with myself, from Western Australia. Most of them have moved to bigger and better things. I am still a humble back bencher, as I told George a few months ago. He said that I was in the best place and that Ministers, those people holding high office in this place, were restricted by their position.

SPEECH.PARA: The first impression I had of George Poyser has already been mentioned by Senator Button. It was not my intention to mention him by name, as he is still here. The incident concerned some legislation that the Government was extremely anxious to enact dealing with industrial relations. As honourable senators will know, at that time the numbers in the chamber were even and the Government therefore had to rely on every honourable senator being present. I understand that Senator Button went for rather a lengthy meal at the Lobby restaurant and therefore was not available when the Opposition called a division immediately after the suspension of the sitting for dinner. I was not aware that Senator Button thought that the dinner break continued until 8.15 p.m., but that is his story and I shall let him stick to it. I left the chamber following George Poyser, the Whip, just as John Button came through the glass doors outside the chamber. I had occasion to recall this when I visited George earlier this year. I thought that I was in a shearing shed or down on the wharves when I heard the language coming from George in ordering John Button into his office to explain why he was late.

George Poyser was once, prior to our coming here, Temporary Chairman of Committees. When I was elected to that position he rang to congratulate me. He said that I was not to follow an example he had set. He had been listening for a considerable time during a debate to a member of the Country Party waxing eloquent and had become a little annoyed. He came out with a most unsuitable expletive from the chair, to the shock and horror of the then Clerk of the Senate and honourable senators present. George later told me that he saw the then President, Sir Magnus Cormack, who refused to accept his resignation as Temporary Chairman of Committees because he valued his work. I think that we all valued George's work, both when he was a back bencher and later when he left parliament and we were merely friends. George was a marvellous friend to me when he was a senator and more particularly when he left. I stayed with him and Dorothy on a couple of occasions. He took us down to St Leonards, where he had a house to which he planned to retire but which eventually he had to give up. I have listened to most of his fishing tales, and was often tempted to buy him those teatowels with the fishing stories on them because George could tell as good a fishing story as anyone else.

Honourable senators will remember what happened after the 1974 election and at the time the Whitlam Government was removed from office in 1975. There were three quick elections. Because of my position on the ticket, I had three elections in 2 1/2 years. I mentioned that to George, and he informed me that he had had three elections in 13 months. He was appointed to the Senate in November. The term of the person whom he replaced did not expire for 12 months but to be returned to the Senate George was still required under the laws governing elections to stand for election at the time of the House of Representatives election. Twelve months later, a Senate election came up. George's three elections in 13 months greatly surpassed the mere three in 2 1/2 years of which I could boast.

A few months ago George rang me at Parliament House to tell me that he had terminal cancer. He had already discussed it with his family and had decided that he would not go to hospital for treatment. He had come across an organisation in Geelong, a hospice organisation, which called into the homes of people with cancer. He said that he was relying on the organisation's representatives to carry out certain activities, which they did. They called on George about 9 o'clock on the night before he died and again, I understand, at about 3 o'clock in the morning. Some of the members of the organisation attended his funeral.

George had a marvellous relationship with his family-not only his immediate family, but also his son-in-law and daughters-in-law. His grandchildren, particularly, thought of him as a friend. A person can be paid no greater compliment than to be recognised as a friend, particularly by relatives. Dorothy is a great friend of mine. George was a great man who will be remembered as a great man and as a great representative of the Victorian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my words of sympathy to those that have already been well expressed. In a variety of ways George Poyser, perhaps more than many other honourable senators, had considerable influence on me. George, by his guidance, made me more effective in my first two or three years as a senator than I could otherwise have been. George had problems with me, which already have been related to the Senate. For some reason he called me the bedouin-someone usually hidden, to be found when needed and always elusive. I remember missing a connection overseas-we were short of numbers in the Senate, as has already been said-but the next aeroplane leaving the place where I was stranded was not due for three days. I was not prepared to ring George directly. I rang a friend who hesitated somewhat and then passed on the message that I would not be in the chamber when I was supposed to be. John Button suffered because of his brief fall from grace, so one can imagine how I suffered when I was missing from this Parliament for three days.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall George's great amusement when he discovered that I was to follow him as Whip. He could not believe it. He was astonished and it took him some time to become used to the fact that the person whom he considered to be the most delinquent-a term already used-was appointed to follow him. There is no doubt that his example was one that I followed. He was a good instructor on how this place should be organised. He ran it very firmly. I discovered why at times he was so irascible-the job was difficult. He did the job extremely well, as his opponents have already said.

George was a man of preciseness and personal discipline, which he imposed fairly on others, and a man with immense loyalty to his party and to the people whom he represented. He was immensely loyal to his family. His courage in facing up to death is an example that few of us will be able to follow. I express my sympathy to his wife, Dorothy, and to his family. I am certain that they are proud of George Poyser, proud of every moment he lived, and proud of the example he showed in his last moments.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I invite honour- able senators to stand as a mark of respect, I would like to place on record my appreciation of the parliamentary services and personal friendship to me of the late George Poyser. I think I can fairly say that the day Senator Poyser walked into this Parliament to fill a casual vacancy was also the day on which the Parliament was being dissolved. He had not been allotted a room and he asked me where he could use a phone to ring his wife. I took him down to my room so that he could ring his wife and, as a result of that, we became very close personal friends. Indeed, in a period in 1973 when I was hospitalised, it was George and his wife, Dorothy, who invited my wife and me to go with them to their holiday home at St Leonards.

INTERJECT.PARA: As has been said, he was the Government Whip in the period 1974 to 1975, at a time when I was Manager of Government Business in the Senate. In those critical days in October and November 1975 when the Government was fighting for its existence, I remember that every evening there was a discussion in my ministerial room between Senator Poyser and myself on the one hand and Senator Withers, the then Leader of the Opposition, on the other. Bearing in mind what has been said here earlier about language, I have often thought that if only one had a tape recording of the things that were said in that room in those days a transcript of it would make tremendous political reading and I am also sure the censor would have some concerns about it.

George Poyser and former Senator Cyril Primmer were close friends, and I can remember sitting here evening after evening listening to them tell tale after tale about the old timers of the Labor movement in Victoria, the early days of Warrnambool, and the days in Geelong. George Poyser was a great raconteur and a close, dependable and loyal friend, and my deepest sympathy and that of my wife Lorna go to his widow, Dorothy, and the members of her family in their sad bereavement. George was a great Australian. Having said that, I invite honourable senators to stand as a mark of respect to his memory.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As a mark of respect to the memory of the late Senator Poyser and the late Senator Negus, the sitting of the Senate is suspended until 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the following papers:

SPEECH.PARA: Budget Statements 1986-87
Estimates of Expenditure and Revenue of the Commonwealth Public Account 1986-87
Portfolio Program Estimates 1986-87
Payments to or for the States, the Northern Territory and Local Government Authorities 1986-87
Government Securities on Issue at 30 June 1986
Australia's Overseas Development Assistance Program 1986-87
National Income and Expenditure 1985-86
Income Tax Statistics
Particulars of Proposed Expenditure for the Service of the Year Ending on 30 June 1987
Particulars of Certain Proposed Expenditure in Respect of the Year Ending on 30 June 1987
Particulars of Proposed Expenditure in Respect of the Year Ending on 30 June 1987 in relation to the Parliamentary Departments.
I seek leave to incorporate a statement outlining the Government's budgetary proposals for the financial year 1986-87.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite are all masochists. I cannot understand them. Perhaps they are sadists, not masochists.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight the Treasurer is delivering in another place his Budget Speech for 1986-87.
It is my privilege to outline to the Senate the Budget proposals of the Government.
Over the past year the factors which determine Australia's national prosperity have changed dramatically.
The strong economic growth and the huge employment growth of the last three years have now been slowed due to the sudden collapse of our export earnings.
The prospects for our future growth, built on the expectation that we could readily sell our traditional products, have been substantially diminished.
Many Australians have wondered why the economy was doing so well in 1985 and yet, apparently, doing so poorly in 1986.
The answer lies in the dramatic collapse in world commodity prices since late last year.
We have been placed in a position where we are failing to cover the cost of our imports to the tune of more than a billion dollars a month-and inevitably our growth had to slow.
With the world having slashed our national income by over $6 billion we could not continue on as though nothing had happened.
To try would see the world force destructive adjustment on Australia making it hostage to the international financial community.
And that is not a position acceptable to this Government.
We believe that Australia must maintain control over its own destiny and this can only be done by facing the problem squarely and making the remedial changes quickly and decisively.
This the Government will do through this Budget and other policy changes.
It is imperative that our domestic economy and our standard of living adjust to our changed trading circumstances so that we can make an early return to higher growth and stronger employment.
What precisely are the adjustments required?
As a nation, if we are to become more independent and self-sufficient, we need to invest more and consume less.
In other words, we must save for the future rather than spend for the present.
The Government can help this process directly by spending less and borrowing less, thereby improving the climate for lower interest rates and for private sector investment.
The savings and tax decisions in this Budget are also designed to restrain the growth of private consumption.
But the Budget alone cannot achieve all of the changes Australia requires.
It is also essential that Australians exercise restraint over wages and prices.
We simply cannot allow the inevitable inflationary effects of the dollar's fall to feed into our cost structure.
Contrary to the beliefs of some, Australia is well equipped to make the adjustments to rectify its problems.
We have made enormous progress in the past 3 years in modernising and freeing up the economy.
We have a much lower wage cost structure, a vibrant financial sector, and vastly more competitive industries than a few years ago.
While we have now encountered serious difficulties in our primary export markets, through our combined efforts and continued restraint we can turn those efforts towards new opportunities.
For these reasons, the Budget incorporates a very large cut in spending and a very large cut in Government borrowing.
In making these vital decisions we have sought to ensure that the burden of change is spread as fairly as possible across the community.
Even in difficulty, however, we have maintained the Labor Party's traditional commitment to the most needy.
But we have not shirked our responsibility to take hard decisions where these have been required.
Reflecting this, the Government has been able to bring the deficit down from $5,726 million last year to $3,503 million this year.
I repeat, this Budget cuts the deficit by $2,223 million to $3,503 million.

It is also important to understand that while in total the Commonwealth has budgeted for a deficit of $3.5 billion, much of this deficit arises from spending abroad on defence equipment and other items.
Allowing for these overseas transactions there will be an estimated domestic budget surplus of $805 million.
Combined with reductions in State borrowings, the large cut in the Budget deficit will dramatically lower government demand for borrowed funds.
In fact, total public sector borrowings will be cut by more than $2 1/2 billion in 1986-87.
The Government's bond selling program has been cut from $5.7 billion last year to around $3 billion this year.
As a result, the net bond selling task will be zero.
I would point out that the large reduction in the deficit this year has been made notwithstanding economic developments tending to increase it.
Wage restraint tends to lower taxes more than outlays in the short term.
As I shall discuss later, the Budget figuring incorporates a 2 per cent discount to wages in the next National Wage Case.
Without that assumption, the deficit would have been some $400 million less.
The Government's resolve and achievement in this Budget is well reflected in the fact that if we had taken no action on outlays or receipts the deficit would have been $7.5 billion.
We have brought it down by $4 billion, or more than half.
THE BUDGET MEASURES
Mr President, the deficit reduction in this Budget has been accomplished by an examination of outlays of unprecedented rigour.
If we had done no more than provide for ongoing programs, outlays would have increased by 2.7 per cent in real terms.
We have cut this back to zero real growth.
To achieve this result, nearly $3 billion has been cut from existing programs.
Cut backs have been made in most areas, with major reductions falling on social security, health, education, defence and overseas aid.
In social security, the Government has decided on cutbacks of over $500 million.
Included in those decisions, future six monthly indexation increases to beneficiaries will continue to be paid in full but will be deferred for six weeks.
This means that the 4 per cent increase due in early November will now be paid in mid-December.
In addition, the measures announced last year to relax income testing arrangements for pensions and benefits will be delayed 8 months until July 1987.
These are the only changes to the general pension and benefits area.

While seeking a contribution from this part of the Budget towards the resolution of our national problems, the Government has ensured that there will be no reductions in any existing pension or benefit payments.
What is being required is a minimal sacrifice when compared with that being asked of wage and salary earners.
There will be a crackdown on cheating and fraud in the social security system.
We will not compromise our deep commitment to assist the genuinely needy.
But abuse of the system will not be tolerated.
Special reviews will be conducted by teams of officers to identify and disqualify those wrongfully receiving unemployment benefits.

Additionally, reporting requirements for all unemployment beneficiaries will be tightened and it will be much harder for New Zealand citizens who are visiting Australia to qualify for unemployment and other benefits.
There will also be reviews of sole parent beneficiaries to verify continuing eligibility.
The Government is committed to implementing the Australia Card with a photograph, which will also assist in combatting social security fraud.
Child maintenance arrangements are being reformed so that non-custodial parents will shoulder more financial responsibility for their children, rather than throwing the burden onto the taxpayer.

In line with the Government's aim to target welfare assistance to the most needy, the family allowance for student children aged 16 and 17 will be income tested so that families with household income exceeding $39,000 will no longer receive it.
In the same vein, the Government will in this Budget provide further assistance to the most needy, low income families with children and to the handicapped.
These discretionary adjustments are detailed in the Budget Papers.
The Government has taken a range of measures to help contain the growing cost of Australia's health system.
Spending in this area will be cut by $300 million.
First, strict measures have been adopted to reduce what were clearly excessive pathology charges by some medical practitioners.
Second, the wage restraint asked of the workforce at large has been extended to medical practitioners by deferring increases in schedule fees until 1 November 1986.
Third, the maximum patient contribution for medical services-I stress the maximum, not the typical-is to be raised from $10 to $20 from 1 November.
Fourth, the bed day subsidy to private hospitals will cease from 1 October 1986, but some charitable hospitals will continue to receive assistance.
But even with these savings, and particularly with the recent increases in salaries for nurses, the cost of the health system is continuing to rise.
The Government therefore believes that the Medicare levy should be increased so that it makes a greater contribution to health costs and so that Medicare is self-financing.
Accordingly, the Medicare levy will rise by a quarter of a per cent to 1.25 per cent from 1 December.
Increasing the levy is a more equitable means of responding to unavoidable increases in health costs than the alternative of severely curtailing Medicare benefits.
Pharmaceutical benefits have been another area of burgeoning costs in the health system.
This has been a concern to both the Government and the very sick.
New arrangements will reduce costs to the health system and provide relief to those most in need.
From 1 November prescription drug users now paying a $5 contribution will pay up to a $10 maximum.
New safety net arrangements mean individuals and families requiring more than 25 prescriptions a year will receive prescriptions beyond that number free of charge.
Pensioners will continue to receive items on the Pharmaceutical Benefits list free of any charge.
The Government believes it is only fair that participants in the higher education system share some part of its costs.
Consequently a charge of $250 per year for all higher education students will be introduced in 1987 to offset-or, more accurately, partially offset- administration costs.
This charge represents only a small part of the cost of providing higher education, and will contribute towards an additional student intake of 3000 in 1987.
Lower income families will be protected; holders of tertiary allowances and post-graduate awards and overseas students paying the overseas student charge will not be affected.
Spending on defence is to be held at 1 per cent real growth, saving $190 million, and overseas aid will be cut by $140 million.
Expenditure on the new Parliament House is to be reduced by $30 million, sports facilities by $8 million and the Bicentennial Program by $25 million.
The number of Commonwealth public servants will be reduced by 2000 over the year to June 1987, that is, June 1987 on June 1986.
The Government has made numerous other expenditure cuts in reaching its $3 billion expenditure savings; details are set out in the Budget Papers.
The overwhelming concern of the Government in bringing down this Budget has been to achieve an outcome appropriate for a nation with a trading problem of the magnitude now facing Australia.
That is why spending has been held to zero real increase.
That is why we have sought to produce the lowest practicable budget deficit.
The Government has held outlays and the deficit well below the trilogy requirements.
Outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product have been reduced to 29.4 per cent, compared with 30.1 per cent last year and 30.4 per cent the year before.
The deficit has been reduced to only 1.4 per cent of gross domestic product, back to the average prevailing during the late 1950s and the 1960s.
It is the fourth consecutive fall from the 5 per cent in prospect that we inherited from the Coalition Government in 1983.
In pursuit of this objective and given the urgency of our predicament the Government has decided to lift the tax ratio about half a per cent above the 1984-85 outcome level.
This decision has been taken to achieve an even larger reduction in the deficit, and to do so in an equitable way.
Our trilogy of fiscal commitments was directed at restraining the size of Government over the medium-term and we reaffirm that fundamental objective.
The Government has been spectacularly successful in lowering expenditure growth and the deficit.
Moreover, it is our objective to bring the tax ratio back to 25 per cent of gross domestic product next year.
This year, however, the first stage of the very substantial cuts in personal income tax provided by the tax reform program will be delayed three months.
These cuts-at the previously announced rates-will now apply from 1 December this year.
The second and final stage-reducing the top marginal tax rates to 49 cents and 40 cents-will apply from 1 July 1987 as scheduled.
Legislation implementing both stages is being introduced in the House of Representatives tonight.
These cuts-as well as improving incentive-will return to taxpayers about three times the revenue raised by the tax reform package.
The Government has adopted a number of other revenue measures.
In the main, the measures will restrain real household disposable incomes and consumption, consistent with the need for our living standards to be trimmed for a time.
Wholesale sales tax will be increased on a range of consumer products including luxury motor vehicles, wine, certain non-alcoholic beverages and swimming pools.
The sales tax law is also to be amended with effect from midnight tonight to curtail avoidance of taxes on computer software.
The excise on petrol and diesel fuel will increase by 3 cents per litre from tonight.
Because of the existing diesel rebate arrangements, this additional excise will not fall upon farmers and miners.
The rates of the Bank Account Debits Tax will be increased by up to a half from 1 December 1986.
The tax deferral advantages enjoyed by some companies with substituted accounting periods will be phased out over three years.
PRICES AND INCOMES POLICY
Mr President, the Budget I have outlined tonight will greatly assist Australia to adapt to the new international trading circumstances we face.
However, budget policy must be supported by continued price and wage moderation.
The restructuring of Australian industry facilitated by the depreciation of the dollar will accelerate provided we stay competitive with the rest of the world.
Staying competitive means having a greater ability to supply our own market with Australian-made goods and to win a larger share of world markets.
Over the past 3 years Australia's working men and women have shown commendable income restraint.
More than any other single factor, their co-operation and good sense has been responsible for the creation of 630,000 jobs since April 1983.

Over this period real labour costs have fallen by more than 7 per cent. Incidentally, over the same period in the United Kingdom, under a system which members of the Opposition would like to reproduce in Australia, real wages have increased by 11 1/2 per cent.
It is not the fault of wage and salary earners that export prices have fallen.
Just as it is not their fault that the dollar has fallen, pushing up import prices.
But we cannot afford to let wages grow automatically in line with this price surge.

If adverse trading conditions and a depreciating Australian dollar are the cause of the Consumer Price Index rising, it follows that to allow those increases to flow through automatically into wages would compound our problems.
We would be adjusting our wages upwards not to compensate for the problem but to build the problem in.
This would only lead Australia into a price and wage spiral.
I am certain that all Australians will understand and accept that we cannot have our national income slashed by over $6 billion and at the same time seek to fully maintain our wages in real terms.

Accordingly, at the next National Wage Case when the combined 4 per cent movement in the March and June quarter Consumer Price Index will be considered, the Government will argue to the Arbitration Commission that the proposed increase in wages be cut by 2 per cent.
This means that wages will rise by 2 per cent less than the increase which would fully compensate for inflation.
There are good and clear reasons for this.
Last year award wages grew by 4 1/2 per cent.
With a 2 per cent discount, wages are expected to grow at about the same moderate rates as in 1985-86.
This means that over the course of the next year Australian wage increases will be broadly comparable with our major trading partners.
A 2 per cent discount would therefore maintain our competitiveness and preserve our ability to compete on favourable terms with the rest of the world.
The Government will also seek a further adjustment of the wage increase in the case commencing around April next year if economic conditions applying at the time warrant it.
In determining its attitude to that case, the Government's main focus will continue to be on Australia's ongoing competitive position and our terms of trade performance.
With its past record of success, the Government reaffirms its confidence in the Prices and Incomes Accord.
The Accord framework will continue to deliver more economically and industrially responsible outcomes than any other real world alternative.
The challenges now presented by severely depressed commodity prices demand a continuation of this approach.
ECONOMIC OUTLOOK
Mr President, it will take some time for the ground lost in our export markets to be recovered, and a stronger growth path to be resumed.
As a result, we expect growth in the non-farm economy to be around 2 1/2 per cent in 1986-87 compared with 4 per cent last financial year.
Most of that growth will stem from our improved international competitiveness; it will show up in the winning of new export markets and the replacement of imports with locally produced goods.
However, the lower growth rate means that fewer jobs will be created over the next year than in the last twelve months.
Employment growth is expected to slow to between 1 1/2 and 2 per cent, and as a consequence, unemployment could rise a little.

Just as it will take some time for the benefits of the depreciation of the dollar to flow through the economy, it will also take some time before the adverse price effects of the depreciation are behind us.
Consequently, reflecting the recent falls in the dollar, we expect the Consumer Price Index to increase by around 8 per cent on average in 1986-87.
However, the trend in the latter part of the year and beyond will be downward.
Mr President, the Budget I am presenting tonight responds decisively to the new international challenge facing Australia.
It constitutes one of the basic and fundamental responses required to permanently improve Australia's trading performance.
It makes the major shift down in Government spending and borrowing that will permit the new investment opportunities to be seized:
- real spending growth has been cut to zero;
- the deficit has been dramatically brought back to its late 1950s and 60s levels;
and
- Government calls on the nation's savings have been substantially alleviated.
This Budget provides Australia with the opportunity to surmount its economic problems and maintain control over its economic destiny.
It demonstrates the Government's absolute determination to do what has to be done to safeguard Australia's economic future.
It demonstrates once again that, by resolute action and by some sacrifice all round, there is no problem that we cannot face and defeat together.
OUTLAYS
Mr President, I now provide more details of the expenditure cuts that have been made.
Budget outlays in 1986-87 are estimated to total $74,764 million.
As I stated earlier, this represents zero growth in real terms.
In the previous thirty years lower real rates of growth have been achieved on only three occasions.
This outcome reflects the determined approach which the Government has adopted to expenditure control.
Details of individual decisions are contained in the Measures section of Statement No 3; additional information will be provided, as appropriate, by the relevant Ministers.
The Prime Minister will also be making a detailed statement on Public Service staffing matters in the next few weeks.
SOCIAL SECURITY AND WELFARE
I have already outlined our major initiatives in this area.
I stress once again: the Government has a commendable record of directing assistance to those in greatest need.
Over the term of the Hawke Government there have been significant increases in the real value of pensions and benefits, and large gains in assistance provided for children in low income families.
This Budget continues the Government's focus on improving benefits for those in need, on removing anomalies and attacking fraud.
In addition to the measures I have already announced, action is to be taken to prevent some people qualifying for dual benefits.

From 1 November 1986, where a newly eligible war or defence widow pensioner is also eligible for a social security pension, the maximum level of the social security pension will be frozen at $60.05 a week.
I mentioned earlier that some benefits to the most needy in the community were to be increased.

To assist pensioners and low income families with children, there will be a $1 a week increase in the additional pension and benefit per child and a $1 a week increase in the rate of the Family Income Supplement from November 1986.

In recognition of the difficulties and additional costs facing disabled people who undertake employment or vocational training, the mobility allowance will increase to $11 a week from November this year.
The handicapped child's allowance will increase by $7 per month to $92 per month from November 1986.
And also from November, the orphan's pension will increase by $4.30 to $60 per month.
A clear need has been established for the Government to provide additional income support for 16 and 17 year olds who are the victims of abuse within their own families or cannot live at home.
Consequently, a Young Homeless Allowance of $23.28 a week has been introduced to supplement the income these young people receive from education allowances or unemployment benefits.
Expenditure in 1986-87 for that purpose is estimated to be about $9 million.
HEALTH
When dealing earlier with the Government's major proposals in the health portfolio, I stressed that we were adamant that health funding must be kept within reasonable bounds.

Consequently, in addition to those other measures, we will investigate the payment of medical benefits which are growing at above average rates and review mechanisms for further restraining growth in health costs.
The Isolated Patient Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme will be transferred to the States.
Extra funding of $11 million this year and $22 million in a full year will be provided to the States and Territories to enable them to provide more effective arrangements.
Funding has been increased in a number of important areas in the health portfolio.
These include health promotion, public health, hepatitis B vaccinations, medical research, family planning and assistance to diabetics.
EDUCATION
I have already mentioned the Government's intention to impose an administration charge on higher education students.
In addition, the overseas student charge currently applicable to university and CAE students will be extended to secondary, TAFE and other previously exempt higher education students from overseas.
Together with increases in existing charges, this extension will yield $7.3 million, offsetting the costs of providing education to overseas students in Australia.
An anomaly exists in current arrangements whereby some social security beneficiaries can receive both student allowances and pensions or benefits.
This is to be removed for new entrants from the 1987 academic year, saving $4 million.
A special payment of $15 per week will instead be made to invalid and sole parent pensioners who are also students to encourage their education and later employment prospects.
LABOUR AND EMPLOYMENT
There has been a significant re-ordering of priorities within this function and, overall, a real cut in spending.

Flowing from last year's decision to implement the Priority One program, expenditure on job training programs will increase by $67 million, including an increased allocation of $33 million for the Australian Traineeship System.
This accords with the Government's intention that training and education opportunities available to our young people be significantly enhanced.
Increased emphasis on training is to be complemented by reduced emphasis on Government job creation schemes.
Consequently, outlays under the Community Employment Program will be reduced by $90 million to $200 million.
The 2 per cent wage discount recently applied to wages is to be extended to former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel receiving Government superannuation benefits.
ABORIGINALS

Assistance to Aboriginals will undergo a significant change in emphasis following the Government's endorsement of the general principles espoused in the Miller Report on Aboriginal Employment Training.
The emphasis of existing programs will be changed from short-term job creation and welfare measures towards policies to establish long-term employment opportunities.
Commonwealth expenditure directed towards Aboriginals will total $570 million in 1986-87.
DEFENCE
Real growth in defence spending has been cut to 1 per cent in 1986-87, a significant reduction on the 3.75 per cent allowed for in the Five Year Defence Program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you not honour your commitments of 3.75 per cent?

—I am interested in that interjection by Senator MacGibbon because the Fraser Government throughout its period in office was committed to 7 1/2 per cent real growth in defence expenditure but averaged 2.2 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, average real growth in defence spending under this Government remains greater than that under our predecessors.
Recently the Government has begun the most thorough and comprehensive review of this country's defence priorities since the Second World War.

In light of the Dibb Report and prevailing economic circumstances, the Government will now prepare a White Paper on Defence which will set down the development of Australia's defence capabilities well into the future.
This report will reflect the need to maintain planning at achievable financial outcomes.
Such a disciplined approach will ensure that essential changes can take place in equipment and force structure.
CULTURE AND RECREATION

The Special Broadcasting Service-an extravagance of the Fraser-Howard years-and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation are to be amalgamated, and their combined funding reduced by $16 million from last year's allocation.
The specialised charter of the SBS will be preserved under the amalgamation.
Gross savings from shared facilities, accommodation, equipment and administration in the amalgamated organisations should be about $2 million in 1986-87 and much greater in future years.
We are also reducing the cost of administrative assistance to the arts.
As a first step, the Australia Council's administrative expenses for 1986-87 are to be reduced by $1 million to allow increased support for the arts.
A wide-ranging review of the Commonwealth's funding of museums is to be undertaken.
The construction of the National Museum of Australia in Canberra will not proceed on the timetable previously conceived; its future will be considered following this review.
INDUSTRY ASSISTANCE
All production bounties other than those applying to fertilisers and shipbuilding are to be reduced by 20 per cent from tonight, saving $43 million.
There will be a phased reduction in the shipbuilding bounty rate from 25 per cent to 20 per cent.
The consumption subsidy for fertilisers will no longer apply to imported products and the savings will be reallocated to increase subsidy rates on locally manufactured phosphatic fertilisers.
The ban on uranium exports to France has failed to serve its original purpose and was in fact bestowing a benefit by allowing France to contract elsewhere for uranium at lower prices.
As the ban was exacting no penalty and the material is to be used solely for peaceful purposes, the Government has decided to resume uranium exports, saving the Budget $66 million.
TRANSPORT
Following the earlier announcement of a $50 million reduction in projected outlays under the Australian Land Transport Program, a further reduction of $24 million is to be made.
This means that total roads funding will be maintained at $1250 million, the same nominal level this year as last.
The Government announced in May that it intended to recoup $40 million in aviation expenditures by implementing a cost recovery plan.
These savings are now to be expanded to $49 million.
FREEDOM OF INFORMATION
The cost of fulfilling Freedom of Information requests is currently estimated at some $14 million a year, compared with offsetting revenue of $60,000.
While the Government remains firmly committed to the principles of Freedom of Information, it believes that a greater proportion of the costs should be borne by users of this service.
Charges will be increased but free access will be maintained for enquiries relating to personal income maintenance documents; but lazy politicians and journalists will have to pay.
NORTHERN TERRITORY ELECTRICITY COMMISSION

The Commonwealth remains committed to sharing the cost of constructing Darwin's new power station but has informed the NT Government that it will be halving, as of tonight, assistance with operating costs reflecting in the main the lower costs of its oil feedstock.
This will save $21 million this year.
CHARGE FOR LOAN GUARANTEES
Commonwealth business enterprises receive a significant interest rate benefit due to the fact that their borrowings are guaranteed by the Commonwealth Government.
From 1986-87 an annual charge will be applied to borrowings by the Commonwealth's business enterprises which are guaranteed by the Commonwealth.
This measure is expected to raise about $7 million in 1986-87.
RECEIPTS
Mr President, I have already indicated the major revenue measures in the Budget.
I shall now give further details.
The measures are more extensively described in Statement No 4 of Budget Paper No 1.
MARGINAL INCOME TAX RATE CUTS
Mr President, the fundamental cuts to marginal income tax rates that the Treasurer announced as the centrepiece of the Government's Tax Reform Package will proceed.
The 60 cent rate will be cut to 49 cents, the 48 cent and 46 cent rates to 40 cents and the other marginal tax rates to 29 and 24 cents.
These massive income tax cuts will produce a fairer and more efficient tax system, under which all Australian taxpayers will be better off.

However, as I indicated earlier, the serious international economic predicament which Australia faces has required the deferral of the first stage of these tax cuts until 1 December this year, reducing the cost to revenue in 1986-87 from $2085 million to $1435 million.
Legislation to give effect to the lower rates of tax, including those to apply from 1 July 1987, will be introduced by the Treasurer tonight.

These reductions are only possible because of the Government's moves to eliminate the inequities and abuses of our tax system which have persisted for so long and because of our demonstrated ability to restrain expenditures.
They are an integral part of our overall program to establish the foundations for Australia's future economic growth and prosperity.
SALES TAX

To reduce the heavy tax discrimination against beer and spirits drinkers in favour of wine, the rate of sales tax on alcoholic wine and cider is to be increased from 10 per cent to the standard sales tax rate of 20 per cent from tonight.
This is expected to increase revenue by $47 million in 1986-87.
At present carbonated soft drinks and mineral waters are subject to sales tax of 20 per cent while other non-alcoholic beverages are exempt.
In order to reduce this discrimination, sales tax at 10 per cent will apply from tonight to packaged flavoured milk, previously exempt fruit juice products and non-alcoholic wine and cider.
This measure will yield revenue of $60 million in 1986-87.
From tonight the rate of sales tax is to increase from 20 to 30 per cent on luxury cars and station wagons.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is a luxury car?
—The ones that you drive, I expect.

SPEECH.PARA: This will affect broadly those vehicles whose retail price exceeds the depreciation cost limit for income tax purposes-that is $29,646 in 1986-87.
The revenue yield in 1986-87 is $28 million.

Avoidance of sales tax occurs through the device of selling only the discs and tapes on which computer software is embodied and licensing the consumer to use the software itself; sales tax is then payable only on the value of the discs, which is a small fraction of the total price.
The sales tax law is to be amended, with effect from midnight tonight, to ensure that the taxable sale value of the computer discs or tapes encompasses the software on them.
The production of ``in-house'' software will not be affected by the change, nor will exports of software or business purchases of software which are exempted as an aid to manufacture.
Expected revenue raised from this measure is $80 million in 1986-87.

Finally in the sales tax area, the Government has decided to change, with effect from midnight tonight, the classification for sales tax purposes of a number of goods so as to reduce anomalies and inconsistencies.
The areas affected include swimming pools, hand tools, photographic developing and bathroom fittings.
Details are provided in Statement No 4.
BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX
The Bank Account Debits Tax rates will be increased from 1 December 1986.
The highest rate will increase from $1.50 to $2.00; other rates will increase by up to a half.
Revenue will increase by $45 million in 1986-87.
PETROLEUM PRODUCTS
I announced earlier that excise on petrol and diesel will increase 3 cents per litre with effect from tonight.
This will yield $625 million in 1986-87 and $715 million in a full year.
The decline in international oil prices and consequent reduction in import parity prices had substantially reduced Government revenue from the taxation of petroleum products.
Even with this measure, total Commonwealth revenue from the taxation of petroleum products will be little changed from 1985-86.
A.C.T. TAXES
The Commonwealth Grants Commission has found that the financial contribution from the Australian Capital Territory continues to be low relative to that in the States.
In those circumstances it is considered fair that revenue raised in the A.C.T. be increased.

The Minister for Territories and the Treasurer are releasing a separate statement detailing the measures to be taken, which include introduction of a land tax on business properties and increases in gambling taxes and stamp duties.
PROVISIONAL TAX

An anti-avoidance measure will be introduced to overcome arrangements whereby members of closely held partnerships or trusts have sought to avoid provisional tax by manipulating the distribution of income between partners or beneficiaries from one year to the next.
This will raise revenue by $50 million in 1986-87.
VALUATION OF NATURAL INCREASE IN LIVESTOCK
The Economic and Rural Policy Statement of 15 April 1986 announced changes to stock valuation arrangements for animal stud breeders generally.

As the tax deferral advantages associated with stock valuations are generally much greater for horse breeders, the Government has decided to restrict valuation changes to them, and then only in respect of service fees.
Other animal breeders, such as sheep and cattle breeders, will not now be affected.
A separate statement gives the details.
COMPANY ACCOUNTING PERIODS
A small number of companies receive substantial tax deferral benefits through adoption of an accounting year for tax purposes which finishes on a date earlier than 30 June.
Relative to other companies, such companies are able to defer payment of tax for up to six months.
To remove the tax deferral advantage, it is proposed to advance the due dates for payment of their quarterly instalments and assessments.
This change, which affects only the timing of tax payments and not the size of tax liabilities, will be phased in over the three years starting 1986-87.
Less than 5 per cent of all companies will be affected by the change, which is expected to yield about $220 million in 1986-87 and in each of the following two years.
PAY OF DEFENCE FORCE RESERVE
The Dibb Report on Australia's defence capability envisaged an enhanced role for the Defence Force Reserve.
The Government has decided to reinstate full taxation exemption of the pay of Defence Force Reservists from 1 January 1987.
At the same time the special reserve allowance will be discontinued as an offset.
MEDICARE LEVY
As I announced earlier, the Medicare levy will be increased from one per cent to 1 1/4 per cent, from 1 December 1986.
The estimated gain to revenue is $175 million in 1986-87.
Threshold levels are to be raised to ensure that low income earners continue not to pay the levy.
BENEFICIARY REBATES

The taxation rebates for people receiving unemployment, sickness or special benefits will be increased again this year to ensure that people wholly or mainly dependent on such benefits are not liable to tax.
INCOME AVERAGING FOR SPORTSPERSONS AND PERFORMING ARTISTS
From the 1986-87 income year, sportspersons and performing artists are to be eligible for income tax averaging provisions designed to smooth out tax liabilities on fluctuating incomes.
Anomalies in the existing authors and inventors scheme are to be removed.
PASSPORT FEES
The validity period of Australian passports will be extended from 5 to 10 years and the fee increased from $30 to $60.
MONETARY POLICY
It is the Government's intention to shift some of the present burden from monetary policy.
Lower interest rates would be compatible with stronger domestic economic activity and balance of payments adjustment provided other policies are taking more of the weight of that adjustment process.
That is one reason why it has been so important to achieve substantial cuts in the Budget deficit and the public sector borrowing requirement in 1986-87.
As I said earlier, total public sector gross borrowings are estimated to fall by over $2 1/2 billion this year.
As a ratio to GDP, the gross PSBR will fall to about 4.4 per cent, compared with 6.0 per cent in 1985-86 and a peak of 8.1 per cent in 1983-84.
Treasury Bond Tenders in 1986-87 are expected to total around $3 billion.
In net terms there will be no new bond raisings.
The whole program will be accounted for by the roll-over of maturing debt.
The gross program compares with $5.7 billion in 1985-86 and a peak of $9.7 billion in 1983-84.
Consistent with this reduced program, the Treasury is announcing tonight details of the next Bond Tender for an amount of $400 million.
Last year's move to a more even spread of tenders over the year was well received.
A similar schedule is planned for this year.
These measures will help to ease pressures on domestic financial markets and to lower interest rates.
Actual interest rate movements will depend also on what happens to overseas interest rates and to inflationary and exchange rate expectations.
In assessing the appropriateness of monetary policy, we will continue to review a wide range of current and prospective financial and general economic indicators.
The Government's basic objective for monetary policy is for it to play its role in full support of other policies.
We will maintain a firm monetary policy, consistent with the need to reduce inflation and to finance a current account deficit which is likely to remain large in 1986-87.
CONCLUSION
Mr President, in conclusion I wish to return to the main theme of tonight's Budget.
I have made it clear that our prime concern was to set in place the pre-conditions for a turnaround in the current account deficit.
Already there is clear evidence that the underlying forces are working as expected.
Last financial year there was a 7.4 per cent increase in the volume of Australia's exports.
Import volumes declined quite sharply-in the first half of 1986 they fell at an annual rate of more than 10 per cent.
This is the beginning of the necessary structural adjustments which I have described-the switching to new products and activities.
But this welcome improvement in export volumes and reduction in import volumes were over-shadowed by the big falls in world commodity prices.
As quickly as we lifted export volumes, export prices fell.
And in the shorter term, while we still maintain our heavy dependence on primary exports, our problem with commodity prices is not going to go away.
Large falls in import volumes are in prospect this financial year, and further export growth is expected.
But once again we must expect those positive outcomes to be masked by poor prices.
As a result, on present indications, little change is expected in our current account deficit as a percentage of GDP for 1986-87 as a whole.
For seasonal and other reasons, we expect a number of large monthly deficits over the remainder of this calendar year.
Looking further ahead, the fundamental adjustments now underway in the economy should help to achieve substantial reductions beyond 1986-87.
Mr President, when this Government was elected to office in March 1983 we inherited from our Coalition predecessors a massively debilitated economy.
We faced a Budget deficit of unprecedented magnitude, double digit inflation, double digit unemployment and the first negative growth in 30 years.
Over the past three and a half years, with absolute determination and the co-operation of the Australian people, we have overcome these legacies.
With historic levels of economic and employment growth and our sweeping reforms to the financial and taxation systems, our record of achievement is an enviable one.
Now there are new challenges to overcome.
The sudden collapse in the prices of our exports and the resulting loss of national income has forced a range of essential adjustments on the nation.
The 1986-87 Budget which I have presented tonight rings the changes on a more robust, aggressive Australian economy.
Earlier I said that by resolute action and some sacrifice all round we can face and defeat any problem.
This means staying competitive with the rest of the world and trading out of our difficulties.
This is the only path to higher growth, real independence and greater prosperity.
This will be this Budget's crowning achievement.

Leave granted.

Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill gives effect to several Government decisions relating to the remuneration of Parliamentarians, Judges and certain other public office holders.
The prime purpose is to put into effect the Government's decision not to accept the Remuneration Tribunal's recommendation of an 11.7 per cent increase in parliamentary salaries.

In presenting its 1986 review, the Tribunal stated that since 1 July 1984 the salary level of senators and members has been some 11.7 per cent less than ordinarily it should have been. The anomaly arose in the context of the 1984 review when the Tribunal established an equitable base for other groups in its jurisdiction by granting an 11.7 per cent increase, but this increase was not given to members by the Tribunal because of submissions by the Government and other parties. The same situation occurred in 1985 when the Tribunal drew attention to the anomaly but did not act in view of submissions by the Government and the opposition parties.

In 1986 the Tribunal noted similar submissions from the Government and the parties, but determined an 11.7 per cent increase on the basis of what the Tribunal saw as compliance with its statutory obligation and fairness and equity.

The Government announced, on 1 July, its intention not to accept the increase. While we recognise that parliamentary salaries are subject to a considerable anomaly and that in some cases this may be placing some strain on the resources of individual members, we have agreed that parliamentarians must, in the current economic climate, forgo any recommended increase in salary above national wage case increases.

This Act therefore amends Tribunal Determinations 7 and 8, relating to additional salary for parliamentary office holders and basic salary of Senators and Members, so that existing salaries are increased only by the outcome of the recent national wage case. The basic salary of a member will then be $45 543; had the Tribunal's determination remained in force it would have been $50 871.

As Remuneration Tribunal determinations come into effect on the date specified by the Tribunal, which in this case was 1 July 1986, the Act also allows for the alteration to the determinations to be effected retrospectively. The increased salary which has been paid to members since 1 July will therefore be required to be repaid and appropriate arrangements will be put in place. Because ministerial salaries are fixed by Government decision, Ministers have not received any payment by way of the anomaly element.
The Bill also withdraws any entitlement to an 11.7 per cent increase in parliamentary superannuation benefits.

Part III of the Bill amends the Judicial and Statutory Officers (Remuneration and Allowances) Act to give effect to Tribunal recommendations regarding the salary and allowances of judges and members of the Interstate Commission. It provides for salaries to be increased by national wage case decisions only; allowances are to be adjusted in line with cost of living increases.

The opportunity has been taken in Part IV of the Bill to alter the mechanism for increasing the annual appropriation for ministerial salaries under the Ministers of State Act so as to avoid continual alterations to the Act.

To remove the need for recurrent legislative amendment, it is proposed to amend the Ministers of State Act to provide that in future the limit should be fixed by regulation under the Act. The limit will continue to be set on the basis of the actual salaries payble to Ministers as decided by the Government following recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal. The regulations will of course be subject to the same parliamentary scrutiny and the same disallowance provisions as other regulations.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Government in favour of a recent call by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to disallow continuing expenses incurred in primary production, including forestry, as a tax deduction, unless offset against income earned from primary production activities; if so, what effect would such a decision have on private plantation forestry and private forest management in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: My 19 September 1985 Statement on Tax Reform included a farm loss quarantining measure which was to limit the ability of taxpayers to offset immediately losses incurred in primary production activities against income from other sources. The measure was designed to deal with tax sheltering activity in primary production.

It was recognised that the quarantining measure would have some effect on some existing primary production investments, particularly those with long lead times, such as private plantation forestry. The depressed state of primary production has exacerbated those potential effects, causing the measure to have a greater than anticipated impact on genuine primary producers.

In light of these considerations, the Government decided not to proceed with quarantining, but to approach the problem of tax sheltering in the primary production area with more closely targetted remedies.

To this end the Government has decided to review the operation of relevant legislative provisions. This will include: the determination of what is a genuine primary production business as opposed to a hobby farm; the distinction between business-related primary production expenditure as opposed to private expenditure; and the question of the appropriate rate of write-off of capital expenditures, operating expenses and repayments of annual expenses so that they more closely equate with the economic lives of the assests. In addition, the Government has announced changes to the trading stock valuation arrangements for income tax purposes of animals acquired by natural increase by stud operators in respect of their stud operations.

(2) What was the turnover in the Therapist professions employed by the Commonwealth in 1984.
(3) Is there a shortage, in Australia, of qualified Therapist professionals; if so, do advertised vacancies for Commonwealth employment not attract suitable applicants.
(4) What is the percentage of vacant Therapist positions in Commonwealth employment.
(5) Has the demand for Therapist services increased; if so, are Therapists, employed by the Commonwealth, suffering excessive workload pressures.
(6) What was the cost in 1984 of providing private Physio Therapy services to entitled veterans.
(7) How much would it cost the Commonwealth to upgrade the Therapist profession to rectify the problems referred to above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Following a joint review of therapist work by the Public Service Board and the Professional Officers' Association, a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on 23 December 1985 awarded an alignment of APS Therapist levels 1-4 with levels 1-4 in the Science group. Significant pay increases resulted from this decision.

(2) There has been substantial turnover in therapist positions but to obtain precise details would require significant expenditure of resources. Increased salaries for this group should reduce therapist wastage in future.

(3) There is a recognised shortage of therapists at present. However, it is envisaged that this will only be a problem in the short-term as the following measures have been undertaken to alleviate the situation:

The Minister for Education has, following recommendations from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, approved increased places in health science courses in a number of States. For example, in New South Wales, over 100 new enrolments are being funded at the Cumberland College of Health Sciences and increases have been approved for health science courses at the Lincoln Institute of Health Services in Victoria.

The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, under its occupational share system, has in 1985/86 scheduled to allow for migration of 100 physiotherapists, 50 occupational theraspist and 50 speech pathologists. Additionally, therapists should be permitted entry into Australia through the Employer Nomination Scheme.

The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations recently invited the States to participate in refresher courses for therapists. It is understood that New South Wales took up this invitation and 45 therapists will shortly undertake a 12-week refresher course at Cumberland College.

(4) The major Commonwealth employers of therapists (Department of Veterans' Affairs and Community Services, and the ACT Health Authority) currently have approximately 15% of therapists positions vacant.

(5) Yes. But changed work practices and use of part-time employees and private practitioners have alleviated the workload situation in the short term. Measures outlined above should improve the long term situation.

(7) Because the Commonwealth capacity to influence either conditions of employment or the size and distribution of the therapist workforce is limited, it is not possible to accurately assess the cost of upgrading the profession to rectify the problems raised by the honourable senator.
However, it is known that the budget for the refresher course to be run by Cumberland College for the 45 therapists is in the order of $155,000.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Aviation: Airline Staff Screening

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 7 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What input does the Federal Department of Aviation have over the security arrangements for staff screening operated by the individual airline companies, in view of the answers provided to Senator Jones in response to Questions on Notice 507, 508 and 509 (see Hansard, 5 November 1985, p. 1602).

(2) Are those ``individual'' security programs, referred to by the Minister for Aviation in his previous reply adequate, in view of widespread and ever-increasing concern over the growing incidence of hijacking episodes.

(3) Will the Federal Government consider, as a matter of considerable urgency, the possibility of upgrading its security measures to an extent whereby the Department of Aviation undertakes the security screening of each and every airport or airline on-ground or in-flight employee applicant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Prerequisites for employment with airlines including security arrangements for staff screening remains a matter for the airlines. My Department is satisfied that airline management accepts a responsible attitude in this regard.

(2) Airlines security programmes required by the Department are considered adequate. The programmes meet the requirements of the Australian Air Navigation Regulations, Air Navigation Orders and Annex 17 of the Chicago Convention of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (Safeguarding International Civil Aviation Against Acts of Unlawful Interference).

(3) Security procedures presently in place allow for upgraded measures if required. There are no plans for the Department to take over screening functions which are presently the responsibility of airlines.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States National Aeronautics and Space Administration: Astronauts

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are 60 per cent of NASA's astronauts active duty military officers, that there are 5 such officers on the space shuttle Atlantis, and that secret military missions will account for up to 30 per cent of all shuttle flights in the next decade.
(2) What functions do these secret shuttle missions serve, what role does the military play in them, and to what extent is our involvement connected, directly or indirectly to such a program.
(3) Is Australia involved in any way, how are we involved and to what extent is our involvement connected, directly or indirectly to such a program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Many astronauts employed by the US National Aeronautical and Space Administration (NASA) are military officers who have been seconded to NASA but the exact percentage is not known. Nor is the number of military officers scheduled to be aboard every Atlantis shuttle mission known, but it might be expected to vary with the requirements of each mission. President Reagan is reported to have said in early 1985 that from early 1988 one third of all shuttle missions are to be used for military purposes, but present intentions are in doubt as a result of the loss of the shuttle vehicle Challenger in January 1986 and in view of proposals being developed for alternative launch vehicles. Military missions are not always secret and it remains to be seen how many will be classified in future.

(2) and (3) We assume that shuttle flights with defence-related missions serve a variety of roles, mainly to do with the launch of satellites and with research and development. Shuttle crews and payload specialists help launch satellites from the payload bay and conduct experiments.

As the shuttle program was suspended following the loss of the Challenger vehicle, there is no occasion for Australian involvement at present. Comment about the nature and extent of any future Australian involvement in programs to be supported by NASA's space shuttle would be speculative. I am not prepared to engage in such activity.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Aviation: Withdrawal of Weather Briefing Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 27 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Aviation detail the areas where staffing cut-backs may occur following Department of Aviation plans to withdraw weather briefing staff from major Australian cities which could have serious implications for aircraft safety, particularly in cyclone prone areas where earlywarning weather services are essential.
(2) Will service be maintained by the Bureau of Meteorology.
