ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Provision of Human Services by Governments

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 28 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps have been taken to respond to repeated requests that there be held tri-partite discussions, involving all three tiers of government, with the goal of establishing long-term agreements about respective roles in the provision and funding of human services, and child-care in particular, and concluding binding contractual arrangements in view of the significant and growing participation of local government in the provision of human services, and child-care in particular.

(2) Will the Minister for Community Services press for the inclusion of local government representatives on decision-making bodies determining priority areas for the extension of human services, and child-care in particular, rather than just having them on planning committees once the basic decisions have been made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A number of discussions have taken place regarding the respective roles of the different levels of government in the provision of children's services. These have stemmed from the growth in the Commonwealth/State co-operative program and the increasing involvement of local government as contributors to the development of services and as sponsors.

This process is most advanced in Victoria. Following negotiations between my Department and the Municipal Association of Victoria (MAV) I met with the MAV in December 1985 and confirmed agreements on the operation of child care centres already approved under the sponsorship of Victorian local government authorities. It was also agreed that a consultative committee, comprising the MAV, my Department, the State Department of Community Services, the Victorian Trades Hall Council, the Australian Early Childhood Association, the Uniting Church of Australia and the Community Child Care Association of Victoria be established to advise my Department on matters that bear on operational costs of child care centres and the employment of qualified staff. The committee has also considered appropriate terms and conditions of recurrent grants between services and the Commonwealth. In May 1986, a second Victorian municipal umbrella organisation, the Metropolitan Municipal Association, joined the committee at their request.

(2) Funds under the CSP are allocated on the basis of need; a process, which is referred to as a needs based planning approach. To assist in this process, planning committees have been established in each State and Territory to advise the Minister for Community Services on geographical areas where there is a high need for children's services, on the most appropriate service type for these areas and on a priority ranking for particular service types within high need areas.

The committees' advice is based on members' general knowledge of and involvement in children's services, local area discussions and consultations, analysis of relevant statistics, and review of existing services. Membership of these committees in most States includes representatives of Commonwealth, State and local governments and community-based organisations. Care is taken to ensure the community-based representation includes service providers, service users and special needs groups.

The introduction of the needs based planning approach, which replaced an earlier system based solely on submissions, does not preclude individual community groups from submitting funding applications to the Department's State offices. Final decisions in all cases are made by the Minister, taking into account all available information and advice on relative priorities of need and funds available for the CSP.
As can be seen from the above description of the role of planning committees, their advice is given prior to decision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department of Defence conducted a study of Australian ports to determine which ones are capable now of providing facilities for visits by nuclear powered and/or armed ships, and which ports would be capable of providing such facilities in the near future with limited upgrading.
(2) If such a study has been carried out, which ports are considered to be capable now of handling such vessels, and which are considered capable of handling the vessels with limited upgrading.
(3) What facilities would be available in the event of an accident, such as fire, on any such vessel in an Australian port, or in Australian territorial waters in all cases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for De- fence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) has, however, made assessments of the suit- ability for use by nuclear powered warships of particular berths and anchorages in various Australian ports.

Visits by warships that may be armed with nuclear weapons are permitted under the same general terms and conditions as those that apply to visits by warships belonging to the governments of non-nuclear weapons states.
(2) Albany, Brisbane, Darwin, Fremantle (Gage Roads), HMAS Stirling, Hobart, Jervis Bay and Melbourne all contain berths and/or anchorages assessed by the AAEC as suitable for NPW visits.

(3) Safety plans for accidents to the reactors of visiting NPWs vary in accordance with local conditions and administrative arrangements. However, they generally include arrangements for routine and emergency radiation monitoring and protection, coordination of emergency services, evacuation, public information and the removal of the vessel to a remote safe location.

Arrangements for all other types of warship accidents, including nuclear weapon accidents, are covered in the general emergency plans for harbour accidents which exist for every Australian port. These plans utilise the resources of the port emergency services, including fire brigades, police and health agencies, along with State, Territory and Commonwealth support as appropriate.
Allied warships do not normally operate in Australian territorial waters except in transit to and from visits to Australian ports.

These estimates were based on the delivery of the required number of copies to each householder and business premises, irres-ective of whether they were telephone subscribers or non-subscribers. An additional quantity was also available for use by others as requested.

Demand for extra Brisbane directories after this initial distribution was expected to be lower than the previous year when non-subscribers were required to approach Telecom Business Offices or Post Offices for a copy. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 8 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What additional monitoring of imports of contaminated products, materials or foods are Customs personnel undertaking as a result of the Chernobyl nuclear meltdown.
(2) Have importers been advised of additional requirements if they are bringing products from regions affected by the nuclear fallout from the meltdown.
(3) Is there any additional systematic testing of foodstuffs for radioactive iodine and low-energy beta radioactivity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honour- able senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government has introduced a range of measures to assess radiation levels in foodstuffs imported from countries where evidence is to hand that particular countries have been affected by radioactive fallout from the reactor failure. These measures will minimise radioactive products entering the food chain in Australia. No measures have been taken in regard to shipments of goods other than foodstuffs as available evidence indicates such shipments pose no significant health risk. Potentially affected countries have been categorised into two risk groups:

List 1 (lower risk) countries comprise: Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Federal Republic of Germany, Finland, France, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Monaco, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, San Marino, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom; and
List 2 (higher risk) countries comprise: Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania, USSR and Yugoslavia.
Imports of foods and beverages for human consumption will be assessed for radioactivity as follows:
List 1 Countries: local assessment will be undertaken on randomly selected consignments

List 2 Countries: importers should present an approved overseas radioactivity certificate; consignments covered by overseas certificates will be randomly sampled (at a higher level than for checks of List 1 countries) to locally verify stated radioactivity levels; and where no overseas certificate is presented the consignments will be checked locally.
Consignments will not be released without Commonwealth Health approval if the radioactive concentration of caesium 137 exceeds 100 becquerels per kilogram of product.

(2) Following the Government's initial press release on 3 July 1986, the Australian Customs Service announced detailed arrangements to the importing community by Australian Customs Notice 86/179 dated 10 July 1986.

(3) Commonwealth Health has advised that the reasons why Australia and other members of the international community have based assessments on caesium 137 rather than on Iodine 131 or low energy beta radiation sources include:

The short radiological half life of Iodine 131 (approximately 8 days) makes this isotope unsuitable for monitoring potential intermediate and longer term effects of deposition from Chernobyl. Any Iodine 131 which would have been present in affected products would have effectively decayed in the period since the reactor failure.
Beta emissions are very difficult to measure at the low concentrations experienced in the present case;

Caesium 137 is one of the significant residual isotopes with an appropriate half life (approximately 30 years). Being a gamma emitting isotope, caesium 137 can be readily measured with a high degree of accuracy; and

Experience of fallout from atmospheric nuclear testing during the 1950's and 1960's gives confidence in the use of caesium 137 as an indication of the residual spectrum of intermediate (12 month to 50 year) half life products, which includes many low energy beta radiation sources.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many statutory authorities currently exist under the auspices of the Minister's Department.
(2) What are the names of these authorities.
(3) What appeal mechanisms, if any, exist for the general public to lodge a complaint against these authorities.

(4) If it is proved that any member of staff of any of these authorities is guilty of incompetence, what action, if any, could be taken by a member of the public to sue the authority for compensation; if it is not possible to sue the authority, why is that the case.

(5) How many cases concerning these authorities are currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and what is the delay at present between the listing of a case and its hearing before the Tribunal.
(6) If any statutory authority under the Minister's Department cannot be sued, will the Minister consider amending the relevant legislation to make this possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) There are two authorities within the Minister's portfolio, namely the Australian Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA) and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC). The staff of both organisations make decisions that could affect members of the public.

There are other offices, organisations, tribunals and advisory bodies within the Minister's portfolio which are constituted pursuant to statute but which do not come within the scope of the generally accepted meaning of a statutory authority.

(3) Neither the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975 nor the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985 provide appeal mechanisms. However, the normal appeal mechanisms provided by the Ombudsman Act 1976, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 and the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 are available in respect of these authorities.

In addition, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal may review decisions taken under Section 63 (4) of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act relating to the dissemination or publication of information.

(4) The Attorney-General's Department has advised that, unless an authority is statutorily protected, it is liable for the torts of its servants committed in the course of their duty. Where employees acting in the course of their duty are incompetent and, as a consequence, loss is suffered by a member of the public, it will commonly be found that the act or omission which was seen as incompetent was also tortious. In the absence of a denial of liability the negligent giving of erroneous advice is tortious where the advice is given by a person having a duty of care to one who suffers foreseeable damage as a result of reasonably relying on that advice. Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts.

Neither of the authorities listed in the answer to part (2) of this question is statutorily protected against general liability in tort. Indeed, in each case the legislation expressly provides that, as a body corporate, the authority may be sued in its corporate name.
(5) There are no cases before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 13 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do population figures presented by the Department of Communications to recent inquiries conducted by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal been consistent with figures from other sources, including the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
(2) How has the Department arrived at its population figures, particularly for Aboriginal communities.

(3) Has the Department estimated what the population will be in each of the 150 isolated communities originally listed for the Remote or Underserved Communities Scheme (RUCS), in 1988; if so, how were these estimates arrived at, and what were the estimates arrived at.

(4) Was a single methodology used to derive the population figures used by the Department in its evaluation of the suitability of the 150 isolated communities for RUCS; if so, what was the methodology, if not, what amalgam was used.
(5) What figures were arrived at for the purposes of the evaluation.
(6) Why was the population listing for Fitzroy Crossing on 20 January 1986 the only one specifically qualified as ``estimate only''.
(7) What policy consideration involving the economics of a project or any other matter led to the setting of 200 as the minimum population for any community to qualify for RUCS.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The population figures presented to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by the Department of Communications were based on the 1981 Census of Population and Housing population statistics published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). The population figures for communities provided by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) differ from those published by the ABS. The differences can be attributed to the following factors:
The ABS Census was carried out on a single day (20 June 1981); the DAA survey was not carried out simultaneously but statistics were collected over a period of months in 1983.

For social and cultural reasons some Aboriginal communities have reported as members of the community, those who are permanently absent. For such reasons DAA figures are not consistent with those provided by the ABS.
(3) No estimate has been made of the population of RUCS sites in 1988.

(4) Yes. The ABS Census data referred to provide population figures for all communities, or bounded rural localities with a population of 200 or more persons, and were the basis of the Department of Communications population estimates for RUCS.

(6) The Published ABS figure for Fitzroy Crossing's population was 428. However, it was subsequently acknowledged by the ABS that this figure only included the Aboriginal population of the nearby Aboriginal reserve. The non-Aboriginal population of Fitzroy Crossing proper was less than 200 and was therefore not listed by the ABS because of concern that statistics on small communities (less than 200) may breach the confidentiality of individuals.

However, Departmental estimates, based on the population for the Local Government Area, place the population at close to 200. On this basis, the Aboriginal population of 428 was combined with the remaining population of approximately 200. Therefore, the total population was estimated at 628; hence the qualification ``estimate only''.

(7) The 1981 Census data published by ABS provide information only on bounded rural localities with a population of 200 or more. The terms ``bounded rural localities'' and ``communities'' are for the purpose of RUCS, considered by my Department to be interchangeable. The ABS defines a bounded rural locality as a discerning nucleus of population around which a definite boundary can be drawn. Communities included in RUCS were selected in descending order of population. The smallest community selected for RUCS has a population of 500.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 13 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What consultation has the Department of Communications undertaken with the Aboriginal communities among the 42 communities named on 20 January 1986 as those to receive ABC television via the Remote or Underserved Communities Scheme (RUCS).
(2) When did consultations start with each of those communities.
(3) What consultation was conducted with officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs during the process of identifying the 42 communities to be served through RUCS.

(4) Do remote and underserved South Australian Aboriginal communities, such as Ernabella, have larger populations than some of the communities chosen for RUCS; if so, why have they been excluded in favour of smaller or better served communities in other areas.
(5) When is it expected that the Ernabella community will receive a licence to cover the experimental community television transmissions which began a year ago.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Communications has not directly participated in consultation with Aboriginal communities selected to receive an ABC-TV service under the Remote or Underserved Communities Scheme (RUCS).

Communities were selected for RUCS in accordance with criteria announced by the Minister for Communications on 7 September 1984. From an initial list of approximately 150 communities with populations greater than 200 people, the final 42 communities were selected primarily on the basis of population size as reflected in the 1981 Census.

Consultants were sent to 63 communities, including 21 Aboriginal communities, primarily to prepare engineering reports but also to provide demographic and social data, which were used in the selection process.

Twelve of the communities chosen for RUCS are Aboriginal communities; all of these except Bamaga were visited by the consultants. Bamaga has a Self-help Television Reception Scheme (STRS) system which was licensed in May 1984. This system will be replaced under RUCS by a professional system suited to the population size.

(2) The eleven Aboriginal communities-Kowanyama, Port Keats, Yuendumu, Hermannsburg, Manigrida, Milingimbi, Fitzroy Crossing Woorabinda, Aurukun, Doomadgee and Hooker Creek were all visited by consultants in the period February to June 1985. Bamaga corresponded with the Department at least 6 months prior to the grant of their STRS licence; some of the other communities had also contacted the Department in relation to STRS systems, prior to the consultants' visits.
(3) As one of the prime criteria for RUCS selection was population, community sizes were checked with DAA at various times over the period 1983-1986.
(4) No. The population of Ernabella, from 1983 DAA figures, is 372. (It is not listed separately in Bureau of Statistics Census data). The smallest community in RUCS has a population of 500 people.

(5) The Department of Communications, in conjunction with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, is examining what form of licence arrangement is appropriate for remote Aboriginal communities. This study is in response to the Government's acceptance of recommendations made by the Task Force on Aboriginal and Islander Broadcasting and Communications. However, the transmitting equipment at Ernabella does not meet the minimum standard for licensing. A licence could not be issued until the equipment is upgraded.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What broadcasts were made by the Australian Trade Union officials, on Radio Moscow's Shortwave news service between the 15th of April 1985 and 14th of May 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In addition, formal and on-the-job training for Philippines personnel has been provided in-country as part of DCP projects. Numbers of AFP personnel who have come to Australia in each year since 1963 are:
* Prior to 1978 training was conducted on a calendar year basis; there is some overlap of the 1978 and 1978-79 figures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it important that young people be educated about Australia's place in the Asian region.

(2) Is it important for a national policy to be developed to ensure that the educational systems at primary, secondary and tertiary level be properly geared to meet our national needs in the area of relations with Asia.

(3) Would an Asian Studies Council be the appropriate body to devise strategies to increase and effectively use the resources available for the teaching, research and dissemination of information about Asia within Australia.
(4) Has a working party been set up to advise the Government on the possibility of creating an Asian Studies Council; if so, has that party yet reported to the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. It is vital that our young people, industry and the community as a whole be educated about Australia's place in the Asian region.

(2) Yes. A national strategy to meet growing requirements in relation to Asian studies is needed, particularly to support expansion of our economic relations with Asia. Urgent advice on such a strategy has been requested of the recently established Asian Studies Council, as announced by the Ministers for Foreign Affairs, Trade and myself on 13 May 1986.

(3) The Government has decided that an Asian Studies Council is the appropriate body to devise such strategies to stimulate and promote national awareness of Asia in industry and the community; to provide a national perspective on Asian studies requirements in Australian education; and to develop, promote and guide a national strategy for the strengthening of Asian studies to meet growing national requirements. The Government's decision followed its consideration of the Report of the Working Party on the Asian Studies Council.

(4) The Working Party on the Asian Studies Council reported to the Ministers for Foreign Affairs and Trade and myself at end December 1985. Following the announcement on 13 May 1986 of the Government's decision to establish the Asian Studies Council, copies of the Report were distributed to all Senators and Members of Parliament. As I said in the Senate on 16 April 1986, I will be making a Statement on the Council to the Senate after finalising decisions on membership of the Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 April 1986:

(3) Was the response from the CTEC that it was not willing to consider the proposal for the current 1985-87 triennium.

(4) Will the Federal Government give approval for the introduction in Victoria of 4-year pre-service Bachelor of Education (Primary) courses for commencing and some continuing students in 1987, since the proposal of the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission is backed up by extensive assessments and investigations at both national and state levels.

(5) Will the Government also give approval for the phasing-in period in Victoria for 4-year Bachelor of Education (Primary) courses to conclude with all students completing the third year of a Bachelor of Education (Primary) in 1989 proceeding immediately to the fourth year in 1990.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (4) and (5) In view of the priorities given by this Government to increasing intakes into higher education and promoting greater equity of access in the 1985-87 triennium and the major resource implications of the proposal, the Government accepts the advice of CTEC that the proposal not be considered in the 1985-87 triennium.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: WIN Television Ltd: Change from VHF to UHF

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 30 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has concern been expressed by the Management of WIN Television Limited of the proposed change of that station from Channel 4 VHF to a UHF Channel frequency.

(2) If WIN Television is forced to change to a UHF frequency, would most of the 111,700 households in the Illawarra region have to install a separate aerial which is estimated to cost $110 each and further, that 20 per cent of the viewing audience would also have to install a down converter which is estimated to cost $150.

(3) Would the total cost to the local community of converting their television sets to receive UHF broadcasts be in the vicinity of $15.3m and could such a cost be deemed to be in the public interest.

(4) Has the Department of Communications identified that over 9,000 residents in the Illawarra region are already experiencing deficient reception of SBS programs on Channel 28 and that more residents stand to lose access to local commercial television if the proposed change takes place; what action, if any, will the Government take to restore a local television service to the area; if not, why not.

(5) If the proposed change takes place would WIN Television lose over $4m per annum in revenue through the loss of local advertising and would the loss of local advertising have a disastrous effect on the local economy.

(6) Would the Minister for Communications not agree that a compromise between WIN Television and the Department of Communications could be reached on this issue, given the close proximity of the Illawarra region to Sydney, and the disastrous effect that the same change has had on the ratings of SBS television.

(7) Could not such a compromise be along the lines as outlined in the Plan of Action provided to the Minister on 6 February 1986 by the Management of WIN Television, given the reluctance of the Department of Communications to maintain WIN Television on a permanent VHF Broadcasting frequency.
(8) Does the Plan of Action involve the following:
(a) WIN will commence transmission of a second commercial service on UHF during July 1987 in line with the Government's Equalisation of Services program.
(b) Transfer WIN channel 4 to channel 3-July 1988.
(c) Commence transmission of a third commercial service on UHF-January 1991.
(d) Commence simulcasting WIN 3 on UHF-July 1996.
(e) Cease transmission on VHF channel 3-December 1996.
(9) If the Minister does not favour this Plan of Action, why not.

(10) Can the Minister table in the Senate, if there is one, a list of successful UHF stations operating in the USA, in conditions similar to those that would be experienced by a UHF station if one operated in the Illawarra region.
(11) Will the Minister table in the Senate, a list of all other television stations in Australia who will be required to change their broadcasting service from VHF to UHF.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, WIN management has expressed concern about the possible impact of the change from channel 4 to a UHF channel. However, the station has not challenged the need to move from channel 4 and it acknowledges that UHF can provide a high quality service.

(2) It is quite misleading to suggest that Wollongong viewers need to install UHF equipment simply to receive WIN-TV. WIN does not have to leave channel 4 until 1989; in the meanwhile, SBS-TV already serves the area on UHF and Wollongong is to receive two new commercial services on UHF as part of the Government's equalisation program. With all these services, plus WIN on UHF, the local ABC transmitter will also be switched to UHF.
Thus Wollongong residents who choose to install UHF receiving equipment will be doing so in the knowledge that those facilities will ultimately give them access to five local television services.

(3) Individual householders will invest in UHF receiving equipment because they wish to have access to better reception and a greater choice of television programs. Attempting to aggregate the investment that people in one area are prepared to make to obtain that greater choice is meaningless. The local public investment in large VHF antennas and video-cassette recorders, is an example of the investment made in the past by residents to obtain greater choice in TV programming. The investment necessary in UHF-TV antennas will be quite small by comparison.

(4) SBS-TV currently transmits in Wollongong on UHF channels 59 and 44. While it is true that in some areas of Wollongong the UHF signals are less than accurate, the main SBS transmitter is currently using an interim antenna. Signal levels will be increased when the final antenna is installed.

I should emphasize that local terrain makes the Illawarra a difficult area to cover with television signals. The problem areas referred to by Senator Mason actually involve less than five percent of Wollongong residents; Department of Communications surveys indicate that the present UHF coverage of Wollongong is actually superior to that provided on channel 4 in some areas.

(5) Inspection of the FDU Report on Future Directions for Commercial Television, shows that WIN serves one of the largest and most lucrative markets in regional television in Australia. The proposed change in transmission arrangements has the potential to affect the size of WIN's viewing audience and thus affect its revenue. Officers of the Department of Communications are working with the station to establish arrangements which will minimise the impact on viewers and the station's future operations.

(6) As noted in 5 above, officers of the Department of Communications are negotiating with WIN management, to find the smoothest possible path for WIN's transition from channel 4 to UHF. The need for WIN to change frequency arises from the fact that its continued operation on channel 4 is severely hampering the introduction of new FM radio services.
9(7) Every option for WIN to remain on a VHF channel has been fully investigated over a period of years.

The proposal put forward by WIN management on 6 February 1986 relies entirely on the station being able to move its main transmitter from channel 4 to channel 3. Such a move is difficult to contemplate when one realises that, just like channel 4, channel 3 overlaps the FM radio band. As in the case of WIN, television stations currently using channel 3 have to be moved to new channels to allow FM radio development to proceed.
(9) In addition to the factors addressed in the answer to question seven, the WIN plan suggests that a third commercial service would not commence in Wollongong until 1991.

(10) There is no such list. While, in the northern part of its market, WIN suffers some competition because viewers are also able to watch the three Sydney commercial stations, in the remainder of its service area WIN has enjoyed a total monopoly situation since it first opened. In commercial television in the USA, competition is fierce and every station shares its entire market with numerous competitors. It is doubtful that there would be a single station in the USA which enjoys a monopoly situation such as WIN currently enjoys.

(11) A comprehensive timetable for the clearance of television services from channels 3, 4 and 5 (known as Band II) is currently being compiled. This document will include details of the channels to which each station is to be shifted, as well as the approximate date by which the move needs to be implemented. A draft of the timetable is to be available for public comment later this year and it will certainly be made available to Senators.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What information is available to the Australian public about a little publicised dam collapse in Sri Lanka on 20 April 1986.
(2) Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs in a position to confirm or deny a claim by a Norwegian aid official that 2500 people were missing following the disaster and that a further 7800 are homeless.
(3) Was the tragedy the result of a structural malfunction or was the dam deliberately breached.
(4) Has any organisation claimed responsibility for breaching the dam.
(5) Has any request been made to Australia from the Government of Sri Lanka for financial or other assistance for the victims.
(6) Will consideration be given by the Australian Government for the provision of aid if the extent of the disaster is as severe as claimed by the Norwegian official.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 20 April 1986 the main wall of the Kantalai Reservoir near Trincomalee in north-eastern Sri Lanka collapsed. Floodwaters washed over dozens of surrounding villages.

(2) Latest reports indicate that 127 people have been killed or are missing feared dead and some 6000 people have been made homeless. Earlier reports suggested that the devastation, in terms of numbers of people affected, was far worse than has proved to be the case.

(3) and (4) The collapse was a natural disaster. The Sri Lankan Minister for National Security has himself ruled out the possibility that the collapse was the result of sabotage and no organisation has claimed responsibility for the disaster.
(5) At the request of the Sri Lankan Government the UN Disaster Relief Organisation (UNDRO) on 24 April 1986 launched an international appeal for assistance.

(6) The Australian Government has contributed $50,000 to the UNDRO appeal for victims of the dam collapse. The funds are being directed to the League of Red Cross Societies, one of the agencies assisting affected Sri Lankans.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are current statistics on the number and percentage of trucks believed to be operating with defects on Australian roads available and could the Minister for Tansport provide a State by State breakdown and include the Territories in view of information provided by the New South Wales Department of Motor Transport that half the trucks on roads in that State have defects.
(2) What current measures are in place between the Commonwealth and the States to monitor and enforce laws against all defective vehicles but particularly trucks.

(3) What proportion of (a) fatal, and (b) non-fatal but recorded accidents on Australian roads, involved trucks in the following yearly periods: 1983-84, 1984-85, and so far as records show in the current financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The major problem of compiling national statistics on trucks operating with defects is the lack of consistency of data recorded by States and Territories. Legal requirements vary and there are differences in interpretations and definitions of a truck.
The following limited information is provided in respect of New South Wales, Queensland and South Australia.

New South Wales-N.S.W. Report on Heavy Vehicle Inspection Results for 1984-85 are: 36,752 inspections conducted of which 17,644 (48.0%) were found to be defective and 2,390 (6.5%) had major or extremely dangerous defects.

Queensland-1983-84, 80,503 commercial vehicles inspected 9,883 re-inspected (defective) (12.3%). 1984-85, 80,752 commercial vehicles inspected 9,873 re-inspected (defective) (12.2%). July 85 to March 86, 45,520 commercial vehicles inspected 8,710 re-inspected (defective) (19.1%).
South Australia-Police have power to issue defect notices to vehicles which are in an unroadworthy condition. It is estimated that 10% of notices issued would be for commercial vehicles.

(2) Individual States and Territories are currently responsible for monitoring the incidence of defective vehicles and for enforcing road safety laws for vehicles travelling within a particular State or Territory. Under the Interstate Road Tansport Act 1985, a Federal Registration Scheme for vehicles engaged in interstate trade and commerce is planned to commence on 1 January 1987. Vehicles registering in the scheme will be inspected annually. It is expected that the incidence of vehicle rejections will be recorded as part of the statistics that will be required to be kept under the Federal Scheme.

(3) Statistics of road crashes on Australian roads are aggregated into calendar year totals and fiscal year totals are not readily available. Information available on the involvement of trucks in fatal crashes and crashes resulting in admission to hospitals is available, as follows, for the years 1983, 1984 and 1985.
* Excluding NSW-data which is not yet available.
+ Excluding ACT-data which is not yet available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Consumers' Association called for stricter regulations to be applied to protect consumers from unsafe or ineffectual alternative medicine products.
(2) What measures are in place to check the quality or the efficacy of such products before they are offered for sale to the public.
(3) What measures are in place to check the medical, and/or pharmaceutical qualifications of those responsible for producing alternative medicines for public sale.
(4) Are any figures available on how many alternative medical practitioners are operating in Australia and how many patients they attract.
(5) Is any attempt being made to register these people and monitor their practices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand the Australian Consumers' Association has called for stricter regulations to be applied to protect consumers from unsafe or ineffectual alternative medicine products in a submission it has made to the Victorian Inquiry into Alternative Medicine and the Health Food Industry.

(2) Under current legislation, local manufacturers of these preparations may be inspected to ensure that their products are manufactured in accordance with a Code of Good Manufacturing Practice; that however is a matter for the States. National legislation for licensing of manufacturers, which would be conditional upon inspection under the Code of Good Manufacturing Practice, is being discussed with State Health Ministers.

With regard to preparations being imported into Australia, my Department endeavours to obtain a statement from the regulatory authority in the country of export that they have been manufactured under a Code of Good Manufacturing Practice, and that the manufacturer's premises are regularly inspected. So far as efficacy is concerned no checks are made but the only claims allowed are confined to simple statements along traditional lines of use.

(3) At present this is a matter for State law. Under the Australian Code of Good Manufacturing Practice the key personnel involved in the manufacture and control of therapeutic goods should have a background of appropriate education or appropriate experience or a combination thereof, for assuming responsibility to ensure that the goods have the identity, strength, quality and purity that they purport to possess.
(4) The only figures available on how many alternative medical practitioners are operating in Australia are detailed below:

Source: Figures for Victoria, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory are from the Australian Chiropractors' Association; figures for other States are from the respective State registration authorities.
Osteopaths: Separate figures are not held for osteopaths and in most States and Territories joint chiropractors/osteopaths comprise the majority of registrants.
Naturopaths: Figures available for naturopaths are for 1984, and represent naturopaths accredited by the Australian Natural Therapies Accreditation Board:
Data for other States and Territories not available.
Acupuncturists: Figures available for acupuncturists are for 1984 and represent acupuncturists accredited by the Australian Natural Therapies Accreditation Board.
Data for other States and Territories not available.

The figures from the 1983 Australian Health Survey indicate that 1.9% of the population or approximately 288,000 persons consulted with either a chiropractor, osteopath, naturopath, herbalist or acupuncturist during the two weeks prior to the interview taking place.

(5) Registration of medical and paramedical health occupations is not a function of my portfolio. Each State and Territory Government determines which health occupations should be registrable within its jurisdiction and maintains its own registers accordingly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 5 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Science give details of funding sources for Antarctic research.
(2) What percentage comes from Federal, State, University and Private funding, respectively.
(3) Can the Minister give details of:
(a) the criteria for allocation of funding specifically for scientific research in particular areas, such as geology, physics or biology, in Antarctica; and
(b) the percentage of that funding allocated to such specific areas of scientific research in Antarctica.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Federal funding for Antarctic research and data collection is provided through the Antarctic Division, the Bureau of Meteorology and the Ionospheric Prediction Service of the Department of Science; and through the Bureau of Mineral Resources and the Division of National Mapping of the Department of Resources and Energy.
State funding of Antarctic research is provided through the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service for research conducted on Macquarie Island.
Antarctic research conducted by universities is funded through the Australian Research Grants Scheme, the Marine Sciences and Technologies Grants, and through individual University funds.
Details of funding for organisations that are involved in Antarctic research but are outside the Antarctic Division are not routinely available and a survey has not been conducted recently.
The Antarctic Division of the Department of Science allocated $7.545 million to Antarctic research in 1985/86. This figure includes salaries, administrative and operational expenses.

(3) (a) Allocation of funds for research in various disciplines depends on the scientific merit of programs as assessed by scientific experts, on the area of operations in the Antarctic, the extent to which programs proposed are capital intensive, the extent of logistic support required, and the staff resources required to support the projects proposed. The broad directions in which research can proceed are determined by the Antarctic Science Advisory Committee (or its predecessor, the Antarctic Research Policy Advisory Committee), and thus the extent to which disciplines can be financially supported is a reflection of the priorities established by these Committees.

(3) (b) The percentage of Antarctic Division funding of Antarctic research for 1986/87, including salaries, administrative and operational expenditure, according to the scientific disciplines studies, is as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1986:

These toll-free numbers and local numbers were published on the back of the booklet ``Fringe Benefits Tax: a guide for employers''.
(a) There are 54 taxation officers presently attached to these units.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 6 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How significant are marketing tactics by the United States and Europe to the decline in the fortunes of some Australian farmers, given the reported remarks by the United States Ambassador to Australia, Mr Bill Lane, that Australia should stop complaining that the United States is preying on its farm produce markets.
(2) What are the marketing tactics and which areas of agriculture are being worst affected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian farmers are among the most efficient in the world. They are not shielded from the operations of the market and are obliged to respond directly to market price signals.
There is no doubt that competition for sales from heavily subsidised exporters from the US and the EC has been a major contributing factor to the current Australian rural problems.

The agricultural support policies of the US and the European Community have resulted in a continued growth in production in these countries and a major buildup of stocks with a consequent adverse effect on free market prices. World trade in agricultural commodities is becoming increasingly distorted as the major stockholding nations have increasingly resorted to export subsidies to dispose of these stocks.
Producers in the US and EC have been insulated from the deteriorating world market prices caused by this export subsidisation by either import restrictions, price support or deficiency payments.

Australian producers, on the other hand, are particularly vulnerable to the price-depressing effects of these subsidies as they are price takers on the world market. For example, international wheat prices have declined by almost 25% over the past five years. The effect of this price decline has been a dramatic reduction in incomes for grain producers. The BAE has estimated, for example, that, for wheat, farm income on family farms declined from $47,500 in 1981/82 to minus $7,500 in 1985/86.

In recent months the international trading situation has deteriorated, with increasing trade tensions between the US and the EC because of the provisions associated with the accession of Spain and Portugal, and increases in EC export subsidies in retaliation for US Export Enhancement Program (EEP) sales. The Australian Government has repeatedly cautioned both the US and the EC that there can be no winners in any trade war and that the proper avenues for the resolution of such conflicts are in multilateral fora such as the GATT.
The policies of the US and the EC are not the only international factors currently having an adverse effect on the rural sector.

Other factors include the fall in the growth in import demand by major developing countries in line with slower income growth in these countries and policy changes in centrally planned economies, for example China, and in other countries, such as India, which have resulted in major increases in production in these countries and a consequent drop in import demand in some traditional markets.

(2) The main international marketing tactics of the US and the EC are the EEP, the Targeted Export Assistance Program (TEAP), marketing loan schemes for rice and cotton and the provision of Government-guaranteed export credit in the US, and the use of export subsidies (referred to as restitutions by Europeans) in the EC.

The EEP is a program authorising the spending of up to $US1.5 billion on assistance for exports of agricultural products. It will apply over the three US fiscal years to 30 September 1988 and a minimum of $1 billion must be spent on the program during this period.

The program which was announced on 15 May 1985, and subsequently included in the US Food Security Act of 1985 (US Farm Bill), offers US Government-owned commodities as bonuses against commercial sales of US agricultural products to targeted markets. The objectives of the program have been specified as being to increase US agricultural exports and to regain markets taken unfairly by foreign competitors who use export subsidies, in particular the EC.

The Australian Government has made many representations to the US Administration, members of Congress and industry representatives on the EEP since its inception. The Prime Minister has written to President Reagan on two occasions emphasising Australia's concerns and also raised these matters in discussions with the President and with Administration officials during his visit to Washington in April. I put our concerns to the Secretary for Agriculture and other senior US figures on a number of occasions last year and in June this year. The Minister for Trade visited Washington in February to take up, at first hand, Australia's concerns on the EEP and the Farm Bill, and, in early June undertook bilateral discussions with the EC and the US during a visit to the Republic of Korea, Canada and the US.

During my most recent visit, I stressed that Australian farmers would lose around one third of their net income in the next year as a direct result of the US Farm Act. I pointed out that the subsidised disposal of surplus products in the US was creating havoc in international markets and seriously damaging the economies of agricultural dependent countries. I was reassured that Australian concerns were genuinely considered in the administration of the EEP and that the US was attempting to manage its export programs in ways that would limit their effect on non-subsidising countries.
In addition to these visits and approaches, our Embassy in Washington has made continued representations on the subject, particularly in cases where Australian markets have been threatened.

These approaches have had some degree of success. It is our assessment that they contributed to the decision by Congress, in March, to halve the mandatory expenditure provision of the EEP from $US2 billion to $US 1 billion. We have also been given assurances that the EEP will be administered on a targeted basis aimed essentially at markets of subsidising exporters, and that recipients under the EEP will be encouraged to maintain their normal level of imports from traditional non-subsidising suppliers such as Australia.

To date, the bulk of EEP expenditure has been directed towards exports of grains, although the Farm Bill provisions for the program state that 15% of the total expenditure must be in the area of livestock products. Specific EEP initiatives have been announced for wheat, wheat flour, rice, barley malt, barley, semolina, mixed poultry feed, frozen poultry, eggs and dairy cattle.

A second export assistance program which could have implications for Australia is the Targeted Export Assistance Program (TEAP). This program provides for mandatory expenditure of $110 million a year for US fiscal years 1986-88 and $325 million a year for 1989-1990, in cash or commodities, to counter or offset the adverse effects of subsidies, import quotas or other unfair trade practices on the export of US agricultural commodities.

While TEAP expenditure to date has been confined to promotional expenditure for fruit and vegetables, provision also exists for the implementation of a blended credit program. This involves a mix of commercial and concessional credit for US agricultural exports, thereby effectively reducing the cost of such credit. Such a program, if implemented, could further disrupt international agricultural trade.

The marketing loan schemes for rice and cotton are also of concern to Australia. These involve the provision of additional subsidies through repayment of Government loans at less than the loan rate and provision for payments-in-kind to rice and cotton producers. The loan rate is the price per unit (bushel, bale or pound) at which the US Commodity Credit Corporation (CCC) will provide loans to farmers who participate in commodity programs and who submit their crop as collateral. The rate is also the effective price at which the CCC purchases the crop from producers who choose to repay their loan by forfeiting their crops.

These subsidy provisions allow exporters to offer rice and cotton on world markets at lower prices. Such action could, if the prices were sufficiently low, threaten Australian interests in major rice and cotton markets. In fact, the rice provisions have allowed US exporters to contemplate exporting rice to Papua New Guinea, Australia's largest market for rice. To date, however, we have received no indication of actual shipments of rice from the US to this market.

The Government has also been concerned about the possibility of the spead of marketing loan schemes to other crops, for example wheat. However, during my recent visit to the US, I was advised by Secretary for Agriculture Lyng that marketing loans would not be introduced for wheat in 1987. This prospect has not been ruled out, however, for later years, should the agricultural situation not improve.

Other US export marketing practices which reduce the competitiveness of Australian exports are the use of Government-guaranteed export credits for periods ranging from 6 months to 10 years. Australia has voiced its objections to the Administration over the introduction of a 3-10 year export credit guarantee program under the Intermediate Credit Guarantee Program.

As part of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), the EC implements a program of export restitutions (subsidies) on the export of specified agricultural commodities to designated markets. This is necessary to dispose of the surpluses generated by the CAP's domestic support policies. These subsidies amounted to around $A9.3 billion in 1984 and $A9.6 billion in 1985.

This represented 36% of the total Community support to its agricultural sector in 1984 ($A25.8 billion) and 34% of total support in 1985 ($A28.2 billion). Moreover, in these two years, EC budgetary support for the CAP took 70% and 67% of the total EC budget.

The operation of the CAP has affected world prices for many of Australia's agricultural exports, either through EC export activities or EC import restrictions. For the major temperate products, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has estimated that the EC's agricultural policies have depressed world prices by an average of 16% over the past decade.

The Australian Government is continually seeking to place our concerns before the EC Commission and EC Member States. I have pressed these concerns myself on many occasions. I visited the Community in February and June last year and again in June this year for discussions with EC Commissioners and Commission officials, and with the Ministers for Agriculture of various EC Member States. Again, other Ministers including the Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade have made many personal representations on the need for CAP reform and the avoidance of actions that would adversely affect Australian rural exports.

Australia has also been prominent in the public debate on reform of the CAP, and in September 1985 presented a submission to the Commission on its Green Paper on ``Perspectives for the Common Agricultural Policy''. The 1986/87 EC farm price package recently agreed by the EC Council of Agricultural Ministers was disappointing in its implications for reform of the CAP. The message that I bore in my recent trip was that such reform could no longer be evaded. The recent appointment of a Special Trade Representative in Europe will further enhance our ability to make representations to the EC Member States and interested groups in the EC.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 7 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many new major hotels
(a) have been built in Australia since 1983;
(b) are presently under construction in Australia; and
(c) are planned for future construction in Australia.
(2) What is the value of the projects in each of the groups in (a), (b) and (c) above.
(3) How many major refurbishments of major hotels
(a) have been completed in Australia since 1983;
(b) are presently in progress; and
(c) are planned in Australia.
(4) What is the value of the projects in each of the groups in (a), (b) and (c) above.
(5) How many new jobs in the Australian tourist accommodation industry
(a) have been created since 1983; and
(b) are expected to be created in the next 3 years.
(6) Have new and expanded hotels experienced any difficulty in finding trained staff.
(7) What steps in the Government taking to increase funding for training in the tourism accommodation industry.
(8) Does the strong growth of investment and employment in the tourist accommodation industry give the lie to the myth that penalty rates are forcing establishments to close.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (2) (a) Information provided to the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism by State/Territory tourism authorities indicates that since December 1983 the number of major international standard hotels has increased by almost 50 per cent to 58 establishments in operation as at 31 December 1985.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics' Australian Tourist Accommodation Series shows that overall the number of hotels/motels increased by 179 establishments, from 3,750 to 3,929 between the March quarter 1983 and the September quarter 1985 (latest available data).

From an analysis of figures provided by Cordell Building Publications, the Department has estimated that between 1 July 1982 and 31 March 1984 tourist accommodation and resort projects (including major hotels) valued at $646.1 million commenced. However this figure showed strong growth over the next seven quarters from 1 April 1984 to 31 December 1985 when projects to the value of over $1540 million commenced.

(1) (2) (b) At the end of the December quarter 1985 there were 21 major international standard establishments under construction. The value of all major tourism projects under construction (including major hotels) as at 31 December 1985 was $2,498 million. Source: State/Territory tourism authorities.

(1) (2) (c) At the end of the December quarter 1985 information supplied to the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, by the State/Territory tourism authorities, showed there were 12 major hotels firmly committed to commence construction within approximately eighteen months.

Analysis of data supplied to the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism by Cordell Building Publications indicates that as at 31 December 1985 there were $6,389 million of proposed tourist accommodation and resort developments in the pipeline. Although not all of the developments will proceed in the short term the figures do serve to highlight the buoyant nature of the tourism industry and the interest and confidence of investors.
(3) (4) Official statistics on hotel refurbishments are not available.

(5) (a) While accurate statistics are not available, it is estimated that as at 30 September 1985 there were about 76,200 persons employed full-time and part-time in the hotel/motel industry. This represents an increase of some 8,900 positions since 31 March 1983.

(b) Based on the levels of tourism related construction activity the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism estimates that tourism projects commenced since 31 March 1984 will contribute around 8,300 permanent full and part-time jobs as they are progressively completed and become operational.

(6) Yes. The growth in tourism in Australia has created strong demand for trained staff to work in the accommodation sector. The CES has mounted special recruitment drives to find suitable staff for major new international standard hotels such as the Regent of Sydney and the Sydney Inter-Continental. Various other measures have been adopted by the Government to overcome the problem.

(7) The Government has already taken steps to increase funding for training in all sectors of the tourism industry including the accommodation sector by increasing the allocation for the National Tourism Industry Training Committee (NTITC) every year since 1983, in addition to providing significant funds for broader labour market programs which also benefit the industry.

(8) A number of misconceptions about the impact of penalty rates still exist. If the tourism industry is to fulfil its potential for job generation, it needs to be recognised that, as a seven day a week industry, a sensible wage formula and flexibility in award provisions is required.

The issue of penalty rates however cannot be considered in isolation. I understand that there is an opportunity for tourism industry interest to be aired before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the context of the proposed review of minimum rates, paid rates and supplementary payments.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Weight Limits for Heavy Road Vehicles

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 7 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) At what stage is the proposed review of weight limits for heavy road vehicles conducted by the National Association of Australian State Road Authorities.
(2) What is the Government's attitude to this proposal.
(3) What effect would increased weight limits have on the cost of road maintenance.
(4) What effect would increased weight limits have on construction standards for new roadworks and what would be the cost of any changed standards.
(5) What is the Government's attitude to the funding of any increased costs.
(6) What effect would increased weight limits have on fuel consumed by the road transport industry and what would be the revenue effect of altered consumption levels.
(7) What consideration has been given to the road safety aspects of increased weight limits.
(8) What special problems would be caused in relation to rural roads by increased weight limits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Review of Road Vehicle Limits has been released by the National Association of Australian State Road Authorities for public comment.

The period for public comment was extended at the initiative of the Federal Government from 30 March to 30 June 1986 following advice from the Australian Road Freight Transport Advisory Committee, which is an industry advisory body reporting to the Federal Minister for Transport.
In addition, a special working party of government and industry representatives has prepared a paper for public comment by 31 July 1986 which examines possible cost recovery measures.

(2) The Federal Government will determine its final attitude to the Review of Road Vehicle Limits Study once all interested community groups have had an adequate opportunity to respond to the Study and to the paper on possible cost recovery measures prepared by a special working party of government and industry representatives.

(3) The Review of Road Vehicle Limits Study canvassed three alternative options, A, B, and C, for revised vehicle mass and dimension limits. For a typical semi-trailer in the eastern States these options could respectively involve a gross vehicle mass of 41 tonnes, 42 tonnes and 42.5 tonnes, compared to the existing mass limit of 38 tonnes.
The study team estimated that the increased costs to maintain the road system for each option in 1984/85 prices would be as follows:

(4) The costs of constructing and maintaining roads to accommodate higher vehicle mass limits as estimated in the Review of Road Vehicle Limits Study are outlined in the answers to part 3. These costs reflect higher construction standards for particular roads.
(5) The Federal Government shares the view of the Australian Transport Advisory Council which brings together Federal, State and Territory Ministers responsible for transport, that:
any additional costs associated with relaxing vehicle mass and dimension limits should be recovered from road user beneficiaries, and
any additional revenues should be earmarked for expenditure on roads.
(6) The Review of Road Vehicle Limits Report estimated that annual revenue cost savings in fuel consumption in 1984/85 prices for each option would be as follows:

The revenue effects of higher vehicle mass and dimension limits would depend on the degree to which they were utilized by industry. The implications for the Federal Government are not expected to be significant.

(7) The Review of Road Vehicle Limits Study examined safety issues connnected with relaxing vehicles mass and dimension limits and, in addition, the Federal Government sought advice from the Federal Office of Road Safety. After careful consideration the Office concluded that:
the proposed increases in mass and dimension limits would not have any adverse safety implications
current Australian Design Rules have the capacity to handle the proposed mass increase.

The Federal Office of Road Safety also commented that although further improvements to the Australian Design Rules are being developed, they are not a pre-requisite for the safe introduction of proposed mass limits. All the proposed mass limits are in use in one or more States already and, as a consequence, many vehicles now in use have been designed and certified to operate at the proposed limits.

(8) Special problems of the various classes of roads, including rural roads, were taken into account in the cost estimates contained in the Review of Road Vehicles Study which were provided in the answer to Part 3. They are also recognised in the ATAC cost recovery principles outlined in the answer to part 5.

Salary and allowances of two members ... 137,000

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 7 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the extent of radioactivity in tobacco smoke.
(2) What are the main radioactive components.
(3) What mechanisms exist to allow the Australian public to know the answers to questions (1) and (2) above.
(4) What mechanisms exist to require advertisements or containers of tobacco products to make known this information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Tobacco smoke from a single cigarette has an average radioactivity content of about 20 millibecquerels of lead-210, bismuth-210 and polonium-210 plus small amounts of radium-226 and its short lived radioactive daughters.
(2) The main radioactive components are lead-210 and polonium-210.

(3) and (4) A range of mechanisms exist for informing the Australian public about the main radioactive components and the extent of radioactivity in tobacco smoke. These include news releases, package labelling-for example, through an extension of the existing Voluntary Code in Respect of CPM (`Tar') and Nicotine Labelling on Cigarette Packaging, and an extension of the existing Voluntary Advertising Code for Cigarettes in Australia.
The open scientific literature indicates that the radioactive content of cigarette smoke does not make a significant contribution to the incidence of lung cancer within the general population.

Therefore-and in view of the already very high health risks of smoking-I do not consider a requirement for information about radioactivity to appear in labelling and advertising of tobacco products is warranted. Rather, continuing efforts should be directed to informing people that there is no such thing as a `safe' cigarette and that smoking at any level is harmful to health.
The National Campaign Against Drug Abuse is an important mechanism in this connection.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An investigation has been carried out of the operation of sliding doors at the Brisbane Airport International Terminal.

(2) A complaint was made in writing to the Airport Director by the father of a 10 month old child, that on 11 April 1986 his daughter ``came close to being crushed by the sliding airport doors''. His is the only report received on the incident.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 27 May 1986

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Home and Community Care Program in New South Wales operating out of 10 regional offices to very adequately serve the needs of the elderly throughout that State.

(2) What guarantees has the Minister for Community Services received from his State counterpart to ensure that regional planning is also a feature of the Home and Community Care Program to provide aged care services to all centres of population in Queensland. Given the greater decentralised nature of Queensland with 55 per cent of the population living outside Brisbane.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) While administrative procedures for the Home and Community Care (HACC) Program are jointly approved, day to day administration of the program is the responsibility of State governments.

In New South Wales the administering authority is the Department of Youth and Community Services. Program administration in this state is currently being developed and interim administrative and consultative arrangements have been established. An interim State Advisory Committee, which includes representatives of Commonwealth and State departments as well as service providers and users, will seek to identify local and regional priorities.

Officers of my Department attend meetings of the interim State Advisory Committee, and are involved in assessment of projects and the development of plans at a regional level. Funding proposals are considered jointly.

Program administration is carried out on a regional basis through the Department of Youth and Community Services' ten regional offices. This arrangement permits a careful consideration of regional needs consistent with overall program policy.

(2) The Queensland Government signed the Home and Community Care Agreement on 8 April 1986, and administrative and consultative arrangements are currently being discussed by the Queensland Minister for Health and Environment and myself in order to facilitate improved regional planning and to provide equal access to services for the geographically isolated as well as for other disadvantaged groups.

I am considering administrative proposals submitted by the Queensland Minister which will permit a co-ordinated approach to the operation of the program. While initially regional needs may be identified by State Health officials, the Commonwealth is establishing an interim consultative committee (Interim Commonwealth HACC Advisory Committee) which will include representatives of regional groups who will provide essential information and advice. It is expected that the State Government will also establish a similar committee so as to obtain information and advice from a range of sources.
As in all other states, funding proposals will be jointly considered by Commonwealth and State Officials before being forwarded to the Queensland Minister for Health and myself for joint approval.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 17 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (a) Was any information, made public by TVQ 0 and the Courier Mail in March 1986 regarding illegal drug importation to Brisbane in 1984, known to the Australian Federal Police prior to March 1986, concerning the claimed activities of Telecom employees in the Brisbane metropolitan area.
