QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 8 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations seen the report on outworking in the clothing industry prepared by the Centre for Working Women.

(2) Has the growth of outworking been at the expense of organised factory work, and does it represent unfair competition against those employers prepared to obey industrial awards and fair working and safety standards.
(3) Does the practice of outworking depend on the avoidance of minimum legal wage and conditions standards by employers and the exploitation of workers.
(4) Has this practice been used especially amongst ethnic communities who may be less aware of proper Australian labour practices.
(5) Does the secrecy associated with the practice of outworking encourage taxation fraud.

(6) Does the stated policy of the Liberal Party to ``deregulate'' the labour market amount to the encouragement to employers to adopt similar practices designed to reduce working standards and place unfair competition on established and reputable employers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have seen the Report, ``Women Outworkers'', of the Centre for Working Women Co-operative Limited referred to in the honourable senator's question, and I commend its authors for providing some insights into the working lives of women outworkers, whose own voices are rarely heard.

The Government has for some time been concerned about the growth of home-based employment practices in a variety of industry sectors. In particular, the working conditions of outworkers, as well as other employment issues relating to the clothing industry which have become apparent during the Industry Assistance Commission's inquiry into the textile, clothing and footwear industries, are being monitored by officers of my Department.
I might add, however, that the social context in which outwork is performed and the legal complexities inherent in the situation do not make the task of resolving the problem of outwork an easy one.

(2) There is little in the way of consistent reliable data on the extent and mode of operation of outworking in Australia, nor of the casual effects of the practice on manufacturers and makers-up who observe their legal obligations.

Evidence, in the form of estimates by people thought to be well placed to make such judgements, varies considerably. For example, the lowest estimate of the number of clothing outworkers is 10,000 and was made by the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Council Ltd. A leading clothing manufacturer and retailer, Katies, estimated there to be 30,000, while the NSW Clothing Makers Association put the number as high as 60,000. The Clothing and Allied Trades Union's judgement based on these estimates, is that there would be no less than 30,000 and no more than 60,000 and tends to indicate numbers between 30,000 and 40,000 as being probable.

I am aware, through correspondence with the Confederation of Apparel Manufacturers, that there is concern about unfair competition from outworking. That association is in full accord with the Clothing and Allied Trades Union in seeking to have the area properly regulated.
(3) Unregulated outwork continues to exist and expand despite the limits determined by Federal and State awards and State legislation.
Furthermore, the scope of the jurisdiction under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 for making awards in relation to outworkers has not been conclusively clarified.

In an early case, the High Court held to be invalid an award prohibiting employers from having work done by independent contractors outside their factory or workshop, unless that person was the holder of an outdoor-worker's permit, on the grounds that a dispute between an employer and employee about such a matter was not a dispute about an ``industrial matter'' within the mean of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904. (R v The Judges of the Commonwealth Industrial Court & Ors; Ex parte Cocks v Ors (1968) 121 (LR 313).

More recent High Court decisions have taken a more flexible view on what constitutes an ``industrial matter'' which can be heard by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. This has prompted the Clothing and Allied Trades Union to seek a variation to their award which is currently before the Commission. In the meantime, because of the confused state of the law, neither the Union nor the Arbitration Inspectorate has been able to effectively secure award prescriptions.

(4) Many outworkers are immigrant women of non-English speaking backgrounds and are, therefore, often unaware of any legal entitlements they might have (for example, under the terms of the Victorian Accident Compensation Act 1985 or the NSW Workers Compensation Act 1926) or for other reasons unable to avail themselves of such entitlements. Again, however, specific and comprehensive evidence is difficult to obtain.

(5) Clearly, insufficient regulation and policing of outwork practices can result in fraud and exploitation. Moreover, unregistered outworkers usually receive under-award pay, work in poor conditions, and do not have the benefits of sickness pay, holidays, maternity leave, penalty rates, workers compensation and the like.

(6) While the specifics of operation of the Opposition's industrial relations policy are open to conjecture, it leaves little doubt that the Opposition would reinforce the present system whereby outworkers as ``independent contractors'' would have no effective recourse to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That system has been described by the Apparel Manufacturers Association and others as constituting unfair competition for those employers who are prepared to abide by the spirit as well as the letter of award prescriptions.
Continuing efforts are being made by various bodies and my own Department to regularise outworking practices and to obtain the necessary data for a proper assessment of the situation.

The Victorian Department of Labour (in consultation with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Clothing and Allied Trades Union and the Victorian Trades Hall Council) has under review possible legislative changes for consideration by the Victorian Government.
The Women's Directorate in the NSW Department of Industrial Relations, in co-operation with the NSW Ethnic Affairs Commission, is presently conducting a survey on outworkers in that State.

Also in NSW, a tripartite Committee to Inquire into the Status of Women in Employment in Commerce and Industry, established by the Minister for Industrial Relations and chaired by Ms K. Spooner of the NSW Institute of Technology, will examine outwork, unpaid work, commission selling and award-free areas of work. The Committee is expected to report later this year.

The International Labour Organisation has scheduled for next year the third Tripartite Technical Meeting on the Clothing Industry. Although the draft agenda makes no specific reference to outwork, it is expected that the issue will be discussed in the context of employment in, and training for, the industry.

The National Labour Consultative Council's Committee to Examine Aspects of the Multicultural Workforce has addressed the outwork question in its examination of employment issues relevant to immigrant women. These deliberations are on-going.

The Departments of Labour Advisory Committee's Working Party on Women in the Labour Force has collected information on outwork in the various States and intends to draw together these findings and make recommendations.
In my own Department, the Women's Bureau monitors the expansion of outwork, collects literature and data, and examines the socio-economic factors which lead women to accept this kind of employment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 8 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of comments attributed to rural consultant Mr Bob Pattison of ACIL Australia Pty Ltd to the effect that talk of a ``rural recession'' could be artificially depressing the price of good rural properties.

(2) Does much of the politically inspired talk of disaster serve only to reduce the confidence of financial institutions and investors in our vitally important rural sector at a time when lending and investment support is most needed by farmers.
(3) Does this ``talking down'' of rural land prices hit hardest at small farmers who are in most need of support.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of an article by Mr John Hurst published in the Financial Review of 7 May 1986 which reports comments made by Mr Bob Pattison of ACIL Australia Pty Ltd on the depressing effect talk of a ``rural recession'' could have on the price of rural land.

I am also cognisant that the Prime Minister's country task force in May 1986 reported that farmers were finding that land values had fallen below the long term trend line because expectations were that the short term future in farming was bleak. The task force blamed ``gloom and doom proponents'' for creating this pessimistic outlook.

(2) While many farmers are currently facing very difficult circumstances due to poor international trading conditions, the Government believes Australia's primary industries are versatile and adaptable and generally face a sound future. Loose talk of a crisis does nothing to help agriculture as a whole and particularly those farmers currently facing poor prospects. Instead it may reduce the confidence of financial institutions in rural sector investments at a particularly critical time.

I have had a number of discussions with the banks, which are the major providers of credit to the rural sector. They have assured me that they understand the nature of the rural sector and are willing to be as accommodating as possible in meeting its needs. I would hope other investors share this view.

(3) The Economic Planning Advisory Council's paper ``The Medium-Term Outlook of the Rural Sector'' (Jan. 1986) warns that falling land values are adversly affecting equity levels in some areas. Farmers experiencing the most difficulty in paying their debts and remaining viable in the current situation are those with low incomes and low equity. Both large and small farmers may find themselves in this situation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 May 1986:

(2) Can the Minister advise whether the sales tax also applies to the 3-ply wood imitation Aboriginal artefacts such as boomerangs, which are imported to Australia from South Korea.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Goods manufactured in Australia are subject to sales tax unless they are specifically exempted from the tax. Goods which are exempt from sales tax are listed in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.

Aboriginal artefacts such as boomerangs, spears, did-geridoos and stone axes are not specifically listed in the First Schedule and, when made for sale as souvenirs, they are manufactured goods of a taxable class. The rate of tax applying to Aboriginal artefacts of these kinds is 20%.

However, I have been informed by the Commissioner of Taxation that in the majority of cases artefacts made by Aboriginals for sale as souvenirs qualify for exemption under one of the items in the First Schedule applicable to small manufacturers, particularly item 100. Item 100 provides exemption for goods manufactured and sold by a person where the average annual value of that person's sales of all goods does not exceed $12,000.
(2) Three-ply wood imitation Aboriginal artefacts such as boomerangs, imported into Australia from South Korea, are subject to sales tax at the rate of 20%.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 29 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there any researched reason to believe Australia is being swamped by migrants who are not assimilating, and has the Federal Government put any program in place to monitor this aspect of migration policy, in view of remarks made on 27 May 1986 by Sir Colin Hines, New South Wales President of the Returned Services League, that Sydney suburbs dominated by single ethnic groups are a threat to the traditional Australian lifestyle.
(2) What is the present level of co-operation and research into assimilation problems between the various ethnic groups, the organisations that represent them and the Federal Government.
(3) What are the latest figures of individual ethnic communities now living in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no data known to my Department which would support the view that Australia is being swamped by migrants who are not assimilating nor, for that matter, that migrant numbers are too large. Migrants continue to make a positive contribution to Australian society.

In any event, assimilation is an outdated concept. The Government's multicultural policies recognise the right of ethnic communities to retain their cultural traditions. Migrants for their part, have obligations to abide by Australian laws, live in consonance with the Australian way of life and learn English. This dual process encourages and facilitates integration into our multicultural society, and the development of understanding, tolerance and mutual respect between all of its members.
For this reason, no programs are operating or planned to monitor the extent or rate of ``assimilation'' to any posited ``norm''.

The comments attributed to Sir Colin assume the existence of one ``traditional Australian lifestyle'', which ignores the fact that geographic and social as well as ethnic and cultural diversity have been a feature of Australian society virtually from its inception. While some suburbs in some cities may have an identifiable ethnic character, this also is a continuing feature of the immigration process. Newcomers naturally find comfort and practical assistance in settling initially near other people from the same background. As they become established in Australia, their geographic mobility and their economic and employment profile takes on similar patterns to those of the host society. It is an ongoing process that does not pose a threat to our national character or our Australian social systems.

(2) The level of cooperation between ethnic community structures and their members and the Federal Government remains high. Consultation by means of public or representative meetings about matters of concern takes place as necessary, and Ministerial and official meetings with advocacy organisations such as the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, the Federation of Ethnic Communities' Councils of Australia, it's affiliates, and Ethnic Affairs Commissions regularly explore issues of inter and intra-community relations and other relevant matters of note.

A considerable number of research and review projects have been and continue to be undertaken on the settlement of migrant groups and immigration categories, both by government and academic institutions.

A recent survey done for the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and presented at its National Research Conference in May 1986 dealt with inter-group attitudes and behaviour in Adelaide. This survey showed a clear majority of Australians who were willing to have migrants integrate into Australian life while maintaining their old cultural traditions.

(3) I refer you to Australian Bureau of Statistics bulletin, released in October 1985, entitled ``Estimated Resident Population by Country of Birth and Sex: Australia, June 1983 and 1984''. The data contained in this bulletin are too extensive to be reproduced in Hansard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What payments, by way of aid, were expended in the Philippines for each of the years 1982-83, 1983-84, 1984-85 and 1985-86, for (a) military; (b) civil construction; (c) agricultural; (d) cultural; (e) educational; (f) scientific; (g) trade union; and (h) food aid purposes, and the yearly total of all aid.

(2) Will the Government give consideration to funding the development of democratic institutions in the Philippines and in particular to the encouragement of democratic trade unions, in view of the recent establishment of democratic government in that country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following table sets out Australia's bilateral official development assistance (ODA) to the Philippines for the financial years 1982-83, 1983-84 and 1984-85 in relation to the categories of assistance you specified, apart from defence. The 1985-86 figures are not yet available. Australia does not give ODA to the Philippines for military purposes. Australia and the Philippines maintain a Defence Cooperation Program (DCP) for which the Minister for Defence is responsible. None of the Australia/ Philippines DCP activity is, however, classified as ODA.
AUSTRALIAN BILATERAL ODA TO THE PHILIPPINES BY SECTOR OF DESTINATION

(2) The Australian Government has welcomed the measures taken by the Aquino Government to restore democratic institutions in the Philippines, including a commitment to respect for human and political rights. A Constitutional Commission, which will draft a new constitution, began its deliberations on 2 June.

The Australian Government attaches importance to the development of trade unionism in a democratic framework. In 1984-85 the Government contributed $4,000 to training provided by the Trade Union Training Authority (see above Table). During his visit to the Philippines from 23 to 29 June, Mr Hayden offered additional access to training programs in Australia for Trade Union officials from the Philippines, possibly within the context of our aid program. President Aquino expressed interest.

It is not the policy of the Australian Government, however, to impose political conditions on the aid it provides to the Philippines and other developing countries. Australian aid is not designed to change the political systems of recipient countries. Rather, Australia gives aid primarily for humanitarian reasons to alleviate poverty through economic and social development. By contributing to the social and economic advancement of the people of the Philippines, including the poorest and most deprived sectors of the community, the Australian Government believes its aid will play a positive role in the reform process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 30 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council increased its interview rate by 56 percent over a 5 year period and is now in the position of having long waiting lists for its services, particularly in underfunded country towns.
(2) What special provisions are being made to put greater emphasis on funding of counselling services to prevent marital breakdown.

(3) Has the Attorney-General taken action to implement the recommendation of the National Marriage Guidance Council in conducting a comprehensive inquiry into Government policy affecting marriage support services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney- General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The statistical returns lodged by the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council up until and including the 1984/85 year indicate that the interview load of the agency increased by 57 percent between 1980/81 and 1984/85 and the Council has reported that it has long waiting lists. The Council being an autonomous body is reponsible for the allocation of funds to its various country branches from the income it receives from Commonwealth grants and contributions from clients.

(2) The marriage counselling organizations which are approved and receive financial assistance under the Family Law Act 1975 provide a counselling service directed to assisting people entering, living within or leaving marriage to resolve interpersonal difficulties affecting their relationships. One of the consequences of this work can rightly be claimed to be the prevention or marital breakdown and the increase in 17 percent in Commonwealth funding to the organizations in 1985/86 is indicative of the support of Government for the services provided.

(3) In order that I may be in a better position to decide whether I should lend support to an inquiry as suggested, I have asked the Institute of Family Studies to include in its research program a project to measure the role and effectiveness of marriage counselling and education. The Institute plans to conduct the study during 1986/87.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Queensland Government approached the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations in March 1986 for discussions concerning Commonwealth assistance for nurse refresher training.

(2) Yes. The question of ``substantial contribution'' by the States was clarified in a letter I sent to the Queensland Minister for Health earlier this year and was also explained to senior officers of the Queensland Department of Health by officers of my Department. It is anticipated that Queensland will submit a proposal to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations in the near future.

(3) The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations welcomes proposals aimed at encouraging registered nurses to return to the workforce. There is no in-principle objection to the Queensland Department of Health developing refresher course proposals in co-operation with the private health industry. Any such proposal would be considered in light of established guidelines and it is expected that the Queensland Nurses' Union would have been actively involved in the course development process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What amount of moneys have been spent by Federal and State Governments in projects in any way related to uranium mining in each of the last 10 years in Australia. (See answer to Question on Notice No. 1015, Hansard, 30 May 1986, p. 3131.)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth has certain responsibilities concerning the regulation of uranium mining in Australia. The resources used in meeting its obligations, which include rehabilitation of old mines, are spread over a range of Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities and, because of the diversity and independence of their functions, it is not practicable to prepare details of expenditure related specifically to uranium mining incurred by each of them. However, expenditure relating to uranium mining which has been incurred by the following specific organisations and functions has been identified to the extent possible and is set out below. These amounts would, I believe, account for the bulk of the Commonwealth's direct expenditure in this area.
I am not aware of the amount of money expended by State or Northern Territory Governments on uranium mining.
1. Expenditure by AAEC which has been identified as being directly related to uranium mining, including its share of the Ranger project between 1978 and 1981 (see note below).

2. The activities of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region are not entirely directed towards uranium mining. However, only the total expenditure of the Office of the Supervising Scientist is available.
3. Payments for NT Regulatory Services were absorbed into tax sharing arrangements with the Northern Territory in 1981/82.

The proceeds from the divestment by AAEC of its uranium interests in Ranger and Ngalia Basin in 1980/81 plus dividend and capital repayments from Mary Kathleen Uranium Ltd have exceeded its expenditure on uranium mining. In addition to the AAEC being reimbursed for its expenditure on the Ranger project, the Commonwealth received a further $146 million in respect of the sale of its interests in the Ranger project in 1979/80.

Payments, by the Commonwealth for the Ranger Assessor, to the Northern Territory in lieu of uranium royalties and to the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account are recovered from the mining companies and are not a net cost to the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister for State, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the National Crime Authority examined the matters covered in recommendation 10 009 of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union concerning the provision of the data base (excluding material derived from taxation records) to the Australian Federal Police, the Victorian Police Force and the Victorian Commissioner of Corporate Affairs; if so, does the National Crime Authority support the views expressed by Mr Costigan in this recommendation; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The National Crime Authority has informed me that the database compiled by the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union has since been substantially modified in line with the operational needs of the Authority.

The Authority has examined the needs of other law enforcement agencies for access to the material on its database pursuant to paragraph 11 (1) (a) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984. On-line access is not provided, but material (including data originating from the Costigan Royal Commission database) is being passed to the relevant authorities in three ways, viz:
(a) upon direct request for specific information;
(b) following a decision by the Authority to refer an investigation or information to another agency, rather than investigate further itself; and
(c) as investigations are concluded, material is passed to the relevant prosecuting authority.

In deciding against on-line access, the Authority took into consideration the need for security, particularly as regards information supplied to the Authority on a confidential basis by law enforcement agencies and others, and the importance of minimising the circulation of untested criminal intelligence.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Waterfront Security and Security of Air Cargo

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has the Government since taken to improve waterfront security and the existing arrangements for the security of air cargo as the Government promised in its response to recommendation 10 015 of the Costigan Royal Commission on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.
(2) Is the Government now satisfied, in the light of recent importation of drugs and other illegal substances, that the recommendation should be carried out; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The matter of waterfront security is one for joint Commonwealth and State consideration. The Australian Police Ministers' Council (APMC) has examined both the Costigan recommendation and the report of the Joint Task Force on the Security of Wharves and Containers. In May 1986 the APMC resolved to establish separate State Port Security Committees to carry out functions determined according to each State's needs. The heads of each Committee will meet as necessary to discuss matters of national concern and to provide a forum for development of national policies. The Victorian Government has already established the Victorian Port Security Advisory Unit as an intelligence and information gathering agency.

The matter of air cargo security is under review by a Central Steering Committee chaired by the Department of the Special Minister of State and comprising the Department of Aviation, the Australian Customs Service, the Australian Federal Police and State and Northern Territory police forces.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force: New Aircraft

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was it stated in the Journal of the Institution of Engineers of 7 March 1986, by Stan Schaetzel that Hawker De Havilland (HDH) provided a fixed price bid of $184.1 million to cover completion of the development program, certification and delivery of 69 aircraft to the RAAF as well as the private development of the A20 aircraft.
(2) Was the competing bid from Pilatus $240 million for the PC9; if so, was this $55.9 million greater than the Australian aircraft.

(3) Why was the HDH bid increased by some $86 million when a fixed price bid of $184.1 million was offered (including the development of the A20) causing the Pilatus offer to become apparently $30 million cheaper.
(4) What sort of guarantee has been given by Pilatus to the Australian Government with regard to meeting the rated 8,000 hr fatigue life stipulated by the RAAF.
(5) Is this relevant when indications are that the PC-7 and PC-9 do not have the fatigue life when operated under the environment in the RAAF as required by the A10B Specifications.

(6) Is the PC-9 Pilatus an advanced, high performance trainer (not a basic trainer), overlapping the current Macchi syllabus to a large degree, and not particularly suitable for basic primary training.

(7) How can the Minister for Defence endorse the resultant 3 trainer aircraft fleet, with all its associated maintenance/spares/specialised personnel, when the much cheaper A10B was originally designed to do all the work of the CT-4 and some work of the Macchi jet trainer.

(8) How did the Minister derive the claimed $20 million yearly saving by buying the Pilatus PC-9 when the project has already cost the Australian taxpayer $94 million and a three (3) aircraft fleet will be far more expensive to maintain that the original Australian A10B/Macchi two aircraft fleet.
(9) What specific elements of the PC-9 will be re- designed and developed in Australian conditions if the Labor Government continues to buy this Swiss aircraft.

(10) Why isn't the PC-9 Pilatus simply replacing the CT-4 primary trainer aircraft as would have happened had the Minister authorised the continuation of the much cheaper Australian designed and built A10B basic training aircraft.

(11) Is the Swiss PC-9 too dangerous for first up pilots to fly and does it not have adequately designed under-carriage to meet the strength requirements of a high sink rate landing normally associated with first up pilots during basic training (Refer Interavia 7/1985).

(12) Why is the Minister trying to make the Australian Industry pay for the hardware purchased and produced during the A10B project, when the Department of Defence and the Labor Cabinet has scrapped the whole project.

(13) To what extent and value specifically has the Minister insisted that the Pilatus provide work for the considerable design teams, as consolidated by the Australian Aerospace Industry Companies (AAC) and the HDH, given that the envisaged Pilatus projects will concern mainly production personnel with very little Australian Design Engineering input.
(14) Will the PC-9 Pilatus undergo modifications, so as to meet any of the original RAAF specifications so rigidly enforced on industry with the A10B trainer, such as:
(a) rough field capability and not just grass field capability as proposed by the Minister.
(b) Environmental Control System to cope with prevailing Australian weather conditions.
(c) birdstrike proof windscreen.

(15) If modifications are going to occur, is the Minister insisting that they be carried out by Design teams in Australia and not in Switzerland by the Swiss as indicated by the RAAF Director-General of the Trainer Project Air Commodore Bob Kee in the Australian Aircraft magazine of February 1986.
(16) Will a full set of jigs for Pilatus PC-9 be made in Switzerland and shipped out to Australia as indicated by Air Commodore Bob Kee and Minister for Defence.
(17) Could these jigs be made in Australia if the PC-9 aircraft goes ahead.
(18) Is the Minister still insisting that this work arrangement for the Australian Aerospace workers is being adhered to.

(19) How is the RAAF able to claim that the Pilatus PC-9 is able to be used for weapons training in the future when Swiss federal law forbids Swiss companies from selling equipment to outside countries that can be used for war or training for war.

(20) Why were the three (3) partner companies in the AAC allowed to spend many costly manhours perfecting many of the complex systems required by the original A10B specification (formerly Wamira), in full and constant collaboration with the RAAF, when that same specification was then immediately relaxed and ignored (by the RAAF) when the PC-7 and PC-9 were included in the selection process.
(21) How did the Minister and the RAAF arrive at the figure of $20 million per year quoted as potential savings by the introduction of the PC-9, with regard to the current RAAF training philosophy.

(22) If, as indicated by the RAAF and Auditor-General, the Minister was aware of the cost and schedule overruns on the A10B project (formerly Wamira), why did he not step in earlier to get the project back ``on the rails'' as HDH did in mid to late '85, and thereby save this important National project.

(23) Did the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) state in ``Flight International, Jan. '86'': ``Government has an important role to play in the creation of a secure policy frame-work that will facilitate growth''; if so, how can the Minister for Defence defend this statement, when he was instrumental in effectively killing the Industry's design; capability by aborting the A10B and A20 projects.

(24) How will the Government and in particular the Minister reconcile these additional costs in primary training, when the PC-9, as an advanced aircraft, will itself cost vast sums to adopt it to existing RAAF usage.
(25) Did the Minister claim in the Defence Industry Newsletter (22 January 1986) that offset programs could offer a considerable amount of additional design work.

(26) Is the indigenous design content effectively zero and manufacturing will not employ large numbers of Australian workers as the A10B/A20 combination project would have, particularly in the Design and Development field.

(27) Why is the Minister and RAAF urgently wanting to bring the PC-9 into service particularly when Australian Industry showed through testing in 1985 that the CT-4 has a conservative life extension through until 1995 and the Macchi until 2000.

(28) Why doesn't the Minister stop the PC-9 purchase in the light of (27) above and save the Government at least $270 million and authorise the following steps to get the Australian Aerospace Industry back into developing what they do well, that is, design, development and manufacture of aircraft and aircraft systems.
(29) Will the Minister give consideration to:
(a) restarting the A10B project only to the original requirement of building, testing and flying the (4) four A10B aircraft.
(b) spending the money saved on the PC-9 on the immediate start of (4) four P-3 AEW aircraft in conjunction with Lockheed Aircraft Company.
(c) spending the money saved on the PC-9 on the immediate start to fitting out the fleet of 707 RAAF transport aircraft for the flight refuelling in support of F/A-18 and F-111 aircraft.

(30) Is the Minister's statement in Defence Industry Newsletter 22 January 1986 that ``all that was left on the A10 as regards design work was fine tuning'' and ``only required 680 hours work including flight testing'' misleading.
(31) Will $94 million be wasted unless the testing on the A10B is completed and the Design is verified.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In his article published in the Journal of the Institute of Engineers on 7 March 1986, Mr Schaetzel stated that ``HDH provided a fixed-price bid of $184.1 million to cover the completion of the development program, certification and delivery of 69 aircraft''. HDH also indicated that, should the Commonwealth elect to proceed with the A10B aircraft, the Company would fund the development of the A20 as a private venture.
(2) The estimated total project cost for the Pilatus PC-9 was $240 million and this was some $30 million less than the estimated total project cost for the Australian aircraft.

(3) The HDH bid for completion of the A10 was not increased. However, that bid of $184.1 million did not represent the total project cost, which always includes the cost of support necessary to place the aircraft in service.
(4) In its formal tender to the Australian Government Pilatus has guaranteed an 8000 hr fatigue life for the aircraft.
(5) The guarantee provided by Pilatus recognises the RAAF operating environment in the same way as did the A10 specification, and the RAAF has no indications of inadequacies.

(6) The PC-9 is a Basic Trainer which, although possessing a higher performance than that of the A10, is nonetheless suitable for basic primary training and has been so assessed by specialist RAAF flying instructors.

(7) A three trainer aircraft fleet (CT-4/PC-9/Macchi) will not necessarily be more costly in operating and overhead costs than would have been the A10B/Macchi combination, and noting that one new aircraft is to be introduced in both cases, the overall cost of training will depend upon the distribution of flying hours between the three aircraft (the CT-4 being cheaper to operate than the PC-9 and the PC-9 cheaper than the Macchi). In this regard a major advantage of the PC-9 derives from its higher performance and flexibility within the training system.

(8) See the previous answer. The savings achieved by comparison with the present arrangements or the previously proposed A10B/Macchi combination would depend upon the number of flying hours that could be transferred from the Macchi to the PC-9 while retention of the CT-4 would allow that much cheaper aircraft to be used for the early stages of the flying training syllabus. The actual savings to be achieved will depend upon the pilot throughput and on the distribution of flying hours between the three aircraft types. That saving could amount to some $20 million annually. Expenditure achieved against the Australian design has been limited to $74 million. The project cost estimates for completion of the A10B and for the PC-9 excluded this cost as ``sunk'' to give the A10B the best chance for continuation. This figure is not relevant to the question of savings to be made in the pilot training system through introduction of the PC-9 aircraft.

(9) There will be no significant re-design of the PC-9 for Australian use. However the aircraft will be fitted with low-pressure tyres to permit operation from grassed surfaces. That modification is relatively minor and will be developed by Pilatus.

(12) The Commonwealth has transferred, free of charge, the design rights for the A10 to Hawker de Havillands. The Hardware that was acquired and produced at the Taxpayers' expense during the A10 project is Commonwealth property and the Government cannot merely turn it over to Australian industry free of charge. The Commonwealth has, however, agreed to dispose of those items and hardware to industry at a very nominal cost. We understand these conditions are entirely acceptable to the industry.

(13) The terms of the Commonwealth's invitation to Pilatus to tender for licensed manufacture of the PC-9 required that Company to provide opportunity for Australian industry to participate in collaborative design and development work. Pilatus has honoured that obligation and has made an offer to Australian industry to join in the design and development of a new aircraft on a 50-50 cost sharing basis. It will be for industry to decide whether or not it takes up that offer.
(14) See answer (9) above. However, such modifications were assessed at the time of the evaluation of A10B and PC-9 costs to provide a more equitable basis of comparison.

(16) and (17) The intention of HDH and the Commonwealth is that to the maximum extent possible, jigs and tooling for the PC-9 will be made in Australia. It is recognised that the scale of the production might not warrant local manufacture of some small numbers of special tooling, in which case these would be acquired from Pilatus.
(18) Yes, presuming the arrangement referred to is that outlined in my press statement 205/86 dated 16 December 1985.
(19) Swiss Federal Law would not prevent Australia from using the PC-9 for weapons training for its own purposes.

(20) The original Wamira A10 project was based on assessments that benefit would flow from the Australian aerospace industry demonstrating that it could design and develop an aircraft to Military Specifications and from the export potential of some of the features of the aircraft. While it was recognised that this would involve a cost premium it was not until the design was well advanced that the likely full extent of that premium became apparent. The relaxation of specifications for the trainer completion was of benefit to the HDH A10B as well as the PC-7 and PC-9.

(22) When it became apparent in late 1984 that the trainer program was exceeding the expected cost and was falling behind schedule by a considerable amount, the Government took action. In seeking ways of allowing the project to proceed during the period to December 1985, the Government took full account of its importance.

(23) The quotation from Flight International January 1986 is accurate and the position stated is supported by the Minister for Defence. The Government does not accept the assertion that in terminating the A10 project it was effectively killing the industry's design capability.
(25) Yes, and the recent helicopter contracts support that view.

(26) Noting answer (9) above, there is very little indigenous design content in the PC-9. Manufacturing workload however will be comparable to that promised by the A10 noting that significant components of both aircraft are imported (eg engines, avionics) and subject to offsets. Note also answer (13).

(27) The Government and the RAAF wish to introduce the PC-9 as early as possible in order to achieve the potential for savings in operating costs through relieving the Macchi jet trainer of much of its workload and thereby extending the service life of that aircraft.
(29) (a) No. (b) and (c) those projects are being examined on their merits for priority in the Defence program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 11 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the Department of Community Services introduce realistic benefits for disabled couples living independently in the community.
(2) What is the future of the National Attendant Care Program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is aware of the need to provide a realistic level of support for people, who require help if they are to be able to remain living in their own homes. In 1984/85 the Government introduced the Home and Community Care Program (HACC) which aims to provide a comprehensive range of basic maintenance and support services to frail aged and disabled people of all ages living in the community, as well as their carers, in order to help maintain their independence and to prevent their premature admission to long term residential care. A wide range of services can be provided under the HACC Program including home nursing, home help and paramedical services. HACC services are to be provided within the community by State Government organisations, local government or non-profit community organisations.

In addition, my Department currently pays domiciliary nursing care benefits in recognition of the additional costs experienced by relatives in caring for other relatives, who may include disabled couples in the home. The current rate of $42 a fortnight per person cared for is paid to approved persons who choose to care at home for chronically ill or disabled relatives aged 16 years or over who would otherwise require admission to a nursing home. It was never intended to cover the full cost of home care but rather to provide a degree of recognition and financial assistance for approved persons providing such care.
(2) This is a matter for consideration in the forthcoming budget.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 11 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How will the Department of Health respond to a recent report by Dr Allan Forbes of the United States Food and Drug Administration which is reputed to confirm that sugar is harmless.
(2) Has the Department of Health sought copies of his report which has found that there is-
(a) no conclusive evidence that dietary sugars were an independent risk factor for heart disease;
(b) no evidence linking sugar consumption to gallstone;
(c) no unique role for sugar in making people overweight; and
(d) no evidence that sugar intake contributes to hypertension.
(3) When will the Health Department assess these findings and amend its literature accordingly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Officers of my Department see no need to respond to the recent paper by Dr Allan Forbes of the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) since this was a review of an earlier report, the conclusions of which they are in agreement with-namely that sugar (sucrose) is a safe ingredient for incorporation into foods, but that at high levels of intake, especially as part of snack-type foods, it may pose a hazard to dental health.
(2) Yes. My Department has sought a copy of Dr Forbes' full paper. At this time it is not yet available. Preliminary advice received from FDA in Washington is as follows:

Dr Forbes' paper was presented at a meeting in the United Kingdom. It is a review of an earlier FDA report which looked at sugar in the American diet from a regulatory point of view. This earlier report was an evaluation, conducted on behalf of FDA, of the safety aspects of sucrose as a food additive or ingredient. It was published in 1976. For regulatory purposes, sugar (sucrose) was given GRAS-that is Generally Recognised As Safe-status. This status has been reaffirmed since then. The FDA report considered sugar in this safety context only.
(3) The Department of Health has already assessed Dr Forbes' observations and sees no need to amend its literature. It has never claimed that
(a) dietary sugars are an independent risk factor for heart disease;
(b) there is evidence linking sugar consumption to gallstones;
(c) there is a unique role for sugar in making people overweight; or

The Department of Health, like its counterparts in the United States and many other countries, will continue to recommend that overall sugar consumption in Australia be reduced-especially as a component of `snack' foods and beverages. Excessive intake (levels consumed by many Australians) is a contributing factor to (1) the development of dental caries, (2) the displacement of more nutritious foods which significantly reduces intake of essential minerals and vitamins and (3) the development of overweight in many individuals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 11 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the future success of the Federal Government's Aged Care Program, Home and Community Care, being placed in serious jeopardy because the Queensland Government is refusing to allow equal participation of community organisations in advising on priorities for its implementation.

(2) What steps can the Minister for Community Services take to guarantee that aged care services initiated through the Home and Community Care Program will be delivered on the same basis in Queensland as in every other State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One of the principles of the Home and Community Care Program is joint Commonwealth/State decision making in consultation with service providers and users. The Commonwealth wishes to see mechanisms established which give service providers and users an effective on-going role in assessment of priorities and identification of existing services. The Queensland Government signed the Home and Community Care Agreement on 8 April 1986, and administrative and consultative arrangements are being discussed between the Queensland Minister for Health and the Environment and myself. These arrangements, which include the role of service providers in implementing the Home and Community Care Program, will be jointly agreed by the State and the Commonwealth.

(2) In Queensland, as in all other States/Territories applications for grants will be assessed against priorities under the Program, their relative merits and funds available. Joint approval of projects to receive funding will be given by the State Minister and myself. Day-to-day administration of the Program will be the responsibility of the State Government under agreed program guidelines.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 11 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is as disclosed to Senate Estimates Committee E on 17 September, 1985, the 800 short tons of uranium yellowcake purchased by the Commonwealth Government from Queensland Mines, in lieu of its being sold to France, currently stored in galvanised drums with only tarpaulins as a protective cover.

(2) Will the Government give an assurance that this inadequate and potentially dangerous storage of uranium yellowcake be investigated and changed, given the response of the particular public servant, who was being questioned, that ``there is not a great deal of experience as yet in keeping such material in drums in that environment''.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The uranium concentrates purchased from Queensland Mines Ltd (QML) are stored at the Nabarlek mine within a locked compound located inside QML's storage compound. The concentrates are contained in steel drums coated with a protective paint inside and out to meet contractual specifications. The drums are stacked on pallets with sufficient room between them for adequate ventilation and the stack of drums is covered with a tarpaulin for additional protection from the weather.

(2) The response referred to by the Honourable Senator indicated that the integrity of the drums and their contents should be maintained for at least five years. The packing and storage of the concentrates has been inspected by an officer of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission on behalf of the Commonwealth and the arrangements were found to be satisfactory. Moreover, the stack and its drums are subject to regular inspection by the Australian Safeguards Office to ensure that the material meets the requirements of that Office as far as its physical safety and condition are concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 11 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the sliding doors at Brisbane International Airport pass by a steel wall support when they open.
(2) Is it possible when the doors open that a person standing close to the sliding glass panel beside the doorway could be struck with great force and injured.

(3) Has the Minister for Aviation been made aware of an incident which occurred recently when a small child who had crawled up to the sliding glass panelling adjacent to the doors was in danger of being crushed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 June 1986:
