ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 13 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has the CSIRO taken to concentrate its resources in accordance with the priorities set down in the booklet `Shaping the Future'-A Strategy for CSIRO 1985-90.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Concentration of CSIRO research effort on topics of greatest importance and promise is being achieved through the introduction of formal corporate planning procedures. Division and Institute plans are drawn up in consultation with potential users and through Divisional advisory committees. The planning process also incorporates measures such as the designation by the Executive of ``growth areas'' based on advice from Institute Directors. These are areas of particular priority to which a special allocation or redeployment of resources is applied. Currently special priority is accorded information technology, generic manufacturing technologies, water resources research, space science and technology, plant diseases and human nutrition. In addition the research areas biotechnology and materials science are protected from resources contraction. Termination or contraction of some programs is necessary in order to release resources for redeployment to higher priority areas.
The completed plans are now being brought together in a corporate strategic plan outlining the Organization's research priorities on a sectoral basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the New Submarine Program predicated on the first new boat going into service in 1991.

(2) Is the New Submarine Program on schedule, and will the Oberon boats be phased out according to the announced schedule, or is it now considered that some of the Oberon class boats will need refits because of delays in the New Submarine Program.
(3) Will such unbudgeted work, because of delays, be treated as a new expenditure item, or will the costs be debited against the already seriously inflated budget for the new submarine.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Following the Government's decision to construct all the new submarines in Australia, the Project Definition Study Contractors have been asked to develop proposals for the construction based on the most cost effective delivery schedule, whilst maximising Australian Industry Involvement within the constraints of practicability and cost. The final proposals will be lodged on 11 November this year and only after full evaluation of these proposals would a definite date for delivery of the first submarine be available.

(2) The New Submarine Program is on schedule. The Oberon boats will be phased out of service progressively to match the introduction of the new submarines into RAN service. There is no foreseen requirement to extend the life of the Oberons beyond that already planned.
(3) No unbudgeted work is presently planned or foreseen for the Oberon Class submarines. The New Submarine Project remains within budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 November 1985 (Hansard, page 2601) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the Government's and the Department of Health's activities in relation to monitoring the use of high technology equipment, particularly the use of the extracorporeal shock wave lithotripter machine. The Minister for Health has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As ESWL is a treatment for a specific medical condition (upper urinary tract stones) there is considerably less scope for financial abuse and manipulation through over-servicing than with diagnostic procedures. However, as each ESWL unit has an installed capital cost of approximately $3.7 million, and annual running (ESWL) costs of more than $1 million, there is a clear need for control of the technology's proliferation.

The National Health Technology Assessment Panel which is made up of representatives from Commonwealth and State governments, the private sector and the medical profession, reported on ESWL in June 1985. It recommended that ``on the basis of current numbers of procedures for upper urinary tract stones, not more than three ESWL machines would be needed for Australia, two of which should be located in Sydney and Melbourne.''

The issue of the siting and numbers of ESWL units has been raised with all State Health Ministers and, in accordance with the recommendations of the NHTAP report, the Commonwealth has offered to contribute toward the capital cost of an ESWL unit in both Sydney and Melbourne. While the Commonwealth's offer has not yet been formally accepted, the New South Wales and Victorian governments are both proceeding with the purchase and installation of an ESWL unit. These two units will be sited in public hospitals and should be operational this year.

A medicare benefit of $380 has been established for the professional services associated with an ESWL procedure. The Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia (VHIAA) is considering the provision of a private health fund benefit to cover the non-professional operating costs of private patients who receive ESWL treatment.

Hospital Corporation of Australia has established a private ESWL unit at the Charles Wentworth Private Hospital in the western suburbs of Sydney. It is, however, unlikely that proliferation of the technology will occur without the financial support of capital costs either by governments or the private health insurance industry. The Commonwealth government, State governments and the VHIAA have all indicated their support for the NHTAP's recommendations for the planned introduction of this expensive technology.
The Department of Health is currently undertaking a review of overall policies relating to the introduction of high cost health technologies to Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 February 1986 (Hansard, page 265), Senator Parer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that the 3 per cent productivity increase included in the accord mark 2 is based on Australian Council of Trade Union determinations? If not, on what basis has the Government determined this increase? How can this figure be predetermined before a case has even been considered by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? Does the Government consider that itself and the ACTU are in contempt by pre-empting any decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in respect of a 3 per cent productivity increase which would cost in the order of $4 billion to $6 billion?
In my reply, I undertook to refer the question to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

No. In August 1985 the Australian Council of Trade Unions lodged a claim with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission under Principle 2, National Productivity, of the National Wage Principle then in operation, seeking a 4 per cent increase in wages and salaries or conditions of employment.
``Upon application, and not before 1985, the Commission will consider whether an increase in wages and salaries or changes in conditions of employment should be awarded on account of productivity.''

On 4 September 1985, it was announced that the Government and the ACTU had reached an agreement under the Accord to accommodate the effects of the depreciation of the Australian dollar which occurred in early 1985 and to ensure a continuation of wage restraint for a further two years. The agreement provided for a discount of 2 per cent from the wage indexation increases to apply in the February-May 1986 National Wage Case. It also provided for a moderation in the ACTU's productivity claim and that the Government and the ACTU would propose to the Commission that an increase equivalent to 3 per cent of ordinary time earnings be awarded as contributions to occupational superannuation schemes.

These proposals were put to the Commission during hearings early in 1986. The advance quantification of claims argued before the Commission in National Wage proceedings is standard procedure and does not pre-empt the Commission's decision in any way. It always remains for the Commission to decide whether any, and if so what, increase should be awarded.

On 26 June 1986 the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission handed down its decision on the national productivity/superannuation claim. In view of the present economic circumstances, the Commission decided that productivity growth for the next two years should, as far as possible, be directed towards lowering Australia's inflation rate relative to that of her trading partners. Therefore, it declined to arbitrate to provide for superannuation, as sought by the ACTU's claim, during the life of the current wage fixation principles.

However, the Commission noted that negotiations and understandings on superannuation were proceeding in the field and there was considerable merit in the public interest in monitoring and regulating any agreements which might be entered into, and in assisting by conciliation.

The Commission also acknowledged that there is some scope to implement the ACTU's superannuation claim. It took the historic step of award prescription of superannuation but favoured this occurring by way of consent between employers and unions. It decided that, pursuant to section 28 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904, it will certify agreements or make consent awards which provide for employer contributions to approved superannuation schemes provided that the cost ceiling of a wage increase equivalent of 3 per cent of ordinary time earnings is not exceeded and that employers genuinely consent to the payment.

The Commission also decided that no agreement providing for superannuation in accordance with its decision should operate before 1 January 1987 except in special and isolated circumstances approved by the Commission. A special Full Bench of the Commission will control the speed of implementation of the various agreements including the dates of operation in order that the economy does not become overloaded.

The Commission also made it a condition for award prescription that superannuation contributions only be made to those schemes which meet the Government's Operational Standards for Occupational Superannuation Schemes, announced by the Treasurer on 11 June 11986.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Trojan Owen and Associates Pty Ltd

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 March 1986 (Hansard, page 1089), Senator Jessop asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question without notice concerning the involvement of the company Trojan Owen and Associates Pty Ltd in community employment program projects. I undertook to seek further information from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

ANSWER.PARA: Current CEP guidelines make provisions for sponsors to engage consultants to manage their projects. Payment is on a fee for service basis with such fees being met from the sponsor contribution to the project.

I am not aware of any instances where Trojan Owen and Associates has received preferential treatment by, or privileged information from, my Department. Project sponsors seeking information about management consultants in South Australia are referred by the CEP Secretariat to a comprehensive register of consultants including Trojan Owen and Associates and a number of other consultants have in fact been used by sponsors. The high level of Trojan Owen involvement in CEP is quite reasonably explained by the company's active role in lobbying sponsors, and its high public profile as a specialist in the management of job creation projects.

I am advised that the Department's CEP Management Information System cannot readily identify consultants' involvement in projects. In view of this, the following information has been prepared using the knowledge of the Department's State Office CEP personnel.
Their advice is that Trojan Owen and Associates has been involved in 14 approved CEP projects in South Australia, and 6 approved CEP projects in Victoria.

Of these projects, 4 commenced under the previous Government's Wage Pause Program and were unable to be completed prior to that Program's completion date. They were subsequently converted to CEP projects. In addition, 3 other projects were approved under the Wage Pause Program and completed with Wage Pause funding.
The details sought in relation to CEP projects with which Trojan Owen and Associates have been involved are as follows:
Adelaide Central Mission Redevelopment of Mission House...
Development of Public, Administration and Club Facilities *...
Onkaparinga Estuary Conservation and Development, Aquatic and Bowls Clubrooms...
Conservation and Development of Morialta Conservation Park...
* Projects commenced under the Wage Pause Program

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 May 1986 (Hansard, page 2182), Senator Michael Baume asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question without notice regarding the Sydney premises of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Senator Baume asked:

ANSWER.PARA: What will be the cost in both capital and annual leasing expenses of the proposed move of the Sydney Operations of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission from the AGC Building in the legal centre of Sydney out to new premises at Woolloomooloo? How much has been spent on improvements, renovations and fittings for and what is the leasing cost of the present area now occupied by the Arbitration Commission in Sydney in each financial year of that occupancy? What will be the total cost of the move? Was this move initiated by the Arbitration Commission itself? If not, who did initiate it and what is the attitude of the Arbitration Commission to this forced move to an inconvenient location?

In my reply I undertook to convey Senator Baume's question to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The capital cost associated with the relocation of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission from the Law Courts Building in Queens Square, Sydney, to new premises at 80 William Street, Sydney, is $6,455,000. The annual leasing cost is $2,714,345.

The Law Courts Building is jointly owned by the Federal and State Governments. Accordingly there are no leasing costs. Since the Commission moved there in 1977, no major improvements or renovations have been completed. Fittings formed part of the original construction cost of the building.
The total cost of the move comprises the above capital and annual leasing expenses, plus $2,030,000 for furniture and fittings, and stocking the library.

The former President of the Commission, Sir John Moore, sought alternative accommodation because of the shortage of accommodation for Members of the Commission in the Law Courts Building. Because of cost considerations, suitable premises could not be found in close proximity to the current premises. Following a detailed evaluation the building currently under construction at 80 William Street was found to be suitable. Some members of the Commission have expressed concern about the proposed location outside the central business district and security aspects associated with the premises. The security matters have now been resolved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 May 1986 (Hansard, page 2618), Senator Crichton-Browne asked me a question without notice concerning the time taken to process applications for the tertiary education assistance scheme in the Western Australian office of my Department. I also undertook to investigate the circumstances of a particular case which he mentioned. The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As far as TEAS processing is concerned, most applicants in Western Australia this year would have received their first payment of allowance within three weeks of their applications being received by the Western Australian Office of my Department. Where the application was incomplete or more information had to be obtained by writing to the applicant, processing time was longer, as might be expected. However most cases where this occurred were finalized in less than two months of the application first being received. Processing could take up to three months in some cases, but these would be quite exceptional and would normally be caused by delay on the part of the applicant in furnishing information essential for assessment.

Senator Crichton-Browne's Office has provided the Western Australian Office of my Department with the name of the student referred to in his question, and the case has been investigated. That particular application was lodged on 7 March and advice was sent to the student on 21 March that additional information was required before independent status could be approved. The additional information needed was supplied by the applicant on 8 April. Reassessment was initated almost immediately, but it then proved necessary to approach the educational institution regarding course details. The student was finally advised that benefits were approved in a letter dated 24 April. The first payment would have been received at the end of April. The whole process was thus completed in under two months, and did not involve a delay of more than three months as asserted in the Senator's question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 May 1986 (Hansard, page 3110), Senator Black asked me a question without notice concerning the reported practice of a Gold Coast-based company which was alleged to have used a system of fines to discipline employees who committed offences such as being late for meetings, saying anything negative and fraternising with employees of the opposite sex. Senator Black asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister say whether abuses of power such as this would be more prevalent under the coalition's industrial relations policy as it includes a system of individual agreements which would be virtually impossible to police?
The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Enquiries by officers of my Department indicate that the employment practice outlined in the Brisbane Courier-Mail of 28 May 1986 has been adopted by the employer concerned.

There is no doubt that implementation of the Opposition's industrial relations policy, which contemplates the progressive use of supposed voluntary agreements between employers and employees, initially in enterprises with 50 or fewer employees, would create an environment conducive to the exploitation of those least able to defend themselves as has happened in the case quoted.

Employers who wished to profit at the expense of others where competition for available jobs exist would be able to arbitrarily determine work practices and conditions of employment on a take it or leave it basis. The social implications of such a system for our society defy imagination.

Capacity exists in the present industrial relations system for the certification by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of memoranda of agreement by the parties to an industrial dispute. The Opposition's proposals regarding supposed voluntary agreements disregard the public policy issues which are comprehended in the use of an orderly system of wage fixation.

The fact that an instance such as that quoted can occur despite the mechanisms presently in place highlights what would happen if the conditions of employment relationships were based on a free market situation. Those most disadvantaged in the community would be further exploited and it would be difficult, if not impossible, to police the multiplicity of so-called agreements which would ensue. Thankfully, that situation is unlikely to occur.

Insofar as the instance reported is concerned officers of my Department have ascertained that although the company involved is based in Queensland its employees work in New South Wales. In these circumstances and having regard to the nature of the work performed it is likely an award of the Industrial Commission of New South Wales applies to the employment in question. I am advised inquiries are being made by the New South Wales Department of Industrial Relations to ascertain whether the terms of the award have been complied with.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June 1986 (Hansard pages 3455-57), Senator Mason asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Health a supplementary question to a question without notice regarding the glamorisation of the use of cocaine by Australian media, both film and television. The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

ANSWER.PARA: Sub-regulation 4a (1a) (a) (v) of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, prohibits the importation of publications, including videotapes, which ``promote or incite the misuse of a drug specified in the Fourth Schedule''. Sub-regulation 4a (1a) (b) (i) further prohibits the importation of any goods that `depict, express or are otherwise concerned with matters of . . . . drug misuse or addiction . . . . in a manner that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person to the extent that they should not be imported'.

Similar provisions exist in the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983, which was designed to be model legislation for adoption by the States and governs the sale and hire of films and videotapes offered for sale and hire. Sub-section 25 (3) states that ``The Censorhip Board shall refuse to approve the classification of a film when the Board is satisfied that the film depicts, expresses or otherwise deals with matters of . . . .drug misuse or addiction . . . in such a manner that it offends against the standards of morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by reasonable adult persons to the extent that it should not be classified''.

The Film Censorship Board, in classifying the multiplicity of films and videotapes presented to it, has drawn up a set of guidelines for the classification of videotapes and discs for sale or hire. These include a `Refused Classification' which covers instruction ``manuals'' for the abuse of hard drugs. The guidelines were endorsed by State and Federal Ministers with responsibility for censorship at a meeting in April 1984 and, together with the legislation set out above, provide clear evidence of the Government's opposition to any glamorisation of drug use.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 June 1986 (Hansard, page 3630), Senator Crichton-Browne asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In 1984-85 the Labor Government set a target of 4,000 business migrants but achieved a result of only 1,417 such migrants. In 1985-86 the target was raised to 4,500. It is projected that only 1,800 such people will migrate. Why is this so?
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Business migration program figures each year are given as estimates. In the past two financial years, the program has been set high as an expression of the Government's positive attitude to business migration.

Program numbers have not been met in 1984/85 and 1985/86, although the increase over the period is expected to be about 27 per cent. The reasons are: first, the numbers of potential business migrants world-wide are small; and second, there is strong competition from a number of countries operating similar schemes to attract business migrants.

The new business migration policy introduced on 1 July 1985 has received a positive response world-wide. Interest is increasing but, because of delays in business people settling their affairs and transferring their assets to Australia, the actual increase in arrivals will not show significantly until 1986/87.

The program estimate for 1986/87 is 2,500 visas for business migrants and their dependants, about 40 per cent higher than the number expected for 1985/86. This has been set as a realistic program. We will be more than happy to exceed this program if applications are greater than estimated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps has the Government taken to ensure the safety of Australians both here and abroad, in the wake of the Chernobyl nuclear meltdown.
(2) What steps are being taken to monitor, abroad or on return to Australia, the exposure to radiation of Australian travellers in Europe.
(3) What advice has been given to Australian travellers in relation to precautions and to the danger of particular areas as a result of the Chernobyl meltdown.
(4) Are Australian travellers able to obtain any of this useful information from Australian officials in other countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In response to the accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Station, the Department of Foreign Affairs speedily convened a Task Force comprising experts from a number of related disciplines to advise on the situation. In addition the Australian Atomic Energy Commission established its own task force to advise the Government on the nature and implications of the accident.

The Task Force set up by the Department of Foreign Affairs met on four occasions and, following each meeting, issued advice to all Australian Resident Mission overseas, Commonwealth and State Health Departments, Qantas and other interested bodies in Australia.

Staff at Australian Missions have been kept fully advised of precautions to be followed with regard to the consumption of food products. This information has been available at Australian missions for Australians travelling overseas who wish to seek advice.

Australian missions have also been advised, where necessary, to source fresh food supplies from countries which have imposed contaminant standards and a sustained monitoring programme on produce. Moreover, missions have been advised to ensure that tinned or preserved food was produced before 26 April 1986 or to obtain it from the listed countries. The Department of Health has provided a listing of those countries whose standards in this regard are known to and recognised by them.

Australian citizen known to be resident in Kiev at the time of the accident were advised to leave the area. Also, Ambassadors were authorised to approve temporary evacuation where requested from missions in the regions of concern. In respect of children and wives of staff who left following the accident, all have now returned.

As information has come to hand travellers have been informed via Department of Foreign Affairs travel advisory notices to media channels, Foreign Affairs Offices throughout Australia and Australian Missions overseas of the necessary precautions to follow and the countries or areas best avoided.
(2) The Department of Health has provided the following additional information-
The levels of radioactive contamination reported in the various European countries are such that there appears to be only a very small health risk.

Levels of contamination in all European countries have returned almost to pre-existing background levels and it is therefore considered that travel to Europe presents very little radiation risk with the exception of the immediate area surrounding Chernobyl.
The Department of Health has requested the Australian Customs Service to identify for inspection all food imports from affected areas to assist in the evaluation of possible elevated radioactivity.

The major isotope of immediate concern following the reactor failure was Iodine-131. However, this isotope was no longer a source of concern by early to mid-June (approximately thirty-five to forty days after the accident).
It is most unlikely that Australian travellers returning from the affected areas of Eastern Europe are at risk.

(3) and (4) General advice was provided by the Department of Foreign Affairs to Australian travellers in the form of three travel advisory notices distributed through media channels and to Foreign Affairs Offices throughout Australia; these notices were cabled to Australian Missions overseas and are available to Australians enquiring at any mission. The last advisory repeated hereunder dated 28 July 1986 remains current.

There are indications that areas within the USSR for 100 kms or more to the north and north-west of the Chernobyl site remain affected by higher than normal radiation levels. Travellers may wish to take note of this.

Travellers should also note that while radioactivity levels in most of Eastern Europe have effectively returned to levels before the Chernobyl incident, a residual risk of exposure may continue to be present through eating and drinking some foods and beverages. However, short term exposures of several days to these products will not result in significant increases in the radiation burden in the body and will not present significant health risks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 27 may 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is an advisory body to be established, in light of the final report by the Working Party of the Australian Capital Territory Education Consultative Group on Post Compulsory Education Facilities in Tuggeranong which states:

``In view of the special character of the institution proposed, it is important that an advisory body should be established at an early date to provide a continuing point of reference for consultations and planning of the College''.
(2) When will it be established.
(3) Who will comprise the body and how will they be selected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A decision has not yet been taken on whether an advisory body should be established at this stage to advise on the development of the proposed Tuggeranong Community College. Planning is proceeding for the secondary college component of the College. This is expected to open in 1990 and nearer the time of this opening, there will be a decision on whether an advisory body of the type suggested should be established.
(2) and (3) These questions are not relevant as no decision has been taken on whether to establish the proposed advisory body.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Children's Services Ordinance 1986

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 10 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With whom were consultations held concerning the content of the proposed Children's Services Ordinance 1986, prior to the ordinance being drafted.
(2) Were Australian Capital Territory parents consulted or their views sought; if so, who was contacted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A formal reference was made to the Australian Law Reform Commission by the Attorney-General in February 1979 requesting the Commission to inquire into and report on child welfare law in the ACT.
The Commission's final Report (No. 18 Child Welfare 1981) included a draft ordinance which was the basis for the Children's Services Ordinance 1986.
The Commission was assisted by a group of consultants drawn from the universities, police, welfare and health agencies (see Attachment A).

During its inquiry the Commission undertook extensive consultation with a wide range of interested parties including State Departments, magistrates, police, welfare officers, persons involved in health, education and voluntary work, and parents and children.
Public hearings were held in May 1979 and May 1980 to allow interested persons to make comments and submissions.
A series of seminars was also held with agencies working in the child welfare field in the ACT.

Those providing oral and written submissions to the Commission during its inquiry are shown in Attachment B. It should be noted that submissions were received from both non-profit and commercial day care interests.

The Law Reform Commission's draft ordinance, together with a list of possible amendments and a Departmental report on ACT facilities and services for children, were forwarded to the House of Assembly for comment in May 1983. The matter was referred to the Standing Committee on Health, Housing and Welfare.
The Assembly sought comments and submissions through advertisements in the Canberra Times. Eight submissions were received.
The Standing Committee consulted with the Law Reform Commission and the Department concerning the draft ordinance.
A public meeting was held at the House of Assembly in July 1983.
The Assembly presented its Report in October 1983.
On 26 February 1986 the Minister referred the draft Children's Services Ordinance to the House of Assembly for consideration and report.
The Health, Housing and Welfare Committee sought the views of various Government Departments and other relevant organisations such as ACTCOSS, the Children's Court, and the Law Reform Commission.
Comments on the Ordinance were invited from interested individuals and groups through advertisements in the Canberra Times in March 1986. Submissions were received from the following:
Archdiocese of Canberra and Goulburn: Catholic Welfare Advisory Committee
Capital Territory Health Commission: Child Abuse Committee
National Council of Women of ACT Inc.
R. J. Cahill and C. J. Stanforth
Royal Australian Navy: Navy Social Worker
The Committee met with and received submissions from community organisations, the Chief Magistrate, officers of the Department of Territories and the ACT Health Authority.
A public conference to discuss the draft ordinance was held by Richmond Fellowship on 28 April 1986.
Representatives of various government and non-government agencies attended.

The Department of Territories also consulted about parts of the proposed ordinance with a range of relevant authorities including the Attorney-General's Department, the Australian Federal Police, the Department of Education and the ACT Health Authority.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 10 July 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What consideration has been given to equip Australian Airports with landing facilities to permit the landing of aircraft at times when vision is obscured by fog or cloud.
(2) What system is contemplated.
(3) When is a start expected.
(4) Which ports are, or would be, under consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The Department of Aviation currently operates and maintains 467 radio navigation aids throughout Australia, to assist aircraft to navigate and land when vision is obscured by fog or cloud. Additions and variations to the system are determined by changes in aviation industry requirements, volume of traffic and mix of aircraft types.
